It\xe2\x80\x99s away from the railway; it\xe2\x80\x99s away from the high-road: it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nkept by a decent, respectable Scotchwoman--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDecent, respectable Scotchwomen who keep inns,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Geoffrey,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t cotton to young ladies who are traveling alone. The landlady\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t receive you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was a well-aimed objection--but it missed the mark. A woman bent on\r\nher marriage is a woman who can meet the objections of the whole world,\r\nsingle-handed, and refute them all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have provided for every thing,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cand I have provided for\r\nthat. I shall tell the landlady I am on my wedding-trip. I shall say\r\nmy husband is sight-seeing, on foot, among the mountains in the\r\nneighborhood--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is sure to believe that!\xe2\x80\x9d said Geoffrey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is sure to _dis_believe it, if you like. Let her! You have only\r\nto appear, and to ask for your wife--and there is my story proved to be\r\ntrue! She may be the most suspicious woman living, as long as I am alone\r\nwith her. The moment you join me, you set her suspicions at rest. Leave\r\nme to do my part. My part is the hard one. Will you do yours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was impossible to say No: she had fairly cut the ground from under\r\nhis feet. He shifted his ground. Any thing rather than say Yes!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose _you_ know how we are to be married?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cAll I can\r\nsay is--_I_ don\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do!\xe2\x80\x9d she retorted. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know that we are in Scotland. You know that\r\nthere are neither forms, ceremonies, nor delays in marriage, here. The\r\nplan I have proposed to you secures my being received at the inn, and\r\nmakes it easy and natural for you to join me there afterward. The\r\nrest is in our own hands. A man and a woman who wish to be married (in\r\nScotland) have only to secure the necessary witnesses and the thing is\r\ndone. If the landlady chooses to resent the deception practiced on her,\r\nafter that, the landlady may do as she pleases. We shall have gained\r\nour object in spite of her--and, what is more, we shall have gained it\r\nwithout risk to _you._\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t lay it all on my shoulders,\xe2\x80\x9d Geoffrey rejoined. \xe2\x80\x9cYou women\r\ngo headlong at every thing. Say we are married. We must separate\r\nafterward--or how are we to keep it a secret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly. You will go back, of course, to your brother\xe2\x80\x99s house, as if\r\nnothing had happened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is to become of _you?_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall go to London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you to do in London?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaven\xe2\x80\x99t I already told you that I have thought of every thing? When I\r\nget to London I shall apply to some of my mother\xe2\x80\x99s old friends--friends\r\nof hers in the time when she was a musician. Every body tells me I have\r\na voice--if I had only cultivated it. I _will_ cultivate it! I can live,\r\nand live respectably, as a concert singer. I have saved money enough to\r\nsupport me, while I am learning--and my mother\xe2\x80\x99s friends will help me,\r\nfor her sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo, in the new life that she was marking out, was she now unconsciously\r\nreflecting in herself the life of her mother before her. Here was the\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s career as a public singer, chosen (in spite of all efforts to\r\nprevent it) by the child! Here (though with other motives, and under\r\nother circumstances) was the mother\xe2\x80\x99s irregular marriage in Ireland,\r\non the point of being followed by the daughter\xe2\x80\x99s irregular marriage in\r\nScotland! And here, stranger still, was the man who was answerable for\r\nit--the son of the man who had found the flaw in the Irish marriage, and\r\nhad shown the way by which her mother was thrown on the world! \xe2\x80\x9cMy Anne\r\nis my second self. She is not called by her father\xe2\x80\x99s name; she is called\r\nby mine. She is Anne Silvester as I was. Will she end like Me?\xe2\x80\x9d--The\r\nanswer to those words--the last words that had trembled on the dying\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s lips--was coming fast. Through the chances and changes of many\r\nyears, the future was pressing near--and Anne Silvester stood on the\r\nbrink of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d she resumed. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you at the end of your objections? Can you\r\ngive me a plain answer at last?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo! He had another objection ready as the words passed her lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose the witnesses at the inn happen to know me?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cSuppose\r\nit comes to my father\xe2\x80\x99s ears in that way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose you drive me to my death?\xe2\x80\x9d she retorted, starting to her feet.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour father shall know the truth, in that case--I swear it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe rose, on his side, and drew back from her. She followed him up. There\r\nwas a clapping of hands, at the same moment, on the lawn. Somebody had\r\nevidently made a brilliant stroke which promised to decide the game.\r\nThere was no security now that Blanche might not return again. There\r\nwas every prospect, the game being over, that Lady Lundie would be free.\r\nAnne brought the interview to its crisis, without wasting a moment more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Geoffrey Delamayn,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have bargained for a private\r\nmarriage, and I have consented. Are you, or are you not, ready to marry\r\nme on your own terms?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me a minute to think!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot an instant. Once for all, is it Yes, or No?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe couldn\xe2\x80\x99t say \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d even then. But he said what was equivalent to it.\r\nHe asked, savagely, \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the inn?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe put her arm in his, and whispered, rapidly, \xe2\x80\x9cPass the road on the\r\nright that leads to the railway. Follow the path over the moor, and the\r\nsheep-track up the hill. The first house you come to after that is the\r\ninn. You understand!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe nodded his head, with a sullen frown, and took his pipe out of his\r\npocket again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet it alone this time,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, meeting her eye. \xe2\x80\x9cMy mind\xe2\x80\x99s upset.\r\nWhen a man\xe2\x80\x99s mind\xe2\x80\x99s upset, a man can\xe2\x80\x99t smoke. What\xe2\x80\x99s the name of the\r\nplace?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCraig Fernie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho am I to ask for at the door?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor your wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose they want you to give your name when you get there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I must give a name, I shall call myself Mrs., instead of Miss,\r\nSilvester. But I shall do my best to avoid giving any name. And you will\r\ndo your best to avoid making a mistake, by only asking for me as your\r\nwife. Is there any thing else you want to know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe quick about it! What is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow am I to know you have got away from here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t hear from me in half an hour from the time when I have\r\nleft you, you may be sure I have got away. Hush!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTwo voices, in conversation, were audible at the bottom of the\r\nsteps--Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s voice and Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s. Anne pointed to the door\r\nin the back wall of the summer-house. She had just pulled it to again,\r\nafter Geoffrey had passed through it, when Lady Lundie and Sir Patrick\r\nappeared at the top of the steps.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE SIXTH.\r\n\r\nTHE SUITOR.\r\n\r\nLADY LUNDIE pointed significantly to the door, and addressed herself to\r\nSir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s private ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cObserve!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Silvester has just got rid of somebody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick deliberately looked in the wrong direction, and (in the\r\npolitest possible manner) observed--nothing.\r\n\r\nLady Lundie advanced into the summer-house. Suspicious hatred of the\r\ngoverness was written legibly in every line of her face. Suspicious\r\ndistrust of the governess\xe2\x80\x99s illness spoke plainly in every tone of her\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I inquire, Miss Silvester, if your sufferings are relieved?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am no better, Lady Lundie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said I was no better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou appear to be able to stand up. The interview with Geoffrey had worn her out;\r\nthere was no spirit left in her to resist the petty malice of the woman,\r\nafter bearing, as she had borne it, the brutish indifference of the man.\r\nIn another moment the hysterical suffering which she was keeping down\r\nwould have forced its way outward in tears. With a little jaunty flourish of the hand,\r\nhe dusted the stray grains of snuff off his finger and thumb, and looked\r\nback again at the lawn-party, and became more absorbed in the diversions\r\nof his young friends than ever.\r\n\r\nLady Lundie stood her ground, plainly determined to force a serious\r\nexpression of opinion from her brother-in-law. Before she could speak\r\nagain, Arnold and Blanche appeared together at the bottom of the steps.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when does the dancing begin?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Sir Patrick, advancing to\r\nmeet them, and looking as if he felt the deepest interest in a speedy\r\nsettlement of the question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe very thing I was going to ask mamma,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Blanche. \xe2\x80\x9cIs she in\r\nthere with Anne? Is Anne better?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie forthwith appeared, and took the answer to that inquiry on\r\nherself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Silvester has retired to her room. Miss Silvester persists in\r\nbeing ill. Any thing that _you_ wish!\xe2\x80\x9d With that parting shot at her\r\nstep-mother, Blanche withdrew. Arnold, who had thus far waited in\r\nsilence at the foot of the steps, looked appealingly at Sir Patrick. The\r\ntrain which was to take him to his newly inherited property would start\r\nin less than an hour; and he had not presented himself to Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nguardian in the character of Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s suitor yet! She returned to the charge--in spite of Sir Patrick,\r\nhumming at the top of the steps, and of Arnold, waiting at the bottom.\r\n(Her enemies said, \xe2\x80\x9cNo wonder poor Sir Thomas died in a few months after\r\nhis marriage!\xe2\x80\x9d And, oh dear me, our enemies _are_ sometimes right!)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must once more remind you, Sir Patrick, that I have serious reason\r\nto doubt whether Miss Silvester is a fit companion for Blanche. She\r\nposts her own letters--_and,_ she has lately been excessively insolent\r\nto Me. There is something wrong. At my age,\xe2\x80\x9d added Sir Patrick, cunningly drifting into\r\ngeneralities, \xe2\x80\x9cnothing is serious--except Indigestion. The guests were safe in the\r\nhouse--there was no interruption to be feared, Arnold showed himself.\r\nSir Patrick (perfectly undisturbed by Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s parting speech) sat\r\ndown in the summer-house, without noticing his young friend, and asked\r\nhimself a question founded on profound observation of the female sex.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere there ever two women yet with a quarrel between them,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\r\nthe old gentleman, \xe2\x80\x9cwho didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to drag a man into it? Do you follow\r\nme, so far?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nYes. Do you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take my oath to every inch of it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShop?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNature!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick rose to his feet; his satirical humor was silenced at last.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf ever I have a son,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cthat son shall go\r\nto sea!\xe2\x80\x9d He took Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s arm, as a preliminary to putting an end to\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s suspense. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I _can_ be serious about any thing,\xe2\x80\x9d he resumed,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s time to be serious with you. I am convinced of the sincerity of\r\nyour attachment. All I know of you is in your favor, and your birth and\r\nposition are beyond dispute. If you have Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s consent, you have\r\nmine.\xe2\x80\x9d Arnold attempted to express his gratitude. Sir Patrick, declining\r\nto hear him, went on. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd remember this, in the future. When you next\r\nwant any thing that I can give you, ask for it plainly. Don\xe2\x80\x99t attempt to\r\nmystify _me_ on the next occasion, and I will promise, on my side, not\r\nto mystify _you._ There, that\xe2\x80\x99s understood. Now about this journey of\r\nyours to see your estate. Property has its duties, Master Arnold, as\r\nwell as its rights. The time is fast coming when its rights will be\r\ndisputed, if its duties are not performed. I have got a new interest in\r\nyou, and I mean to see that you do your duty. It\xe2\x80\x99s settled you are to\r\nleave Windygates to-day. Is it arranged how you are to go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Sir Patrick. Lady Lundie has kindly ordered the gig to take me to\r\nthe station, in time for the next train.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen are you to be ready?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold looked at his watch. \xe2\x80\x9cIn a quarter of an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good. Mind you _are_ ready. Stop a minute! you will have plenty of\r\ntime to speak to Blanche when I have done with you. You don\xe2\x80\x99t appear to\r\nme to be sufficiently anxious about seeing your own property.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not very anxious to leave Blanche, Sir--that\xe2\x80\x99s the truth of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind Blanche. Blanche is not business. They both begin with a\r\nB--and that\xe2\x80\x99s the only connection between them. I hear you have got one\r\nof the finest houses in this part of Scotland. How long are you going to\r\nstay in Scotland? How long are you going to stay in it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have arranged (as I have already told you, Sir) to return to\r\nWindygates the day after to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Here is a man with a palace waiting to receive him--and he is\r\nonly going to stop one clear day in it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not going to stop in it at all, Sir Patrick--I am going to stay\r\nwith the steward. I\xe2\x80\x99m only wanted to be present to-morrow at a dinner\r\nto my tenants--and, when that\xe2\x80\x99s over, there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing in the world to\r\nprevent my coming back here. The steward himself told me so in his last\r\nletter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if the steward told you so, of course there is nothing more to be\r\nsaid!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t object to my coming back! pray don\xe2\x80\x99t, Sir Patrick! I\xe2\x80\x99ll promise\r\nto live in my new house when I have got Blanche to live in it with me.\r\nIf you won\xe2\x80\x99t mind, I\xe2\x80\x99ll go and tell her at once that it all belongs to\r\nher as well as to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGently! gently! you talk as if you were married to her already!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s as good as done, Sir! Where\xe2\x80\x99s the difficulty in the way now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he asked the question the shadow of some third person, advancing\r\nfrom the side of the summer-house, was thrown forward on the open sunlit\r\nspace at the top of the steps. In a moment more the shadow was followed\r\nby the substance--in the shape of a groom in his riding livery. The man\r\nwas plainly a stranger to the place. He started, and touched his hat,\r\nwhen he saw the two gentlemen in the summer-house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Sir Patrick\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, Sir; I was sent by my master--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is your master?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Honorable Mr. Delamayn, Sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean Mr. Geoffrey Delamayn?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Arnold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Sir. Mr. Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s brother--Mr. Julius. I have ridden over from\r\nthe house, Sir, with a message from my master to Mr. Geoffrey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you find him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey told me I should find him hereabouts, Sir. But I\xe2\x80\x99m a stranger, and\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t rightly know where to look.\xe2\x80\x9d He stopped, and took a card out of\r\nhis pocket. \xe2\x80\x9cMy master said it was very important I should deliver this\r\nimmediately. Would you be pleased to tell me, gentlemen, if you happen\r\nto know where Mr. Geoffrey is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold turned to Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t seen him. Have you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have smelt him,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Sir Patrick, \xe2\x80\x9cever since I have been in\r\nthe summer-house. There is a detestable taint of tobacco in the\r\nair--suggestive (disagreeably suggestive to _my_ mind) of your friend,\r\nMr. Delamayn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold laughed, and stepped outside the summer-house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are right, Sir Patrick, we will find him at once.\xe2\x80\x9d He looked\r\naround, and shouted, \xe2\x80\x9cGeoffrey!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA voice from the rose-garden shouted back, \xe2\x80\x9cHullo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re wanted. Come here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeoffrey appeared, sauntering doggedly, with his pipe in his mouth, and\r\nhis hands in his pockets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho wants me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA groom--from your brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat answer appeared to electrify the lounging and lazy athlete.\r\nGeoffrey hurried, with eager steps, to the summer-house. He addressed\r\nthe groom before the man had time to speak With horror and dismay in his\r\nface, he exclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Jupiter! Ratcatcher has relapsed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick and Arnold looked at each other in blank amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe best horse in my brother\xe2\x80\x99s stables!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Geoffrey, explaining,\r\nand appealing to them, in a breath. \xe2\x80\x9cI left written directions with the\r\ncoachman, I measured out his physic for three days; I bled him,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nGeoffrey, in a voice broken by emotion--\xe2\x80\x9cI bled him myself, last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, Sir--\xe2\x80\x9d began the groom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use of begging my pardon? You\xe2\x80\x99re a pack of infernal\r\nfools! Where\xe2\x80\x99s your horse? I\xe2\x80\x99ll ride back, and break every bone in the\r\ncoachman\xe2\x80\x99s skin! Where\xe2\x80\x99s your horse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you please, Sir, it isn\xe2\x80\x99t Ratcatcher. Ratcatcher\xe2\x80\x99s all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRatcatcher\xe2\x80\x99s all right? Then what the devil is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a message, Sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout my lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! About my father?\xe2\x80\x9d He took out his handkerchief, and passed it over\r\nhis forehead, with a deep gasp of relief. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought it was Ratcatcher,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n he said, looking at Arnold, with a smile. He put his pipe into his\r\nmouth, and rekindled the dying ashes of the tobacco. \xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d he went on,\r\nwhen the pipe was in working order, and his voice was composed again:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s up with my father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA telegram from London, Sir. Bad news of my lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man produced his master\xe2\x80\x99s card.\r\n\r\nGeoffrey read on it (written in his brother\xe2\x80\x99s handwriting) these words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have only a moment to scribble a line on my card. Our father is\r\ndangerously ill--his lawyer has been sent for. Come with me to London by\r\nthe first train. Meet at the junction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithout a word to any one of the three persons present, all silently\r\nlooking at him, Geoffrey consulted his watch. Anne had told him to wait\r\nhalf an hour, and to assume that she had gone if he failed to hear from\r\nher in that time. The interval had passed--and no communication of\r\nany sort had reached him. The flight from the house had been safely\r\naccomplished. Anne Silvester was, at that moment, on her way to the\r\nmountain inn.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE SEVENTH.\r\n\r\nTHE DEBT.\r\n\r\nARNOLD was the first who broke the silence. \xe2\x80\x9cIs your father seriously\r\nill?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nGeoffrey answered by handing him the card.\r\n\r\nSir Patrick, who had stood apart (while the question of Ratcatcher\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nrelapse was under discussion) sardonically studying the manners and\r\ncustoms of modern English youth, now came forward, and took his part\r\nin the proceedings. Lady Lundie herself must have acknowledged that he\r\nspoke and acted as became the head of the family, on t his occasion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I right in supposing that Mr. Delamayn\xe2\x80\x99s father is dangerously ill?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n he asked, addressing himself to Arnold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDangerously ill, in London,\xe2\x80\x9d Arnold answered. \xe2\x80\x9cGeoffrey must leave\r\nWindygates with me. The train I am traveling by meets the train his\r\nbrother is traveling by, at the junction. I shall leave him at the\r\nsecond station from here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t you tell me that Lady Lundie was going to send you to the\r\nrailway in a gig?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf the servant drives, there will be three of you--and there will be no\r\nroom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe had better ask for some other vehicle,\xe2\x80\x9d suggested Arnold.\r\n\r\nSir Patrick looked at his watch. There was no time to change the\r\ncarriage. He turned to Geoffrey. \xe2\x80\x9cCan you drive, Mr. Delamayn?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill impenetrably silent, Geoffrey replied by a nod of the head.\r\n\r\nWithout noticing the unceremonious manner in which he had been answered,\r\nSir Patrick went on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case, you can leave the gig in charge of the station-master.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell the servant that he will not be wanted to drive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me save you the trouble, Sir Patrick,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold.\r\n\r\nSir Patrick declined, by a gesture. He turned again, with undiminished\r\ncourtesy, to Geoffrey. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is one of the duties of hospitality, Mr.\r\nDelamayn, to hasten your departure, under these sad circumstances. Lady\r\nLundie is engaged with her guests. I will see myself that there is no\r\nunnecessary delay in sending you to the station.\xe2\x80\x9d He bowed--and left the\r\nsummer-house.\r\n\r\nArnold said a word of sympathy to his friend, when they were alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry for this, Geoffrey. I hope and trust you will get to London\r\nin time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stopped. There was something in Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s face--a strange mixture of\r\ndoubt and bewilderment, of annoyance and hesitation--which was not to\r\nbe accounted for as the natural result of the news that he had received.\r\nHis color shifted and changed; he picked fretfully at his finger-nails;\r\nhe looked at Arnold as if he was going to speak--and then looked away\r\nagain, in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there something amiss, Geoffrey, besides this bad news about your\r\nfather?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Arnold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m in the devil\xe2\x80\x99s own mess,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan I do any thing to help you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nInstead of making a direct reply, Geoffrey lifted his mighty hand, and\r\ngave Arnold a friendly slap on the shoulder which shook him from head\r\nto foot. Arnold steadied himself, and waited--wondering what was coming\r\nnext.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, old fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Geoffrey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember when the boat turned keel upward in Lisbon Harbor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold started. If he could have called to mind his first interview in\r\nthe summer-house with his father\xe2\x80\x99s old friend he might have remembered\r\nSir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s prediction that he would sooner or later pay, with\r\ninterest, the debt he owed to the man who had saved his life. As it was\r\nhis memory reverted at a bound to the time of the boat-accident. In\r\nthe ardor of his gratitude and the innocence of his heart, he almost\r\nresented his friend\xe2\x80\x99s question as a reproach which he had not deserved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think I can ever forget,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, warmly, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you swam\r\nashore with me and saved my life?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeoffrey ventured a step nearer to the object that he had in view.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne good turn deserves another,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold took his hand. \xe2\x80\x9cOnly tell me!\xe2\x80\x9d he eagerly rejoined--\xe2\x80\x9conly tell me\r\nwhat I can do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are going to-day to see your new place, ain\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you put off going till to-morrow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it\xe2\x80\x99s any thing serious--of course I can!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeoffrey looked round at the entrance to the summer-house, to make sure\r\nthat they were alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know the governess here, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Silvester?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got into a little difficulty with Miss Silvester. And there\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t a living soul I can ask to help me but _you._\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know I will help you. What is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t so easy to say. Never mind--you\xe2\x80\x99re no saint either, are\r\nyou? You\xe2\x80\x99ll keep it a secret, of course? Look here! I\xe2\x80\x99ve acted like an\r\ninfernal fool. I\xe2\x80\x99ve gone and got the girl into a scrape--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold drew back, suddenly understanding him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood heavens, Geoffrey! You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do! Wait a bit--that\xe2\x80\x99s not the worst of it. She has left the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeft the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeft, for good and all. She can\xe2\x80\x99t come back again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause she\xe2\x80\x99s written to her missus. Women (hang \xe2\x80\x98em!) never do these\r\nthings by halves. She\xe2\x80\x99s left a letter to say she\xe2\x80\x99s privately married,\r\nand gone off to her husband. Her husband is--Me. Not that I\xe2\x80\x99m married to\r\nher yet, you understand. I have only promised to marry her. She has gone\r\non first (on the sly) to a place four miles from this. And we settled I\r\nwas to follow, and marry her privately this afternoon. That\xe2\x80\x99s out of\r\nthe question now. While she\xe2\x80\x99s expecting me at the inn I shall be bowling\r\nalong to London. Somebody must tell her what has happened--or she\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nplay the devil, and the whole business will burst up. I can\xe2\x80\x99t trust any\r\nof the people here. I\xe2\x80\x99m done for, old chap, unless you help me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold lifted his hands in dismay. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the most dreadful situation,\r\nGeoffrey, I ever heard of in my life!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeoffrey thoroughly agreed with him. \xe2\x80\x9cEnough to knock a man over,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cisn\xe2\x80\x99t it? I\xe2\x80\x99d give something for a drink of beer.\xe2\x80\x9d He produced\r\nhis everlasting pipe, from sheer force of habit. \xe2\x80\x9cGot a match?\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nasked.\r\n\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s mind was too preoccupied to notice the question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you won\xe2\x80\x99t think I\xe2\x80\x99m making light of your father\xe2\x80\x99s illness,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, earnestly. \xe2\x80\x9cBut it seems to me--I must say it--it seems to me that\r\nthe poor girl has the first claim on you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeoffrey looked at him in surly amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe first claim on me? Do you think I\xe2\x80\x99m going to risk being cut out of\r\nmy father\xe2\x80\x99s will? Not for the best woman that ever put on a petticoat!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s admiration of his friend was the solidly-founded admiration\r\nof many years; admiration for a man who could row, box, wrestle,\r\njump--above all, who could swim--as few other men could perform those\r\nexercises in contemporary England. But that answer shook his faith. Only\r\nfor the moment--unhappily for Arnold, only for the moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know best,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned, a little coldly. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat can I do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeoffrey took his arm--roughly as he took every thing; but in a\r\ncompanionable and confidential way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, like a good fellow, and tell her what has happened. We\xe2\x80\x99ll start\r\nfrom here as if we were both going to the railway; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll drop you at\r\nthe foot-path, in the gig. You can get on to your own place afterward by\r\nthe evening train. It puts you to no inconvenience, and it\xe2\x80\x99s doing the\r\nkind thing by an old friend. There\xe2\x80\x99s no risk of being found out. I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nto drive, remember! There\xe2\x80\x99s no servant with us, old boy, to notice, and\r\ntell tales.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEven Arnold began to see dimly by this time that he was likely to pay\r\nhis debt of obligation with interest--as Sir Patrick had foretold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I to say to her?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m bound to do all I can do to\r\nhelp you, and I will. But what am I to say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was a natural question to put. It was not an easy question to answer.\r\nWhat a man, under given muscular circumstances, could do, no person\r\nliving knew better than Geoffrey Delamayn. Of what a man, under given\r\nsocial circumstances, could say, no person living knew less.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay?\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated. \xe2\x80\x9cLook here! say I\xe2\x80\x99m half distracted, and all that.\r\nAnd--wait a bit--tell her to stop where she is till I write to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold hesitated. Absolutely ignorant of that low and limited form of\r\nknowledge which is called \xe2\x80\x9cknowledge of the world,\xe2\x80\x9d his inbred delicacy\r\nof mind revealed to him the serious difficulty of the position which his\r\nfriend was asking him to occupy as plainly as if he was looking at it\r\nthrough the warily-gathered experience of society of a man of twice his\r\nage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you write to her now, Geoffrey?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the good of that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConsider for a minute, and you will see. You have trusted me with a\r\nvery awkward secret. I may be wrong--I never was mixed up in such a\r\nmatter before--but to present myself to this lady as your messenger\r\nseems exposing her to a dreadful humiliation. Am I to go and tell her\r\nto her face: \xe2\x80\x98I know what you are hiding from the knowledge of all the\r\nworld;\xe2\x80\x99 and is she to be expected to endure it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBosh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Geoffrey. \xe2\x80\x9cThey can endure a deal more than you think.\r\nI wish you had heard how she bullied me, in this very place. My good\r\nfellow, you don\xe2\x80\x99t understand women. The grand secret, in dealing with a\r\nwoman, is to take her as you take a cat, by the scruff of the neck--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t face her--unless you will help me by breaking the thing to\r\nher first. I\xe2\x80\x99ll stick at no sacrifice to serve you; but--hang it!--make\r\nallowances, Geoffrey, for the difficulty you are putting me in. I am\r\nalmost a stranger; I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how Miss Silvester may receive me,\r\nbefore I can open my lips.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThose last words touched the question on its practical side. The\r\nmatter-of-fact view of the difficulty was a view which Geoffrey\r\ninstantly recognized and understood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has the devil\xe2\x80\x99s own temper,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no denying that.\r\nPerhaps I\xe2\x80\x99d better write. Have we time to go into the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. The house is full of people, and we haven\xe2\x80\x99t a minute to spare.\r\nWrite at once, and write here. I have got a pencil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I to write on?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny thing--your brother\xe2\x80\x99s card.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeoffrey took the pencil which Arnold offered to him, and looked at the\r\ncard. The lines his brother had written covered it. There was no room\r\nleft. He felt in his pocket, and produced a letter--the letter which\r\nAnne had referred to at the interview between them--the letter which she\r\nhad written to insist on his attending the lawn-party at Windygates.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis will do,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s one of Anne\xe2\x80\x99s own letters to me. There\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nroom on the fourth page. If I write,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, turning suddenly on\r\nArnold, \xe2\x80\x9cyou promise to take it to her? Your hand on the bargain!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe held out the hand which had saved Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s life in Lisbon Harbor, and\r\nreceived Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s promise, in remembrance of that time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, old fellow. I can tell you how to find the place as we go\r\nalong in the gig. By-the-by, there\xe2\x80\x99s one thing that\xe2\x80\x99s rather important.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d better mention it while I think of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t present yourself at the inn in your own name; and you\r\nmustn\xe2\x80\x99t ask for her by _her_ name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho am I to ask for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a little awkward. She has gone there as a married woman, in case\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99re particular about taking her in--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand. Go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd she has planned to tell them (by way of making it all right and\r\nstraight for both of us, you know) that she expects her husband to join\r\nher. If I had been able to go I should have asked at the door for \xe2\x80\x98my\r\nwife.\xe2\x80\x99 You are going in my place--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I must ask at the door for \xe2\x80\x98my wife,\xe2\x80\x99 or I shall expose Miss\r\nSilvester to unpleasant consequences?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t object?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot I! I don\xe2\x80\x99t care what I say to the people of the inn. It\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nmeeting with Miss Silvester that I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll put that right for you--never fear!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went at once to the table and rapidly scribbled a few lines--then\r\nstopped and considered. \xe2\x80\x9cWill that do?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked himself. \xe2\x80\x9cNo; I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nbetter say something spooney to quiet her.\xe2\x80\x9d He considered again, added a\r\nline, and brought his hand down on the table with a cheery smack.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will do the business! Read it yourself, Arnold--it\xe2\x80\x99s not so badly\r\nwritten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold read the note without appearing to share his friend\xe2\x80\x99s favorable\r\nopinion of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is rather short,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave I time to make it longer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps not. But let Miss Silvester see for herself that you have no\r\ntime to make it longer. The train starts in less than half an hour. Put\r\nthe time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, all right! and the date too, if you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had just added the desired words and figures, and had given the\r\nrevised letter to Arnold, when Sir Patrick returned to announce that the\r\ngig was waiting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou haven\xe2\x80\x99t a moment to lose!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeoffrey started to his feet. Arnold hesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must see Blanche!\xe2\x80\x9d he pleaded. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t leave Blanche without saying\r\ngood-by. Where is she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick pointed to the steps, with a smile. Blanche had followed him\r\nfrom the house. Arnold ran out to her instantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGoing?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, a little sadly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be back in two days,\xe2\x80\x9d Arnold whispered. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all right! Sir\r\nPatrick consents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe held him fast by the arm. The hurried parting before other people\r\nseemed to be not a parting to Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s taste.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will lose the train!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Sir Patrick.\r\n\r\nGeoffrey seized Arnold by the arm which Blanche was holding, and\r\ntore him--literally tore him--away. The two were out of sight, in the\r\nshrubbery, before Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s indignation found words, and addressed\r\nitself to her uncle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy is that brute going away with Mr. Brinkworth?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Delamayn is called to London by his father\xe2\x80\x99s illness,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Sir\r\nPatrick. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t like him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hate him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick reflected a little.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is a young girl of eighteen,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I am an\r\nold man of seventy. Curious, that we should agree about any thing. More\r\nthan curious that we should agree in disliking Mr. Delamayn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe roused himself, and looked again at Blanche. She was seated at the\r\ntable, with her head on her hand; absent, and out of spirits--thinking\r\nof Arnold, and set, with the future all smooth before them, not thinking\r\nhappily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Blanche! Blanche!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Sir Patrick, \xe2\x80\x9cone would think he had gone\r\nfor a voyage round the world. You silly child! he will be back again the\r\nday after to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t gone with that man!\xe2\x80\x9d said Blanche. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngot that man for a friend!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere! there! the man was rude enough I own. Never mind! he will leave\r\nthe man at the second station. Come back to the ball-room with me. Dance\r\nit off, my dear--dance it off!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Blanche. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m in no humor for dancing. I shall go up\r\nstairs, and talk about it to Anne.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will do nothing of the sort!\xe2\x80\x9d said a third voice, suddenly joining\r\nin the conversation.\r\n\r\nBoth uncle and niece looked up, and found Lady Lundie at the top of the\r\nsummer-house steps.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI forbid you to mention that woman\xe2\x80\x99s name again in my hearing,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued\r\nher ladyship. \xe2\x80\x9cSir Patrick! I warned you (if you remember?) that the\r\nmatter of the governess was not a matter to be trifled with. My worst\r\nanticipations are realized. Miss Silvester has left the house!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE EIGHTH.\r\n\r\nTHE SCANDAL.\r\n\r\nIT was still early in the afternoon when the guests at Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlawn-party began to compare notes together in corners, and to agree in\r\narriving at a general conviction that \xe2\x80\x9csome thing was wrong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche had mysteriously disappeared from her partners in the dance.\r\nLady Lundie had mysteriously abandoned her guests. Blanche had not\r\ncome back. Lady Lundie had returned with an artificial smile, and a\r\npreoccupied manner. She acknowledged that she was \xe2\x80\x9cnot very well.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nsame excuse had been given to account for Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s absence--and, again\r\n(some time previously), to explain Miss Silvester\xe2\x80\x99s withdrawal from the\r\ncroquet! A wit among the gentlemen declared it reminded him of declining\r\na verb. \xe2\x80\x9cI am not very well; thou art not very well; she is not very\r\nwell\xe2\x80\x9d--and so on. Sir Patrick too! Only think of the sociable Sir\r\nPatrick being in a state of seclusion--pacing up and down by himself in\r\nthe loneliest part of the garden. And the servants again! it had even\r\nspread to the servants! _They_ were presuming to whisper in corners,\r\nlike their betters. The house-maids appeared, spasmodically, where house\r\nmaids had no business to be. Doors banged and petticoats whisked in the\r\nupper regions. Something wrong--depend upon it, something wrong! \xe2\x80\x9cWe\r\nhad much better go away. My dear, order the carriage\xe2\x80\x9d--\xe2\x80\x9cLouisa, love,\r\nno more dancing; your papa is going.\xe2\x80\x9d--\xe2\x80\x9c_Good_-afternoon, Lady\r\nLundie!\xe2\x80\x9d--\xe2\x80\x9cHaw! thanks very much!\xe2\x80\x9d--\xe2\x80\x9c_So_ sorry for dear Blanche!\xe2\x80\x9d--\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s been _too_ charming!\xe2\x80\x9d So Society jabbered its poor, nonsensical\r\nlittle jargon, and got itself politely out of the way before the storm\r\ncame.\r\n\r\nThis was exactly the consummation of events for which Sir Patrick had\r\nbeen waiting in the seclusion of the garden.\r\n\r\nThere was no evading the responsibility which was now thrust upon him.\r\nLady Lundie had announced it as a settled resolution, on her part, to\r\ntrace Anne to the place in which she had taken refuge, and discover\r\n(purely in the interests of virtue) whether she actually was married\r\nor not. Blanche (already overwrought by the excitement of the day) had\r\nbroken into an hysterical passion of tears on hearing the news, and had\r\nthen, on recovering, taken a view of her own of Anne\xe2\x80\x99s flight from the\r\nhouse. Anne would never have kept her marriage a secret from Blanche;\r\nAnne would never have written such a formal farewell letter as she had\r\nwritten to Blanche--if things were going as smoothly with her as she\r\nwas trying to make them believe at Windygates. Some dreadful trouble\r\nhad fallen on Anne and Blanche was determined (as Lady Lundie was\r\ndetermined) to find out where she had gone, and to follow, and help her.\r\n\r\nIt was plain to Sir Patrick (to whom both ladies had opened their\r\nhearts, at separate interviews) that his sister-in-law, in one way, and\r\nhis niece in another, were equally likely--if not duly restrained--to\r\nplunge headlong into acts of indiscretion which might lead to very\r\nundesirable results. A man in authority was sorely needed at Windygates\r\nthat afternoon--and Sir Patrick was fain to acknowledge that he was the\r\nman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuch is to be said for, and much is to be said against a single\r\nlife,\xe2\x80\x9d thought the old gentleman, walking up and down the sequestered\r\ngarden-path to which he had retired, and applying himself at shorter\r\nintervals than usual to the knob of his ivory cane. \xe2\x80\x9cThis, however,\r\nis, I take it, certain. A man\xe2\x80\x99s married friends can\xe2\x80\x99t prevent him from\r\nleading the life of a bachelor, if he pleases. But they can, and do,\r\ntake devilish good care that he sha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t enjoy it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s meditations were interrupted by the appearance of a\r\nservant, previously instructed to keep him informed of the progress of\r\nevents at the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re all gone, Sir Patrick,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a comfort, Simpson. We have no visitors to deal with now, except\r\nthe visitors who are staying in the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone, Sir Patrick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re all gentlemen, are they not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Sir Patrick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s another comfort, Simpson. Very good. I\xe2\x80\x99ll see Lady Lundie\r\nfirst.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDoes any other form of human resolution approach the firmness of a\r\nwoman who is bent on discovering the frailties of another woman whom she\r\nhates? You may move rocks, under a given set of circumstances. But here\r\nis a delicate being in petticoats, who shrieks if a spider drops on her\r\nneck, and shudders if you approach her after having eaten an onion. Can\r\nyou move _her,_ under a given set of circumstances, as set forth above?\r\nNot you!\r\n\r\nSir Patrick found her ladyship instituting her inquiries on the same\r\nadmirably exhaustive system which is pursued, in cases of disappearance,\r\nby the police. Who was the last witness who had seen the missing person?\r\nWho was the last servant who had seen Anne Silvester? Begin with the\r\nmen-servants, from the butler at the top to the stable boy at the\r\nbottom. Go on with the women-servants, from the cook in all her glory\r\nto the small female child who weeds the garden. Lady Lundie had\r\ncross-examined her way downward as far as the page, when Sir Patrick\r\njoined her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear lady! pardon me for reminding you again, that this is a\r\nfree country, and that you have no claim whatever to investigate Miss\r\nSilvester\xe2\x80\x99s proceedings after she has left your house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie raised her eyes, devotionally, to the ceiling. She looked\r\nlike a martyr to duty. If you had seen her ladyship at that moment, you\r\nwould have said yourself, \xe2\x80\x9cA martyr to duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Sir Patrick! As a Christian woman, that is not _my_ way of looking\r\nat it. This unhappy person has lived under my roof. This unhappy person\r\nhas been the companion of Blanche. I am responsible--I am, in a manner,\r\nmorally responsible. I would give the world to be able to dismiss it\r\nas you do. But no! I must be satisfied that she _is_ married. In the\r\ninterests of propriety. For the quieting of my own conscience. Before I\r\nlay my head on my pillow to-night, Sir Patrick--before I lay my head on\r\nmy pillow to-night!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne word, Lady Lundie--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated her ladyship, with the most pathetic gentleness. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nare right, I dare say, from the worldly point of view. I can\xe2\x80\x99t take the\r\nworldly point of view. The worldly point of view hurts me.\xe2\x80\x9d She turned,\r\nwith impressive gravity, to the page. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know where you will go,\r\nJonathan, if you tell lies!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJonathan was lazy, Jonathan was pimply, Jonathan was fat--_but_ Jonathan\r\nwas orthodox. He answered that he did know; and, what is more, he\r\nmentioned the place.\r\n\r\nSir Patrick saw that further opposition on his part, at that moment,\r\nwould be worse than useless. He wisely determined to wait, before he\r\ninterfered again, until Lady Lundie had thoroughly exhausted herself and\r\nher inquiries. At the same time--as it was impossible, in the present\r\nstate of her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s temper, to provide against what might happen\r\nif the inquiries after Anne unluckily proved successful--he decided on\r\ntaking measures to clear the house of the guests (in the interests of\r\nall parties) for the next four-and-twenty hours.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only want to ask you a question, Lady Lundie,\xe2\x80\x9d he resumed. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nposition of the gentlemen who are staying here is not a very pleasant\r\none while all this is going on. If you had been content to let the\r\nmatter pass without notice, we should have done very well. As things\r\nare, don\xe2\x80\x99t you think it will be more convenient to every body if I\r\nrelieve you of the responsibility of entertaining your guests?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs head of the family?\xe2\x80\x9d stipulated Lady Lundie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs head of the family!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Sir Patrick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI gratefully accept the proposal,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Lundie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg you won\xe2\x80\x99t mention it,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Sir Patrick.\r\n\r\nHe quitted the room, leaving Jonathan under examination. He and his\r\nbrother (the late Sir Thomas) had chosen widely different paths in life,\r\nand had seen but little of each other since the time when they had been\r\nboys. Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s recollections (on leaving Lady Lundie) appeared\r\nto have taken him back to that time, and to have inspired him with a\r\ncertain tenderness for his brother\xe2\x80\x99s memory. He shook his head, and\r\nsighed a sad little sigh. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor Tom!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, softly, after\r\nhe had shut the door on his brother\xe2\x80\x99s widow. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor Tom!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn crossing the hall, he stopped the first servant he met, to inquire\r\nafter Blanche. Miss Blanche was quiet, up stairs, closeted with her maid\r\nin her own room. \xe2\x80\x9cQuiet?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a bad sign. I\r\nshall hear more of my niece.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPending that event, the next thing to do was to find the guests.\r\nUnerring instinct led Sir Patrick to the billiard-room. There he found\r\nthem, in solemn conclave assembled, wondering what they had better do.\r\nSir Patrick put them all at their ease in two minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you say to a day\xe2\x80\x99s shooting to-morrow?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nEvery man present--sportsman or not--said yes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can start from this house,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Sir Patrick; \xe2\x80\x9cor you can start\r\nfrom a shooting-cottage which is on the Windygates property--among the\r\nwoods, on the other side of the moor. The weather looks pretty well\r\nsettled (for Scotland), and there are plenty of horses in the stables.\r\nIt is useless to conceal from you, gentlemen, that events have taken a\r\ncertain unexpected turn in my sister-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s family circle. You will\r\nbe equally Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s guests, whether you choose the cottage or the\r\nhouse. For the next twenty-four hours (let us say)--which shall it be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEvery body--with or without rheumatism--answered \xe2\x80\x9cthe cottage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Sir Patrick, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is arranged to ride over to the\r\nshooting-cottage this evening, and to try the moor, on that side, the\r\nfirst thing in the morning. If events here will allow me, I shall be\r\ndelighted to accompany you, and do the honors as well as I can. If not,\r\nI am sure you will accept my apologies for to-night, and permit Lady\r\nLundie\xe2\x80\x99s steward to see to your comfort in my place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAdopted unanimously. Sir Patrick left the guests to their billiards, and\r\nwent out to give the necessary orders at the stables.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIn the mean time Blanche remained portentously quiet in the upper\r\nregions of the house; while Lady Lundie steadily pursued her inquiries\r\ndown stairs. She got on from Jonathan (last of the males, indoors) to\r\nthe coachman (first of the males, out-of-doors), and dug down, man by\r\nman, through that new stratum, until she struck the stable-boy at the\r\nbottom. Not an atom of information having been extracted in the house\r\nor out of the house, from man or boy, her ladyship fell back on\r\nthe women next. She pulled the bell, and summoned the cook--Hester\r\nDethridge.\r\n\r\nA very remarkable-looking person entered the room.\r\n\r\nElderly and quiet; scrupulously clean; eminently respectable; her gray\r\nhair neat and smooth under her modest white cap; her eyes, set deep in\r\ntheir orbits, looking straight at any person who spoke to her--here,\r\nat a first view, was a steady, trust-worthy woman. Here also on closer\r\ninspection, was a woman with the seal of some terrible past suffering\r\nset on her for the rest of her life. You felt it, rather than saw it, in\r\nthe look of immovable endurance which underlain her expression--in the\r\ndeathlike tranquillity which never disappeared from her manner. Her\r\nstory was a sad one--so far as it was known. She had entered Lady\r\nLundie\xe2\x80\x99s service at the period of Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s marriage to Sir Thomas.\r\nHer character (given by the clergyman of her parish) described her as\r\nhaving been married to an inveterate drunkard, and as having suffered\r\nunutterably during her husband\xe2\x80\x99s lifetime. There were drawbacks to\r\nengaging her, now that she was a widow. On one of the many occasions on\r\nwhich her husband had personally ill-treated her, he had struck her a\r\nblow which had produced very remarkable nervous results. She had lain\r\ninsensible many days together, and had recovered with the total loss of\r\nher speech. In addition to this objection, she was odd, at times, in her\r\nmanner; and she made it a condition of accepting any situation, that she\r\nshould be privileged to sleep in a room by herself As a set-off against\r\nall this, it was to be said, on the other side of the question, that she\r\nwas sober; rigidly honest in all her dealings; and one of the best cooks\r\nin England. In consideration of this last merit, the late Sir Thomas\r\nhad decided on giving her a trial, and had discovered that he had never\r\ndined in his life as he dined when Hester Dethridge was at the head of\r\nhis kitchen. She remained after his death in his widow\xe2\x80\x99s service. Lady\r\nLundie was far from liking her. An unpleasant suspicion attached to the\r\ncook, which Sir Thomas had over-looked, but which persons less sensible\r\nof the immense importance of dining well could not fail to regard as\r\na serious objection to her. Medical men, consulted about her case\r\ndiscovered certain physiological anomalies in it which led them to\r\nsuspect the woman of feigning dumbness, for some reason best known\r\nto herself. She obstinately declined to learn the deaf and dumb\r\nalphabet--on the ground that dumbness was not associated with deafness\r\nin her case. Stratagems were invented (seeing that she really did\r\npossess the use of her ears) to entrap her into also using her speech,\r\nand failed. Efforts were made to induce her to answer questions relating\r\nto her past life in her husband\xe2\x80\x99s time. She flatly declined to reply\r\nto them, one and all. At certain intervals, strange impulses to get a\r\nholiday away from the house appeared to seize her. If she was resisted,\r\nshe passively declined to do her work. If she was threatened with\r\ndismissal, she impenetrably bowed her head, as much as to say, \xe2\x80\x9cGive\r\nme the word, and I go.\xe2\x80\x9d Over and over again, Lady Lundie had decided,\r\nnaturally enough, on no longer keeping such a servant as this; but she\r\nhad never yet carried the decision to execution. A cook who is a perfect\r\nmistress of her art, who asks for no perquisites, who allows no waste,\r\nwho never quarrels with the other servants, who drinks nothing stronger\r\nthan tea, who is to be trusted with untold gold--is not a cook easily\r\nreplaced. In this mortal life we put up with many persons and things,\r\nas Lady Lundie put up with her cook. The woman lived, as it were, on the\r\nbrink of dismissal--but thus far the woman kept her place--getting her\r\nholidays when she asked for them (which, to do her justice, was not\r\noften) and sleeping always (go where she might with the family) with a\r\nlocked door, in a room by herself.\r\n\r\nHester Dethridge advanced slowly to the table at which Lady Lundie was\r\nsitting. A slate and pencil hung at her side, which she used for making\r\nsuch replies as were not to be expressed by a gesture or by a motion\r\nof the head. She took up the slate and pencil, and waited with stony\r\nsubmission for her mistress to begin.\r\n\r\nLady Lundie opened the proceedings with the regular formula of inquiry\r\nwhich she had used with all the other servants,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know that Miss Silvester has left the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cook nodded her head affirmatively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know at what time she left it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnother affirmative reply. The first which Lady Lundie had received to\r\nthat question yet. She eagerly went on to the next inquiry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you seen her since she left the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA third affirmative reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHester Dethridge wrote slowly on the slate, in singularly firm upright\r\ncharacters for a woman in her position of life, these words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the road that leads to the railway. Nigh to Mistress Chew\xe2\x80\x99s Farm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you want at Chew\xe2\x80\x99s Farm?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHester Dethridge wrote: \xe2\x80\x9cI wanted eggs for the kitchen, and a breath of\r\nfresh air for myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid Miss Silvester see you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA negative shake of the head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she take the turning that leads to the railway?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnother negative shake of the head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe went on, toward the moor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn affirmative reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did she do when she got to the moor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHester Dethridge wrote: \xe2\x80\x9cShe took the footpath which leads to Craig\r\nFernie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie rose excitedly to her feet. There was but one place that a\r\nstranger could go to at Craig Fernie. \xe2\x80\x9cThe inn!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed her ladyship.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has gone to the inn!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHester Dethridge waited immovably. Lady Lundie put a last precautionary\r\nquestion, in these words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you reported what you have seen to any body else?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn affirmative reply. Lady Lundie had not bargained for that. Hester\r\nDethridge (she thought) must surely have misunderstood her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean that you have told somebody else what you have just told\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnother affirmative reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA person who questioned you, as I have done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA third affirmative reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHester Dethridge wrote on her slate: \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Blanche.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie stepped back, staggered by the discovery that Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nresolution to trace Anne Silvester was, to all appearance, as firmly\r\nsettled as her own. Her step-daughter was keeping her own counsel, and\r\nacting on her own responsibility--her step-daughter might be an awkward\r\nobstacle in the way. The manner in which Anne had left the house had\r\nmortally offended Lady Lundie. An inveterately vindictive woman, she had\r\nresolved to discover whatever compromising elements might exist in the\r\ngoverness\xe2\x80\x99s secret, and to make them public property (from a paramount\r\nsense of duty, of course) among her own circle of friends. But to do\r\nthis--with Blanche acting (as might certainly be anticipated) in direct\r\nopposition to her, and openly espousing Miss Silvester\xe2\x80\x99s interests--was\r\nmanifestly impossible.\r\n\r\nThe first thing to be done--and that instantly--was to inform Blanche\r\nthat she was discovered, and to forbid her to stir in the matter.\r\n\r\nLady Lundie rang the bell twice--thus intimating, according to the laws\r\nof the household, that she required the attendance of her own maid.\r\nShe then turned to the cook--still waiting her pleasure, with stony\r\ncomposure, slate in hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have done wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d said her ladyship, severely. \xe2\x80\x9cI am your mistress.\r\nYou are bound to answer your mistress--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHester Dethridge bowed her head, in icy acknowledgment of the principle\r\nlaid down--so far.\r\n\r\nThe bow was an interruption. Lady Lundie resented it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Miss Blanche is _not_ your mistress,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, sternly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nare very much to blame for answering Miss Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s inquiries about Miss\r\nSilvester.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHester Dethridge, perfectly unmoved, wrote her justification on her\r\nslate, in two stiff sentences: \xe2\x80\x9cI had no orders _not_ to answer. I keep\r\nnobody\xe2\x80\x99s secrets but my own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat reply settled the question of the cook\xe2\x80\x99s dismissal--the question\r\nwhich had been pending for months past.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are an insolent woman! I have borne with you long enough--I will\r\nbear with you no longer. When your month is up, you go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn those words Lady Lundie dismissed Hester Dethridge from her service.\r\n\r\nNot the slightest change passed over the sinister tranquillity of\r\nthe cook. She bowed her head again, in acknowledgment of the sentence\r\npronounced on her--dropped her slate at her side--turned about--and left\r\nthe room. The woman was alive in the world, and working in the world;\r\nand yet (so far as all human interests were concerned) she was as\r\ncompletely out of the world as if she had been screwed down in her\r\ncoffin, and laid in her grave.\r\n\r\nLady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s maid came into the room as Hester left it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo up stairs to Miss Blanche,\xe2\x80\x9d said her mistress, \xe2\x80\x9cand say I want her\r\nhere. Wait a minute!\xe2\x80\x9d She paused, and considered. Blanche might decline\r\nto submit to her step-mother\xe2\x80\x99s interference with her. It might be\r\nnecessary to appeal to the higher authority of her guardian. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you\r\nknow where Sir Patrick is?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Lady Lundie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI heard Simpson say, my lady, that Sir Patrick was at the stables.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSend Simpson with a message. My compliments to Sir Patrick--and I wish\r\nto see him immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n* * * * *\r\n\r\nThe preparations for the departure to the shooting-cottage were just\r\ncompleted; and the one question that remained to be settled was, whether\r\nSir Patrick could accompany the party--when the man-servant appeared\r\nwith the message from his mistress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you give me a quarter of an hour, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Sir Patrick.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that time I shall know for certain whether I can go with you or\r\nnot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs a matter of course, the guests decided to wait. The younger men\r\namong them (being Englishmen) naturally occupied their leisure time in\r\nbetting. Would Sir Patrick get the better of the domestic crisis? or\r\nwould the domestic crisis get the better of Sir Patrick? The domestic\r\ncrisis was backed, at two to one, to win.\r\n\r\nPunctually at the expiration of the quarter of an hour, Sir Patrick\r\nreappeared. The domestic crisis had betrayed the blind confidence which\r\nyouth and inexperience had placed in it. Sir Patrick had won the day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThings are settled and quiet, gentlemen; and I am able to accompany\r\nyou,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are two ways to the shooting-cottage. One--the\r\nlongest--passes by the inn at Craig Fernie. I am compelled to ask you\r\nto go with me by that way. While you push on to the cottage, I must drop\r\nbehind, and say a word to a person who is staying at the inn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had quieted Lady Lundie--he had even quieted Blanche. But it was\r\nevidently on the condition that he was to go to Craig Fernie in their\r\nplaces, and to see Anne Silvester himself. Without a word more\r\nof explanation he mounted his horse, and led the way out. The\r\nshooting-party left Windygates.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSECOND SCENE.--THE INN.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE NINTH.\r\n\r\nANNE.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYE\xe2\x80\x99LL just permit me to remind ye again, young leddy, that the hottle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfull--exceptin\xe2\x80\x99 only this settin\xe2\x80\x99-room, and the bedchamber yonder\r\nbelonging to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo spoke \xe2\x80\x9cMistress Inchbare,\xe2\x80\x9d landlady of the Craig Fernie Inn, to Anne\r\nSilvester, standing in the parlor, purse in hand, and offering the price\r\nof the two rooms before she claimed permission to occupy them.\r\n\r\nThe time of the afternoon was about the time when Geoffrey Delamayn had\r\nstarted in the train, on his journey to London. About the time also,\r\nwhen Arnold Brinkworth had crossed the moor, and was mounting the first\r\nrising ground which led to the inn.\r\n\r\nMistress Inchbare was tall and thin, and decent and dry. Mistress\r\nInchbare\xe2\x80\x99s unlovable hair clung fast round her head in wiry little\r\nyellow curls. Mistress Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s hard bones showed themselves, like\r\nMistress Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s hard Presbyterianism, without any concealment or\r\ncompromise. In short, a savagely-respectable woman who plumed herself on\r\npresiding over a savagely-respectable inn.\r\n\r\nThere was no competition to interfere with Mistress Inchbare. She\r\nregulated her own prices, and made her own rules. If you objected to\r\nher prices, and revolted from her rules, you were free to go. In other\r\nwords, you were free to cast yourself, in the capacity of houseless\r\nwanderer, on the scanty mercy of a Scotch wilderness. The village of\r\nCraig Fernie was a collection of hovels. The country about Craig Fernie,\r\nmountain on one side and moor on the other, held no second house of\r\npublic entertainment, for miles and miles round, at any point of the\r\ncompass. No rambling individual but the helpless British Tourist wanted\r\nfood and shelter from strangers in that part of Scotland; and nobody\r\nbut Mistress Inchbare had food and shelter to sell. A more thoroughly\r\nindependent person than this was not to be found on the face of the\r\nhotel-keeping earth. The most universal of all civilized terrors--the\r\nterror of appearing unfavorably in the newspapers--was a sensation\r\nabsolutely unknown to the Empress of the Inn. You lost your temper,\r\nand threatened to send her bill for exhibition in the public journals.\r\nMistress Inchbare raised no objection to your taking any course you\r\npleased with it. \xe2\x80\x9cEh, man! send the bill whar\xe2\x80\x99 ye like, as long as ye\r\npay it first. There\xe2\x80\x99s nae such thing as a newspaper ever darkens my\r\ndoors. Ye\xe2\x80\x99ve got the Auld and New Testaments in your bedchambers, and\r\nthe natural history o\xe2\x80\x99 Pairthshire on the coffee-room table--and if\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s no\xe2\x80\x99 reading eneugh for ye, ye may een gae back South again, and\r\nget the rest of it there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was the inn at which Anne Silvester had appeared alone, with\r\nnothing but a little bag in her hand. This was the woman whose\r\nreluctance to receive her she innocently expected to overcome by showing\r\nher purse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMention your charge for the rooms,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI am willing to pay for\r\nthem beforehand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer majesty, Mrs. Inchbare, never even looked at her subject\xe2\x80\x99s poor\r\nlittle purse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt just comes to this, mistress,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m no\xe2\x80\x99 free to tak\xe2\x80\x99\r\nyour money, if I\xe2\x80\x99m no\xe2\x80\x99 free to let ye the last rooms left in the hoose.\r\nThe Craig Fernie hottle is a faimily hottle--and has its ain gude name\r\nto keep up. Ye\xe2\x80\x99re ower-well-looking, my young leddy, to be traveling\r\nalone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe time had been when Anne would have answered sharply enough. The hard\r\nnecessities of her position made her patient now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have already told you,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cmy husband is coming here to\r\njoin me.\xe2\x80\x9d She sighed wearily as she repeated her ready-made story--and\r\ndropped into the nearest chair, from sheer inability to stand any\r\nlonger.\r\n\r\nMistress Inchbare looked at her, with the exact measure of compassionate\r\ninterest which she might have shown if she had been looking at a stray\r\ndog who had fallen footsore at the door of the inn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWeel! weel! sae let it be. Bide awhile, and rest ye. We\xe2\x80\x99ll no\xe2\x80\x99 chairge\r\nye for that--and we\xe2\x80\x99ll see if your husband comes. I\xe2\x80\x99ll just let the\r\nrooms, mistress, to _him,_, instead o\xe2\x80\x99 lettin\xe2\x80\x99 them to _you._ And, sae,\r\ngood-morrow t\xe2\x80\x99 ye.\xe2\x80\x9d With that final announcement of her royal will and\r\npleasure, the Empress of the Inn withdrew.\r\n\r\nAnne made no reply. She watched the landlady out of the room--and then\r\nstruggled to control herself no longer. In her position, suspicion was\r\ndoubly insult. The hot tears of shame gathered in her eyes; and the\r\nheart-ache wrung her, poor soul--wrung her without mercy.\r\n\r\nA trifling noise in the room startled her. She looked up, and detected\r\na man in a corner, dusting the furniture, and apparently acting in the\r\ncapacity of attendant at the inn. He had shown her into the parlor on\r\nher arrival; but he had remained so quietly in the room that she had\r\nnever noticed him since, until that moment.\r\n\r\nHe was an ancient man--with one eye filmy and blind, and one eye moist\r\nand merry. His head was bald; his feet were gouty; his nose was justly\r\ncelebrated as the largest nose and the reddest nose in that part of\r\nScotland. The mild wisdom of years was expressed mysteriously in his\r\nmellow smile. In contact with this wicked world, his manner revealed\r\nthat happy mixture of two extremes--the servility which just\r\ntouches independence, and the independence which just touches\r\nservility--attained by no men in existence but Scotchmen. Enormous\r\nnative impudence, which amused but never offended; immeasurable cunning,\r\nmasquerading habitually under the double disguise of quaint prejudice\r\nand dry humor, were the solid moral foundations on which the character\r\nof this elderly person was built. No amount of whisky ever made him\r\ndrunk; and no violence of bell-ringing ever hurried his movements. Such\r\nwas the headwaiter at the Craig Fernie Inn; known, far and wide, to\r\nlocal fame, as \xe2\x80\x9cMaister Bishopriggs, Mistress Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s right-hand\r\nman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing there?\xe2\x80\x9d Anne asked, sharply.\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs turned himself about on his gouty feet; waved his duster\r\ngently in the air; and looked at Anne, with a mild, paternal smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh! Am just doostin\xe2\x80\x99 the things; and setin\xe2\x80\x99 the room in decent order\r\nfor ye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor _me?_ Did you hear what the landlady said?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs advanced confidentially, and pointed with a very\r\nunsteady forefinger to the purse which Anne still held in her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever fash yoursel\xe2\x80\x99 aboot the landleddy!\xe2\x80\x9d said the sage chief of the\r\nCraig Fernie waiters. \xe2\x80\x9cYour purse speaks for you, my lassie. Pet it up!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n cried Mr. Bishopriggs, waving temptation away from him with the duster.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn wi\xe2\x80\x99 it into yer pocket! Sae long as the warld\xe2\x80\x99s the warld, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nuphaud it any where--while there\xe2\x80\x99s siller in the purse, there\xe2\x80\x99s gude in\r\nthe woman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s patience, which had resisted harder trials, gave way at this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean by speaking to me in that familiar manner?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked,\r\nrising angrily to her feet again.\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs tucked his duster under his arm, and proceeded to\r\nsatisfy Anne that he shared the landlady\xe2\x80\x99s view of her position, without\r\nsharing the severity of the landlady\xe2\x80\x99s principles. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s nae man\r\nlivin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bishopriggs, \xe2\x80\x9clooks with mair indulgence at human\r\nfrailty than my ain sel\xe2\x80\x99. Am I no\xe2\x80\x99 to be familiar wi\xe2\x80\x99 ye--when I\xe2\x80\x99m auld\r\neneugh to be a fether to ye, and ready to be a fether to ye till further\r\nnotice? Hech! hech! Order your bit dinner lassie. Husband or no husband,\r\nye\xe2\x80\x99ve got a stomach, and ye must een eat. There\xe2\x80\x99s fesh and there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfowl--or, maybe, ye\xe2\x80\x99ll be for the sheep\xe2\x80\x99s head singit, when they\xe2\x80\x99ve done\r\nwith it at the tabble dot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was but one way of getting rid of him: \xe2\x80\x9cOrder what you like,\xe2\x80\x9d Anne\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cand leave the room.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Bishopriggs highly approved of the first\r\nhalf of the sentence, and totally overlooked the second.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay--just pet a\xe2\x80\x99 yer little interests in my hands; it\xe2\x80\x99s the wisest\r\nthing ye can do. Ask for Maister Bishopriggs (that\xe2\x80\x99s me) when ye want a\r\ndecent \xe2\x80\x98sponsible man to gi\xe2\x80\x99 ye a word of advice. Set ye doon again--set\r\nye doon. And don\xe2\x80\x99t tak\xe2\x80\x99 the arm-chair. Hech! hech! yer husband will\r\nbe coming, ye know, and he\xe2\x80\x99s sure to want it!\xe2\x80\x9d With that seasonable\r\npleasantry the venerable Bishopriggs winked, and went out.\r\n\r\nAnne looked at her watch. By her calculation it was not far from the\r\nhour when Geoffrey might be expected to arrive at the inn, assuming\r\nGeoffrey to have left Windygates at the time agreed on. A little more\r\npatience, and the landlady\xe2\x80\x99s scruples would be satisfied, and the ordeal\r\nwould be at an end.\r\n\r\nCould she have met him nowhere else than at this barbarous house, and\r\namong these barbarous people?\r\n\r\nNo. Outside the doors of Windygates she had not a friend to help her in\r\nall Scotland. There was no place at her disposal but the inn; and she\r\nhad only to be thankful that it occupied a sequestered situation, and\r\nwas not likely to be visited by any of Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s friends. Whatever\r\nthe risk might be, the end in view justified her in confronting it. Her\r\nwhole future depended on Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s making an honest woman of her. Not\r\nher future with _him_--that way there was no hope; that way her life was\r\nwasted. Her future with Blanche--she looked forward to nothing now but\r\nher future with Blanche.\r\n\r\nHer spirits sank lower and lower. The tears rose again. It would only\r\nirritate him if he came and found her crying. She tried to divert her\r\nmind by looking about the room.\r\n\r\nThere was very little to see. Except that it was solidly built of good\r\nsound stone, the Craig Fernie hotel differed in no other important\r\nrespect from the average of second-rate English inns. There was the\r\nusual slippery black sofa--constructed to let you slide when you wanted\r\nto rest. There was the usual highly-varnished arm-chair, expressly\r\nmanufactured to test the endurance of the human spine. There was the\r\nusual paper on the walls, of the pattern designed to make your eyes ache\r\nand your head giddy. There were the usual engravings, which humanity\r\nnever tires of contemplating. The Royal Portrait, in the first place of\r\nhonor. The next greatest of all human beings--the Duke of Wellington--in\r\nthe second place of honor. The third greatest of all human beings--the\r\nlocal member of parliament--in the third place of honor; and a hunting\r\nscene, in the dark. A door opposite the door of admission from the\r\npassage opened into the bedroom; and a window at the side looked out on\r\nthe open space in front of the hotel, and commanded a view of the vast\r\nexpanse of the Craig Fernie moor, stretching away below the rising\r\nground on which the house was built.\r\n\r\nAnne turned in despair from the view in the room to the view from the\r\nwindow. Within the last half hour it had changed for the worse. The\r\nclouds had gathered; the sun was hidden; the light on the landscape was\r\ngray and dull. Anne turned from the window, as she had turned from the\r\nroom. She was just making the hopeless attempt to rest her weary limbs\r\non the sofa, when the sound of voices and footsteps in the passage\r\ncaught her ear.\r\n\r\nWas Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s voice among them? No.\r\n\r\nWere the strangers coming in?\r\n\r\nThe landlady had declined to let her have the rooms: it was quite\r\npossible that the strangers might be coming to look at them. There was\r\nno knowing who they might be. In the impulse of the moment she flew to\r\nthe bedchamber and locked herself in.\r\n\r\nThe door from the passage opened, and Arnold Brinkworth--shown in by Mr.\r\nBishopriggs--entered the sitting-room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNobody here!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Arnold, looking round. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs pointed to the bedroom door. \xe2\x80\x9cEh! yer good leddy\xe2\x80\x99s joost\r\nin the bedchamber, nae doot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold started. He had felt no difficulty (when he and Geoffrey had\r\ndiscussed the question at Windygates) about presenting himself at\r\nthe inn in the assumed character of Anne\xe2\x80\x99s husband. But the result of\r\nputting the deception in practice was, to say the least of it, a little\r\nembarrassing at first. Here was the waiter describing Miss Silvester\r\nas his \xe2\x80\x9cgood lady;\xe2\x80\x9d and leaving it (most naturally and properly) to the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgood lady\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d husband to knock at her bedroom door, and tell her that he\r\nwas there.
