In despair of knowing what else to do at the moment, Arnold\r\nasked for the landlady, whom he had not seen on arriving at the inn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe landleddy\xe2\x80\x99s just tottin\xe2\x80\x99 up the ledgers o\xe2\x80\x99 the hottle in her ain\r\nroom,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mr. Bishopriggs. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99ll be here anon--the wearyful\r\nwoman!--speerin\xe2\x80\x99 who ye are and what ye are, and takin\xe2\x80\x99 a\xe2\x80\x99 the business\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 the hoose on her ain pair o\xe2\x80\x99 shouthers.\xe2\x80\x9d He dropped the subject of\r\nthe landlady, and put in a plea for himself. \xe2\x80\x9cI ha\xe2\x80\x99 lookit after a\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\nleddy\xe2\x80\x99s little comforts, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered. \xe2\x80\x9cTrust in me! trust in me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s attention was absorbed in the very serious difficulty of\r\nannouncing his arrival to Anne. \xe2\x80\x9cHow am I to get her out?\xe2\x80\x9d he said to\r\nhimself, with a look of perplexity directed at the bedroom door.\r\n\r\nHe had spoken loud enough for the waiter to hear him. Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s look of\r\nperplexity was instantly reflected on the face of Mr. Bishopriggs.\r\nThe head-waiter at Craig Fernie possessed an immense experience of the\r\nmanners and customs of newly-married people on their honeymoon trip.\r\nHe had been a second father (with excellent pecuniary results) to\r\ninnumerable brides and bridegrooms. He knew young married couples in\r\nall their varieties:--The couples who try to behave as if they had been\r\nmarried for many years; the couples who attempt no concealment, and\r\ntake advice from competent authorities about them. The couples who are\r\nbashfully talkative before third persons; the couples who are bashfully\r\nsilent under similar circumstances. The couples who don\xe2\x80\x99t know what\r\nto do, the couples who wish it was over; the couples who must never\r\nbe intruded upon without careful preliminary knocking at the door; the\r\ncouples who _can_ eat and drink in the intervals of \xe2\x80\x9cbliss,\xe2\x80\x9d and the\r\nother couples who _can\xe2\x80\x99t._ But the bridegroom who stood helpless on\r\none side of the door, and the bride who remained locked in on the other,\r\nwere new varieties of the nuptial species, even in the vast experience\r\nof Mr. Bishopriggs himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoo are ye to get her oot?\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll show ye hoo!\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nadvanced as rapidly as his gouty feet would let him, and knocked at\r\nthe bedroom door. \xe2\x80\x9cEh, my leddy! here he is in flesh and bluid.\r\nMercy preserve us! do ye lock the door of the nuptial chamber in your\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s face?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt that unanswerable appeal the lock was heard turning in the door. Mr.\r\nBishopriggs winked at Arnold with his one available eye, and laid his\r\nforefinger knowingly along his enormous nose. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m away before she\r\nfalls into your arms! Rely on it I\xe2\x80\x99ll no come in again without knocking\r\nfirst!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe left Arnold alone in the room. The bedroom door opened slowly by a\r\nfew inches at a time. Anne\xe2\x80\x99s voice was just audible speaking cautiously\r\nbehind it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that you, Geoffrey?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s heart began to beat fast, in anticipation of the disclosure\r\nwhich was now close at hand. He knew neither what to say or do--he\r\nremained silent.\r\n\r\nAnne repeated the question in louder tones:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was the certain prospect of alarming her, if some reply was not\r\ngiven. There was no help for it. Come what come might, Arnold answered,\r\nin a whisper:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe door was flung wide open. Anne Silvester appeared on the threshold,\r\nconfronting him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Brinkworth!!!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, standing petrified with astonishment.\r\n\r\nFor a moment more neither of them spoke. Anne advanced one step into\r\nthe sitting-room, and put the next inevitable question, with an\r\ninstantaneous change from surprise to suspicion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s letter represented the only possible excuse for Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nappearance in that place, and at that time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have got a letter for you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said--and offered it to her.\r\n\r\nShe was instantly on her guard. They were little better than strangers\r\nto each other, as Arnold had said. A sickening presentiment of some\r\ntreachery on Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s part struck cold to her heart. She refused to\r\ntake the letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI expect no letter,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cWho told you I was here?\xe2\x80\x9d She put\r\nthe question, not only with a tone of suspicion, but with a look of\r\ncontempt. The look was not an easy one for a man to bear. It required\r\na momentary exertion of self-control on Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s part, before he could\r\ntrust himself to answer with due consideration for her. \xe2\x80\x9cIs there a\r\nwatch set on my actions?\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, with rising anger. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd are _you_\r\nthe spy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou haven\xe2\x80\x99t known me very long, Miss Silvester,\xe2\x80\x9d Arnold answered,\r\nquietly. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you ought to know me better than to say that. I am the\r\nbearer of a letter from Geoffrey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was an the point of following his example, and of speaking of\r\nGeoffrey by his Christian name, on her side. But she checked herself,\r\nbefore the word had passed her lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean Mr. Delamayn?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, coldly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat occasion have _I_ for a letter from Mr. Delamayn?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was determined to acknowledge nothing--she kept him obstinately at\r\narm\xe2\x80\x99s-length. Arnold did, as a matter of instinct, what a man of larger\r\nexperience would have done, as a matter of calculation--he closed with\r\nher boldly, then and there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Silvester! it\xe2\x80\x99s no use beating about the bush. If you won\xe2\x80\x99t take\r\nthe letter, you force me to speak out. I am here on a very unpleasant\r\nerrand. I begin to wish, from the bottom of my heart, I had never\r\nundertaken it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA quick spasm of pain passed across her face. She was beginning, dimly\r\nbeginning, to understand him. He hesitated. His generous nature shrank\r\nfrom hurting her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with an effort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTry not to be angry with me, Miss Silvester. Geoffrey and I are old\r\nfriends. Geoffrey knows he can trust me--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrust you?\xe2\x80\x9d she interposed. \xe2\x80\x9cStop!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold waited. She went on, speaking to herself, not to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I was in the other room I asked if Geoffrey was there. And this\r\nman answered for him.\xe2\x80\x9d She sprang forward with a cry of horror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he told you--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, read his letter!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe violently pushed back the hand with which Arnold once more offered\r\nthe letter. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t look at me! He _has_ told you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead his letter,\xe2\x80\x9d persisted Arnold. \xe2\x80\x9cIn justice to him, if you won\xe2\x80\x99t in\r\njustice to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe situation was too painful to be endured. Arnold looked at her, this\r\ntime, with a man\xe2\x80\x99s resolution in his eyes--spoke to her, this time, with\r\na man\xe2\x80\x99s resolution in his voice. She took the letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with a sudden humiliation of tone\r\nand manner, inexpressibly shocking, inexpressibly pitiable to see. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nunderstand my position at last. I am a woman doubly betrayed. Please to\r\nexcuse what I said to you just now, when I supposed myself to have some\r\nclaim on your respect. Perhaps you will grant me your pity? I can ask\r\nfor nothing more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold was silent. Words were useless in the face of such utter\r\nself-abandonment as this. Any man living--even Geoffrey himself--must\r\nhave felt for her at that moment.\r\n\r\nShe looked for the first time at the letter. She opened it on the wrong\r\nside. \xe2\x80\x9cMy own letter!\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cIn the hands of another\r\nman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at the last page,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold.\r\n\r\nShe turned to the last page, and read the hurried penciled lines.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVillain! villain! villain!\xe2\x80\x9d At the third repetition of the word, she\r\ncrushed the letter in the palm of her hand, and flung it from her to the\r\nother end of the room. The instant after, the fire that had flamed up in\r\nher died out. Feebly and slowly she reached out her hand to the nearest\r\nchair, and sat down in it with her back to Arnold. \xe2\x80\x9cHe has deserted me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n was all she said. The words fell low and quiet on the silence: they were\r\nthe utterance of an immeasurable despair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are wrong!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Arnold. \xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, indeed you are wrong! It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nno excuse--it\xe2\x80\x99s the truth. I was present when the message came about his\r\nfather.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe never heeded him, and never moved. She only repeated the words\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has deserted me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t take it in that way!\xe2\x80\x9d pleaded Arnold--\xe2\x80\x9cpray don\xe2\x80\x99t! It\xe2\x80\x99s dreadful\r\nto hear you; it is indeed. I am sure he has _not_ deserted you.\xe2\x80\x9d There\r\nwas no answer; no sign that she heard him; she sat there, struck to\r\nstone. It was impossible to call the landlady in at such a moment as\r\nthis. In despair of knowing how else to rouse her, Arnold drew a chair\r\nto her side, and patted her timidly on the shoulder. \xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in\r\nhis single-hearted, boyish way. \xe2\x80\x9cCheer up a little!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe slowly turned her head, and looked at him with a dull surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t you say he had told you every thing?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you despise a woman like me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s heart went back, at that dreadful question, to the one woman\r\nwho was eternally sacred to him--to the woman from whose bosom he had\r\ndrawn the breath of life.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes the man live,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwho can think of his mother--and despise\r\nwomen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat answer set the prisoned misery in her free. She gave him her\r\nhand--she faintly thanked him. The merciful tears came to her at last.\r\n\r\nArnold rose, and turned away to the window in despair. \xe2\x80\x9cI mean well,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet I only distress her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe heard him, and straggled to compose herself \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\ncomfort me. Don\xe2\x80\x99t mind my crying--I\xe2\x80\x99m the better for it.\xe2\x80\x9d She looked\r\nround at him gratefully. \xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t distress you, Mr. Brinkworth. I ought\r\nto thank you--and I do. Come back or I shall think you are angry with\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d Arnold went back to her. She gave him her hand once more. \xe2\x80\x9cOne\r\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t understand people all at once,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, simply. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought you\r\nwere like other men--I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know till to-day how kind you could be.\r\nDid you walk here?\xe2\x80\x9d she added, suddenly, with an effort to change\r\nthe subject. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you tired? I have not been kindly received at this\r\nplace--but I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I may offer you whatever the inn affords.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was impossible not to feel for her--it was impossible not to be\r\ninterested in her. Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s honest longing to help her expressed itself\r\na little too openly when he spoke next. \xe2\x80\x9cAll I want, Miss Silvester, is\r\nto be of some service to you, if I can,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIs there any thing\r\nI can do to make your position here more comfortable? You will stay at\r\nthis place, won\xe2\x80\x99t you? Geoffrey wishes it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe shuddered, and looked away. \xe2\x80\x9cYes! yes!\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, hurriedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will hear from Geoffrey,\xe2\x80\x9d Arnold went on, \xe2\x80\x9cto-morrow or next day. I\r\nknow he means to write.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake, don\xe2\x80\x99t speak of him any more!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried out. \xe2\x80\x9cHow do\r\nyou think I can look you in the face--\xe2\x80\x9d Her cheeks flushed deep, and her\r\neyes rested on him with a momentary firmness. \xe2\x80\x9cMind this! I am his wife,\r\nif promises can make me his wife! He has pledged his word to me by all\r\nthat is sacred!\xe2\x80\x9d She checked herself impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I saying?\r\nWhat interest can _you_ have in this miserable state of things? Don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlet us talk of it! I have something else to say to you. Let us go back\r\nto my troubles here. Did you see the landlady when you came in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. I only saw the waiter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe landlady has made some absurd difficulty about letting me have\r\nthese rooms because I came here alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe won\xe2\x80\x99t make any difficulty now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold. \xe2\x80\x9cI have settled that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_You!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold smiled. After what had passed, it was an indescribable relief to\r\nhim to see the humorous side of his own position at the inn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I asked for the lady who had arrived\r\nhere alone this afternoon--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was told, in your interests, to ask for her as my wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne looked at him--in alarm as well as in surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou asked for me as your wife?\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. I haven\xe2\x80\x99t done wrong--have I? As I understood it, there was\r\nno alternative. Geoffrey told me you had settled with him to present\r\nyourself here as a married lady, whose husband was coming to join her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought of _him_ when I said that. Geoffrey said your\r\nposition here depended on my asking for you at the door (as _he_ would\r\nhave asked for you if he had come) in the character of your husband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe had no right to say that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo right? After what you have told me of the landlady, just think\r\nwhat might have happened if he had _not_ said it! I haven\xe2\x80\x99t had much\r\nexperience myself of these things. But--allow me to ask--wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it\r\nhave been a little awkward (at my age) if I had come here and inquired\r\nfor you as a friend? Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think, in that case, the landlady might\r\nhave made some additional difficulty about letting you have the rooms?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was beyond dispute that the landlady would have refused to let the\r\nrooms at all. It was equally plain that the deception which Arnold\r\nhad practiced on the people of the inn was a deception which Anne had\r\nherself rendered necessary, in her own interests. She was not to blame;\r\nit was clearly impossible for her to have foreseen such an event as\r\nGeoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s departure for London. Still, she felt an uneasy sense\r\nof responsibility--a vague dread of what might happen next. She sat\r\nnervously twisting her handkerchief in her lap, and made no answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t suppose I object to this little stratagem,\xe2\x80\x9d Arnold went on. \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nserving my old friend, and I am helping the lady who is soon to be his\r\nwife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne rose abruptly to her feet, and amazed him by a very unexpected\r\nquestion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Brinkworth,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cforgive me the rudeness of something I am\r\nabout to say to you. When are you going away?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold burst out laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I am quite sure I can do nothing more to assist you,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray don\xe2\x80\x99t think of _me_ any longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn your situation! who else am I to think of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne laid her hand earnestly on his arm, and answered:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlanche!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlanche?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Arnold, utterly at a loss to understand her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes--Blanche. She found time to tell me what had passed between you\r\nthis morning before I left Windygates. I know you have made her an\r\noffer: I know you are engaged to be married to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold was delighted to hear it. He had been merely unwilling to leave\r\nher thus far. He was absolutely determined to stay with her now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t expect me to go after that!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cCome and sit down again,\r\nand let\xe2\x80\x99s talk about Blanche.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne declined impatiently, by a gesture. Arnold was too deeply\r\ninterested in the new topic to take any notice of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know all about her habits and her tastes,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, \xe2\x80\x9cand what\r\nshe likes, and what she dislikes. It\xe2\x80\x99s most important that I should talk\r\nto you about her. When we are husband and wife, Blanche is to have\r\nall her own way in every thing. That\xe2\x80\x99s my idea of the Whole Duty of\r\nMan--when Man is married. You are still standing? Let me give you a\r\nchair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was cruel--under other circumstances it would have been\r\nimpossible--to disappoint him. But the vague fear of consequences which\r\nhad taken possession of Anne was not to be trifled with. She had no\r\nclear conception of the risk (and it is to be added, in justice to\r\nGeoffrey, that _he_ had no clear conception of the risk) on which\r\nArnold had unconsciously ventured, in undertaking his errand to the inn.\r\nNeither of them had any adequate idea (few people have) of the infamous\r\nabsence of all needful warning, of all decent precaution and restraint,\r\nwhich makes the marriage law of Scotland a trap to catch unmarried men\r\nand women, to this day. But, while Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s mind was incapable of\r\nlooking beyond the present emergency, Anne\xe2\x80\x99s finer intelligence told her\r\nthat a country which offered such facilities for private marriage as the\r\nfacilities of which she had proposed to take advantage in her own case,\r\nwas not a country in which a man could act as Arnold had acted, without\r\ndanger of some serious embarrassment following as the possible result.\r\nWith this motive to animate her, she resolutely declined to take the\r\noffered chair, or to enter into the proposed conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhatever we have to say about Blanche, Mr. Brinkworth, must be said at\r\nsome fitter time. I beg you will leave me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Leave me to the solitude that is best for me, and to the sorrow\r\nthat I have deserved. Thank you--and good-by.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold made no attempt to disguise his disappointment and surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I must go, I must,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cBut why are you in such a hurry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want you to call me your wife again before the people of this\r\ninn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs _that_ all? What on earth are you afraid of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was unable fully to realize her own apprehensions. She was doubly\r\nunable to express them in words. In her anxiety to produce some reason\r\nwhich might prevail on him to go, she drifted back into that very\r\nconversation about Blanche into which she had declined to enter but the\r\nmoment before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have reasons for being afraid,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cOne that I can\xe2\x80\x99t give; and\r\none that I can. Suppose Blanche heard of what you have done? The longer\r\nyou stay here--the more people you see--the more chance there is that\r\nshe _might_ hear of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what if she did?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Arnold, in his own straightforward way. \xe2\x80\x9cDo\r\nyou think she would be angry with me for making myself useful to _you?_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Anne, sharply, \xe2\x80\x9cif she was jealous of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s unlimited belief in Blanche expressed itself, without the\r\nslightest compromise, in two words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnxious as she was, miserable as she was, a faint smile flitted over\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Patrick would tell you, Mr. Brinkworth, that nothing is impossible\r\nwhere women are concerned.\xe2\x80\x9d She dropped her momentary lightness of tone,\r\nand went on as earnestly as ever. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t put yourself in Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nplace--I can. Once more, I beg you to go. I don\xe2\x80\x99t like your coming here,\r\nin this way! I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it at all!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe held out her hand to take leave. At the same moment there was a loud\r\nknock at the door of the room.\r\n\r\nAnne sank into the chair at her side, and uttered a faint cry of alarm.\r\nArnold, perfectly impenetrable to all sense of his position, asked what\r\nthere was to frighten her--and answered the knock in the two customary\r\nwords:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE TENTH.\r\n\r\nMR. BISHOPRIGGS.\r\n\r\nTHE knock at the door was repeated--a louder knock than before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you deaf?\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Arnold.\r\n\r\nThe door opened, little by little, an inch at a time. Mr. Bishopriggs\r\nappeared mysteriously, with the cloth for dinner over his arm, and with\r\nhis second in command behind him, bearing \xe2\x80\x9cthe furnishing of the table\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n (as it was called at Craig Fernie) on a tray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the deuce were you waiting for?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Arnold. \xe2\x80\x9cI told you to come\r\nin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd _I_ tauld _you,_\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mr. Bishopriggs, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I wadna come in\r\nwithout knocking first. Eh, man!\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, dismissing his second in\r\ncommand, and laying the cloth with his own venerable hands, \xe2\x80\x9cd\xe2\x80\x99ye think\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve lived in this hottle in blinded eegnorance of hoo young married\r\ncouples pass the time when they\xe2\x80\x99re left to themselves? Twa knocks at the\r\ndoor--and an unco trouble in opening it, after that--is joost the least\r\nye can do for them! Whar\xe2\x80\x99 do ye think, noo, I\xe2\x80\x99ll set the places for you\r\nand your leddy there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne walked away to the window, in undisguised disgust. Arnold found Mr.\r\nBishopriggs to be quite irresistible. He answered, humoring the joke,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne at the top and one at the bottom of the table, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne at tap and one at bottom?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mr. Bishopriggs, in high\r\ndisdain. \xe2\x80\x9cDe\xe2\x80\x99il a bit of it! Baith yer chairs as close together as\r\nchairs can be. Hech! hech!--haven\xe2\x80\x99t I caught \xe2\x80\x98em, after goodness knows\r\nhoo many preleeminary knocks at the door, dining on their husbands\xe2\x80\x99\r\nknees, and steemulating a man\xe2\x80\x99s appetite by feeding him at the fork\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nend like a child? Eh!\xe2\x80\x9d sighed the sage of Craig Fernie, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s a short\r\nlife wi\xe2\x80\x99 that nuptial business, and a merry one! A mouth for yer billin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nand cooin\xe2\x80\x99; and a\xe2\x80\x99 the rest o\xe2\x80\x99 yer days for wondering ye were ever such\r\na fule, and wishing it was a\xe2\x80\x99 to be done ower again.--Ye\xe2\x80\x99ll be for a\r\nbottle o\xe2\x80\x99 sherry wine, nae doot? and a drap toddy afterwards, to do yer\r\ndigestin\xe2\x80\x99 on?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold nodded--and then, in obedience to a signal from Anne, joined her\r\nat the window. Mr. Bishopriggs looked after them attentively--observed\r\nthat they were talking in whispers--and approved of that proceeding, as\r\nrepresenting another of the established customs of young married couples\r\nat inns, in the presence of third persons appointed to wait on them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy! ay!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking over his shoulder at Arnold, \xe2\x80\x9cgae to your\r\ndeerie! gae to your deerie! and leave a\xe2\x80\x99 the solid business o\xe2\x80\x99 life to\r\nMe. Ye\xe2\x80\x99ve Screepture warrant for it. A man maun leave fether and mother\r\n(I\xe2\x80\x99m yer fether), and cleave to his wife. My certie! \xe2\x80\x98cleave\xe2\x80\x99 is\r\na strong word--there\xe2\x80\x99s nae sort o\xe2\x80\x99 doot aboot it, when it comes\r\nto \xe2\x80\x98cleaving!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d He wagged his head thoughtfully, and walked to the\r\nside-table in a corner, to cut the bread.\r\n\r\nAs he took up the knife, his one wary eye detected a morsel of crumpled\r\npaper, lying lost between the table and the wall. It was the letter from\r\nGeoffrey, which Anne had flung from her, in the first indignation of\r\nreading it--and which neither she nor Arnold had thought of since.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that I see yonder?\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Mr. Bishopriggs, under his breath.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMair litter in the room, after I\xe2\x80\x99ve doosted and tidied it wi\xe2\x80\x99 my ain\r\nhands!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe picked up the crumpled paper, and partly opened it. \xe2\x80\x9cEh! what\xe2\x80\x99s here?\r\nWriting on it in ink? and writing on it in pencil? Who may this belong\r\nto?\xe2\x80\x9d He looked round cautiously toward Arnold and Anne. They were both\r\nstill talking in whispers, and both standing with their backs to him,\r\nlooking out of the window. \xe2\x80\x9cHere it is, clean forgotten and dune with!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n thought Mr. Bishopriggs. \xe2\x80\x9cNoo what would a fule do, if he fund this?\r\nA fule wad light his pipe wi\xe2\x80\x99 it, and then wonder whether he wadna ha\xe2\x80\x99\r\ndune better to read it first. And what wad a wise man do, in a seemilar\r\nposition?\xe2\x80\x9d He practically answered that question by putting the letter\r\ninto his pocket. It might be worth keeping, or it might not; five\r\nminutes\xe2\x80\x99 private examination of it would decide the alternative, at the\r\nfirst convenient opportunity. \xe2\x80\x9cAm gaun\xe2\x80\x99 to breeng the dinner in!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\ncalled out to Arnold. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd, mind ye, there\xe2\x80\x99s nae knocking at the door\r\npossible, when I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the tray in baith my hands, and mairs the pity,\r\nthe gout in baith my feet.\xe2\x80\x9d With that friendly warning, Mr. Bishopriggs\r\nwent his way to the regions of the kitchen.\r\n\r\nArnold continued his conversation with Anne in terms which showed that\r\nthe question of his leaving the inn had been the question once more\r\ndiscussed between them while they were standing at the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see we can\xe2\x80\x99t help it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe waiter has gone to bring the\r\ndinner in. What will they think in the house, if I go away already, and\r\nleave \xe2\x80\x98my wife\xe2\x80\x99 to dine alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was so plainly necessary to keep up appearances for the present,\r\nthat there was nothing more to be said. Arnold was committing a\r\nserious imprudence--and yet, on this occasion, Arnold was right. Anne\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nannoyance at feeling that conclusion forced on her produced the first\r\nbetrayal of impatience which she had shown yet. She left Arnold at the\r\nwindow, and flung herself on the sofa. \xe2\x80\x9cA curse seems to follow me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n she thought, bitterly. \xe2\x80\x9cThis will end ill--and I shall be answerable for\r\nit!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the mean time Mr. Bishopriggs had found the dinner in the kitchen,\r\nready, and waiting for him. Instead of at once taking the tray on which\r\nit was placed into the sitting-room, he conveyed it privately into his\r\nown pantry, and shut the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLie ye there, my freend, till the spare moment comes--and I\xe2\x80\x99ll look\r\nat ye again,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, putting the letter away carefully in the\r\ndresser-drawer. \xe2\x80\x9cNoo aboot the dinner o\xe2\x80\x99 they twa turtle-doves in the\r\nparlor?\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, directing his attention to the dinner tray. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nmaun joost see that the cook\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98s dune her duty--the creatures are no\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncapable o\xe2\x80\x99 decidin\xe2\x80\x99 that knotty point for their ain selves.\xe2\x80\x9d He took off\r\none of the covers, and picked bits, here and there, out of the dish with\r\nthe fork, \xe2\x80\x9cEh! eh! the collops are no\xe2\x80\x99 that bad!\xe2\x80\x9d He took off another\r\ncover, and shook his head in solemn doubt. \xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s the green meat. I\r\ndoot green meat\xe2\x80\x99s windy diet for a man at my time o\xe2\x80\x99 life!\xe2\x80\x9d He put the\r\ncover on again, and tried the next dish. \xe2\x80\x9cThe fesh? What the de\xe2\x80\x99il does\r\nthe woman fry the trout for? Boil it next time, ye betch, wi\xe2\x80\x99 a pinch\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 saut and a spunefu\xe2\x80\x99 o\xe2\x80\x99 vinegar.\xe2\x80\x9d He drew the cork from a bottle of\r\nsherry, and decanted the wine. \xe2\x80\x9cThe sherry wine?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in tones of\r\ndeep feeling, holding the decanter up to the light. \xe2\x80\x9cHoo do I know but\r\nwhat it may be corkit? I maun taste and try. It\xe2\x80\x99s on my conscience,\r\nas an honest man, to taste and try.\xe2\x80\x9d He forthwith relieved his\r\nconscience--copiously. There was a vacant space, of no inconsiderable\r\ndimensions, left in the decanter. Mr. Bishopriggs gravely filled it up\r\nfrom the water-bottle. \xe2\x80\x9cEh! it\xe2\x80\x99s joost addin\xe2\x80\x99 ten years to the age\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 the wine. The turtle-doves will be nane the waur--and I mysel\xe2\x80\x99 am\r\na glass o\xe2\x80\x99 sherry the better. Praise Providence for a\xe2\x80\x99 its maircies!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n Having relieved himself of that devout aspiration, he took up the tray\r\nagain, and decided on letting the turtle-doves have their dinner.\r\n\r\nThe conversation in the parlor (dropped for the moment) had been\r\nrenewed, in the absence of Mr. Bishopriggs. Too restless to remain\r\nlong in one place, Anne had risen again from the sofa, and had rejoined\r\nArnold at the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere do your friends at Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s believe you to be now?\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nasked, abruptly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am believed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Arnold, \xe2\x80\x9cto be meeting my tenants, and taking\r\npossession of my estate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you to get to your estate to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy railway, I suppose. By-the-by, what excuse am I to make for going\r\naway after dinner? We are sure to have the landlady in here before long.\r\nWhat will she say to my going off by myself to the train, and leaving\r\n\xe2\x80\x98my wife\xe2\x80\x99 behind me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Brinkworth! that joke--if it _is_ a joke--is worn out!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may leave your excuse to me,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Anne. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you go by the up\r\ntrain, or the down?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the up train.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe door opened suddenly; and Mr. Bishopriggs appeared with the dinner.\r\nAnne nervously separated herself from Arnold. The one available eye of\r\nMr. Bishopriggs followed her reproachfully, as he put the dishes on the\r\ntable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI warned ye baith, it was a clean impossibility to knock at the door\r\nthis time. Don\xe2\x80\x99t blame me, young madam--don\xe2\x80\x99t blame _me!\xe2\x80\x9d_\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere will you sit?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Arnold, by way of diverting Anne\xe2\x80\x99s attention\r\nfrom the familiarities of Father Bishopriggs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny where!\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, impatiently; snatching up a chair, and\r\nplacing it at the bottom of the table.\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs politely, but firmly, put the chair back again in its\r\nplace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord\xe2\x80\x99s sake! what are ye doin\xe2\x80\x99? It\xe2\x80\x99s clean contrary to a\xe2\x80\x99 the laws\r\nand customs o\xe2\x80\x99 the honey-mune, to sit as far away from your husband as\r\nthat!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe waved his persuasive napkin to one of the two chairs placed close\r\ntogether at the table.\r\n\r\nArnold interfered once more, and prevented another outbreak of\r\nimpatience from Anne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does it matter?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cLet the man have his way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet it over as soon as you can,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t, and won\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\nbear it much longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey took their places at the table, with Father Bishopriggs behind\r\nthem, in the mixed character of major domo and guardian angel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s the trout!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, taking the cover off with a flourish.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf an hour since, he was loupin\xe2\x80\x99 in the water. There he lies noo,\r\nfried in the dish. An emblem o\xe2\x80\x99 human life for ye! When ye can spare any\r\nleisure time from yer twa selves, meditate on that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold took up the spoon, to give Anne one of the trout. Mr. Bishopriggs\r\nclapped the cover on the dish again, with a countenance expressive of\r\ndevout horror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there naebody gaun\xe2\x80\x99 to say grace?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome! come!\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold. \xe2\x80\x9cThe fish is getting cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs piously closed his available eye, and held the cover\r\nfirmly on the dish. \xe2\x80\x9cFor what ye\xe2\x80\x99re gaun\xe2\x80\x99 to receive, may ye baith be\r\ntruly thankful!\xe2\x80\x9d He opened his available eye, and whipped the cover off\r\nagain. \xe2\x80\x9cMy conscience is easy noo. Fall to! Fall to!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSend him away!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anne. \xe2\x80\x9cHis familiarity is beyond all endurance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou needn\xe2\x80\x99t wait,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh! but I\xe2\x80\x99m here to wait,\xe2\x80\x9d objected Mr. Bishopriggs. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmy gaun\xe2\x80\x99 away, when ye\xe2\x80\x99ll want me anon to change the plates for ye?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n He considered for a moment (privately consulting his experience) and\r\narrived at a satisfactory conclusion as to Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s motive for wanting\r\nto get rid of him. \xe2\x80\x9cTak\xe2\x80\x99 her on yer knee,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered in Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s\r\near, \xe2\x80\x9cas soon as ye like! Feed him at the fork\xe2\x80\x99s end,\xe2\x80\x9d he added to Anne,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhenever ye please! I\xe2\x80\x99ll think of something else, and look out at the\r\nproaspect.\xe2\x80\x9d He winked--and went to the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome! come!\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold to Anne. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a comic side to all this.\r\nTry and see it as I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs returned from the window, and announced the appearance\r\nof a new element of embarrassment in the situation at the inn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy certie!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s weel ye cam\xe2\x80\x99 when ye did. It\xe2\x80\x99s ill getting\r\nto this hottle in a storm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne started and looked round at him. \xe2\x80\x9cA storm coming!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh! ye\xe2\x80\x99re well hoosed here--ye needn\xe2\x80\x99t mind it. There\xe2\x80\x99s the cloud down\r\nthe valley,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, pointing out of the window, \xe2\x80\x9ccoming up one way,\r\nwhen the wind\xe2\x80\x99s blawing the other. The storm\xe2\x80\x99s brewing, my leddy, when\r\nye see that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was another knock at the door. As Arnold had predicted, the\r\nlandlady made her appearance on the scene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ha\xe2\x80\x99 just lookit in, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Inchbare, addressing herself\r\nexclusively to Arnold, \xe2\x80\x9cto see ye\xe2\x80\x99ve got what ye want.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! you are the landlady? Very nice, ma\xe2\x80\x99am--very nice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMistress Inchbare had her own private motive for entering the room, and\r\ncame to it without further preface.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe\xe2\x80\x99ll excuse me, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she proceeded. \xe2\x80\x9cI wasna in the way when ye cam\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhere, or I suld ha\xe2\x80\x99 made bauld to ask ye the question which I maun e\xe2\x80\x99en\r\nask noo. Am I to understand that ye hire these rooms for yersel\xe2\x80\x99, and\r\nthis leddy here--yer wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne raised her head to speak. Arnold pressed her hand warningly, under\r\nthe table, and silenced her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI take the rooms for myself, and this lady\r\nhere--my wife!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne made a second attempt to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis gentleman--\xe2\x80\x9d she began.\r\n\r\nArnold stopped her for the second time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis gentleman?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mrs. Inchbare, with a broad stare of\r\nsurprise. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m only a puir woman, my leddy--d\xe2\x80\x99ye mean yer husband here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s warning hand touched Anne\xe2\x80\x99s, for the third time. Mistress\r\nInchbare\xe2\x80\x99s eyes remained fixed on her in merciless inquiry. To have\r\ngiven utterance to the contradiction which trembled on her lips would\r\nhave been to involve Arnold (after all that he had sacrificed for her)\r\nin the scandal which would inevitably follow--a scandal which would be\r\ntalked of in the neighborhood, and which might find its way to Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nears. White and cold, her eyes never moving from the table, she accepted\r\nthe landlady\xe2\x80\x99s implied correction, and faintly repeated the words: \xe2\x80\x9cMy\r\nhusband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMistress Inchbare drew a breath of virtuous relief, and waited for what\r\nAnne had to say next. Arnold came considerately to the rescue, and got\r\nher out of the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Anne; \xe2\x80\x9cI know what it is, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll see about\r\nit. She\xe2\x80\x99s always like this, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, when a storm\xe2\x80\x99s coming,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on,\r\nturning to the landlady. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, thank you--I know how to manage her. Well\r\nsend to you, if we want your assistance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt yer ain pleasure, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mistress Inchbare. She turned, and\r\napologized to Anne (under protest), with a stiff courtesy. \xe2\x80\x9cNo offense,\r\nmy leddy! Ye\xe2\x80\x99ll remember that ye cam\xe2\x80\x99 here alane, and that the hottle\r\nhas its ain gude name to keep up.\xe2\x80\x9d Having once more vindicated \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nhottle,\xe2\x80\x9d she made the long-desired move to the door, and left the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m faint!\xe2\x80\x9d Anne whispered. \xe2\x80\x9cGive me some water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was no water on the table. Arnold ordered it of Mr.\r\nBishopriggs--who had remained passive in the back-ground (a model of\r\ndiscreet attention) as long as the mistress was in the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Brinkworth!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anne, when they were alone, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are acting with\r\ninexcusable rashness. That woman\xe2\x80\x99s question was an impertinence. Why did\r\nyou answer it? Why did you force me--?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe stopped, unable to finish the sentence. Arnold insisted on her\r\ndrinking a glass of wine--and then defended himself with the patient\r\nconsideration for her which he had shown from the first.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t I have the inn door shut in your face\xe2\x80\x9d--he asked, good\r\nhumoredly--\xe2\x80\x9cwith a storm coming on, and without a place in which you can\r\ntake refuge? No, no, Miss Silvester! I don\xe2\x80\x99t presume to blame you for\r\nany scruples you may feel--but scruples are sadly out of place with such\r\na woman as that landlady. I am responsible for your safety to Geoffrey;\r\nand Geoffrey expects to find you here. Let\xe2\x80\x99s change the subject. The\r\nwater is a long time coming. Try another glass of wine. No? Well--here\r\nis Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s health\xe2\x80\x9d (he took some of the wine himself), \xe2\x80\x9cin the\r\nweakest sherry I ever drank in my life.\xe2\x80\x9d As he set down his glass,\r\nMr. Bishopriggs came in with the water. Arnold hailed him satirically.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell? have you got the water? or have you used it all for the sherry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs stopped in the middle of the room, thunder-struck at the\r\naspersion cast on the wine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that the way ye talk of the auldest bottle o\xe2\x80\x99 sherry wine in\r\nScotland?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, gravely. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the warld coming to? The new\r\ngeneration\xe2\x80\x99s a foot beyond my fathoming. The maircies o\xe2\x80\x99 Providence, as\r\nshown to man in the choicest veentages o\xe2\x80\x99 Spain, are clean thrown away\r\non \xe2\x80\x98em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you brought the water?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ha\xe2\x80\x99 brought the water--and mair than the water. I ha\xe2\x80\x99 brought ye\r\nnews from ootside. There\xe2\x80\x99s a company o\xe2\x80\x99 gentlemen on horseback, joost\r\ncantering by to what they ca\xe2\x80\x99 the shootin\xe2\x80\x99 cottage, a mile from this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell--and what have we got to do with it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBide a wee! There\xe2\x80\x99s ane o\xe2\x80\x99 them has drawn bridle at the hottle, and\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s speerin\xe2\x80\x99 after the leddy that cam\xe2\x80\x99 here alane. The leddy\xe2\x80\x99s your\r\nleddy, as sure as saxpence. I doot,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bishopriggs, walking away\r\nto the window, \xe2\x80\x9c_that\xe2\x80\x99s_ what ye\xe2\x80\x99ve got to do with it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold looked at Anne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you expect any body?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it Geoffrey?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible. Geoffrey is on his way to London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere he is, any way,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Mr. Bishopriggs, at the window. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nloupin\xe2\x80\x99 down from his horse. He\xe2\x80\x99s turning this way. Lord save us!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nexclaimed, with a start of consternation, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do I see? That incarnate\r\ndeevil, Sir Paitrick himself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold sprang to his feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean Sir Patrick Lundie?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne ran to the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt _is_ Sir Patrick!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cHide yourself before he comes in!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHide myself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will he think if he sees you with _me?\xe2\x80\x9d_\r\n\r\nHe was Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s guardian, and he believed Arnold to be at that moment\r\nvisiting his new property. What he would think was not difficult to\r\nforesee. Arnold turned for help to Mr. Bishopriggs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere can I go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs pointed to the bedroom door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhar\xe2\x80\x99 can ye go? There\xe2\x80\x99s the nuptial chamber!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs expressed the utmost extremity of human amazement by a\r\nlong whistle, on one note.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhew! Is that the way ye talk o\xe2\x80\x99 the nuptial chamber already?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFind me some other place--I\xe2\x80\x99ll make it worth your while.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh! there\xe2\x80\x99s my paintry! I trow that\xe2\x80\x99s some other place; and the door\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nat the end o\xe2\x80\x99 the passage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold hurried out. Mr. Bishopriggs--evidently under the impression that\r\nthe case before him was a case of elopement, with Sir Patrick mixed\r\nup in it in the capacity of guardian--addressed himself, in friendly\r\nconfidence, to Anne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy certie, mistress! it\xe2\x80\x99s ill wark deceivin\xe2\x80\x99 Sir Paitrick, if that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhat ye\xe2\x80\x99ve dune. Ye must know, I was ance a bit clerk body in his\r\nchambers at Embro--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe voice of Mistress Inchbare, calling for the head-waiter, rose shrill\r\nand imperative from the regions of the bar. Mr. Bishopriggs disappeared.\r\nAnne remained, standing helpless by the window. It was plain by this\r\ntime that the place of her retreat had been discovered at Windygates.\r\nThe one doubt to decide, now, was whether it would be wise or not to\r\nreceive Sir Patrick, for the purpose of discovering whether he came as\r\nfriend or enemy to the inn.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE ELEVENTH.\r\n\r\nSIR PATRICK.\r\n\r\nTHE doubt was practically decided before Anne had determined what to do.\r\nShe was still at the window when the sitting-room door was thrown open,\r\nand Sir Patrick appeared, obsequiously shown in by Mr. Bishopriggs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe\xe2\x80\x99re kindly welcome, Sir Paitrick. Hech, Sirs! the sight of you is\r\ngude for sair eyne.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick turned and looked at Mr. Bishopriggs--as he might have\r\nlooked at some troublesome insect which he had driven out of the window,\r\nand which had returned on him again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, you scoundrel! have you drifted into an honest employment at\r\nlast?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs rubbed his hands cheerfully, and took his tone from his\r\nsuperior, with supple readiness,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe\xe2\x80\x99re always in the right of it, Sir Paitrick! Wut, raal wut in that\r\naboot the honest employment, and me drifting into it. Lord\xe2\x80\x99s sake, Sir,\r\nhoo well ye wear!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDismissing Mr. Bishopriggs by a sign, Sir Patrick advanced to Anne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am committing an intrusion, madam which must, I am afraid, appear\r\nunpardonable in your eyes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cMay I hope you will excuse me when\r\nI have made you acquainted with my motive?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe spoke with scrupulous politeness. His knowledge of Anne was of the\r\nslightest possible kind. Like other men, he had felt the attraction of\r\nher unaffected grace and gentleness on the few occasions when he had\r\nbeen in her company--and that was all. If he had belonged to the present\r\ngeneration he would, under the circumstances, have fallen into one of\r\nthe besetting sins of England in these days--the tendency (to borrow an\r\nillustration from the stage) to \xe2\x80\x9cstrike an attitude\xe2\x80\x9d in the presence\r\nof a social emergency. A man of the present period, in Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nposition, would have struck an attitude of (what is called) chivalrous\r\nrespect; and would have addressed Anne in a tone of ready-made sympathy,\r\nwhich it was simply impossible for a stranger really to feel. Sir\r\nPatrick affected nothing of the sort. One of the besetting sins of _his_\r\ntime was the habitual concealment of our better selves--upon the whole,\r\na far less dangerous national error than the habitual advertisement of\r\nour better selves, which has become the practice, public and privately,\r\nof society in this age. Sir Patrick assumed, if anything, less sympathy\r\non this occasion than he really felt. Courteous to all women, he was as\r\ncourteous as usual to Anne--and no more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am quite at a loss, Sir, to know what brings you to this place. The\r\nservant here informs me that you are one of a party of gentlemen who\r\nhave just passed by the inn, and who have all gone on except yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n In those guarded terms Anne opened the interview with the unwelcome\r\nvisitor, on her side.\r\n\r\nSir Patrick admitted the fact, without betraying the slightest\r\nembarrassment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe servant is quite right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI am one of the party. And I\r\nhave purposely allowed them to go on to the keeper\xe2\x80\x99s cottage without\r\nme. Having admitted this, may I count on receiving your permission to\r\nexplain the motive of my visit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNecessarily suspicious of him, as coming from Windygates, Anne answered\r\nin few and formal words, as coldly as before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain it, Sir Patrick, if you please, as briefly as possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick bowed. He was not in the least offended; he was even (if the\r\nconfession may be made without degrading him in the public estimation)\r\nprivately amused. Conscious of having honestly presented himself at the\r\ninn in Anne\xe2\x80\x99s interests, as well as in the interests of the ladies at\r\nWindygates, it appealed to his sense of humor to find himself kept\r\nat arm\xe2\x80\x99s-length by the very woman whom he had come to benefit. The\r\ntemptation was strong on him to treat his errand from his own whimsical\r\npoint of view. He gravely took out his watch, and noted the time to a\r\nsecond, before he spoke again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have an event to relate in which you are interested,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nI have two messages to deliver, which I hope you will not object to\r\nreceive. The event I undertake to describe in one minute. The messages\r\nI promise to dispose of in two minutes more. Total duration of this\r\nintrusion on your time--three minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe placed a chair for Anne, and waited until she had permitted him, by a\r\nsign, to take a second chair for himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will begin with the event,\xe2\x80\x9d he resumed. \xe2\x80\x9cYour arrival at this place\r\nis no secret at Windygates. You were seen on the foot-road to Craig\r\nFernie by one of the female servants. And the inference naturally drawn\r\nis, that you were on your way to the inn. It may be important for you to\r\nknow this; and I have taken the liberty of mentioning it accordingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n He consulted his watch. \xe2\x80\x9cEvent related. Time, one minute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had excited her curiosity, to begin with. \xe2\x80\x9cWhich of the women saw\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, impulsively.\r\n\r\nSir Patrick (watch in hand) declined to prolong the interview by\r\nanswering any incidental inquiries which might arise in the course of\r\nit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me,\xe2\x80\x9d he rejoined; \xe2\x80\x9cI am pledged to occupy three minutes only. I\r\nhave no room for the woman. With your kind permission, I will get on to\r\nthe messages next.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne remained silent. Sir Patrick went on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFirst message: \xe2\x80\x98Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s compliments to her step-daughter\xe2\x80\x99s late\r\ngoverness--with whose married name she is not acquainted. Lady Lundie\r\nregrets to say that Sir Patrick, as head of the family, has threatened\r\nto return to Edinburgh, unless she consents to be guided by his\r\nadvice in the course she pursues with the late governess. Lady Lundie,\r\naccordingly, foregoes her intention of calling at the Craig Fernie inn,\r\nto express her sentiments and make her inquiries in person, and commits\r\nto Sir Patrick the duty of expressing her sentiments; reserving to\r\nherself the right of making her inquiries at the next convenient\r\nopportunity. Through the medium of her brother-in-law, she begs to\r\ninform the late governess that all intercourse is at an end between\r\nthem, and that she declines to act as reference in case of future\r\nemergency.\xe2\x80\x99--Message textually correct. Expressive of Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s view\r\nof your sudden departure from the house. Time, two minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s color rose. Anne\xe2\x80\x99s pride was up in arms on the spot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe impertinence of Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s message is no more than I should\r\nhave expected from her,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI am only surprised at Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndelivering it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s motives will appear presently,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the incorrigible\r\nold gentleman. \xe2\x80\x9cSecond message: \xe2\x80\x98Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s fondest love. Is dying to\r\nbe acquainted with Anne\xe2\x80\x99s husband, and to be informed of Anne\xe2\x80\x99s married\r\nname. Feels indescribable anxiety and apprehension on Anne\xe2\x80\x99s account.\r\nInsists on hearing from Anne immediately. Longs, as she never longed\r\nfor any thing yet, to order her pony-chaise and drive full gallop to\r\nthe inn. Yields, under irresistible pressure, to t he exertion of her\r\nguardian\xe2\x80\x99s authority, and commits the expression of her feelings to Sir\r\nPatrick, who is a born tyrant, and doesn\xe2\x80\x99t in the least mind breaking\r\nother people\xe2\x80\x99s hearts.\xe2\x80\x99 Sir Patrick, speaking for himself, places his\r\nsister-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s view and his niece\xe2\x80\x99s view, side by side, before the lady\r\nwhom he has now the honor of addressing, and on whose confidence he is\r\nespecially careful not to intrude. Reminds the lady that his influence\r\nat Windygates, however strenuously he may exert it, is not likely to\r\nlast forever. Requests her to consider whether his sister-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s view\r\nand his niece\xe2\x80\x99s view in collision, may not lead to very undesirable\r\ndomestic results; and leaves her to take the course which seems best to\r\nherself under those circumstances.--Second message delivered textually.\r\nTime, three minutes. A storm coming on. A quarter of an hour\xe2\x80\x99s ride from\r\nhere to the shooting-cottage. Madam, I wish you good-evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe bowed lower than ever--and, without a word more, quietly left the\r\nroom.\r\n\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s first impulse was (excusably enough, poor soul) an impulse of\r\nresentment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, Sir Patrick!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with a bitter look at the closing\r\ndoor. \xe2\x80\x9cThe sympathy of society with a friendless woman could hardly have\r\nbeen expressed in a more amusing way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe little irritation of the moment passed off with the moment. Anne\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nown intelligence and good sense showed her the position in its truer\r\nlight.\r\n\r\nShe recognized in Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s abrupt departure Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconsiderate resolution to spare her from entering into any details on\r\nthe subject of her position at the inn. He had given her a friendly\r\nwarning; and he had delicately left her to decide for herself as to the\r\nassistance which she might render him in maintaining tranquillity at\r\nWindygates. She went at once to a side-table in the room, on which\r\nwriting materials were placed, and sat down to write to Blanche.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can do nothing with Lady Lundie,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I have more\r\ninfluence than any body else over Blanche and I can prevent the\r\ncollision between them which Sir Patrick dreads.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe began the letter. \xe2\x80\x9cMy dearest Blanche, I have seen Sir Patrick, and\r\nhe has given me your message. I will set your mind at ease about me as\r\nsoon as I can. But, before I say any thing else, let me entreat you,\r\nas the greatest favor you can do to your sister and your friend, not to\r\nenter into any disputes about me with Lady Lundie, and not to commit\r\nthe imprudence--the useless imprudence, my love--of coming here.\xe2\x80\x9d She\r\nstopped--the paper swam before her eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cMy own darling!\xe2\x80\x9d she thought,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwho could have foreseen that I should ever shrink from the thought of\r\nseeing _you?\xe2\x80\x9d_ She sighed, and dipped the pen in the ink, and went on\r\nwith the letter.\r\n\r\nThe sky darkened rapidly as the evening fell. The wind swept in fainter\r\nand fainter gusts across the dreary moor. Far and wide over the face of\r\nNature the stillness was fast falling which tells of a coming storm.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE TWELFTH.\r\n\r\nARNOLD.\r\n\r\nMEANWHILE Arnold remained shut up in the head-waiter\xe2\x80\x99s pantry--chafing\r\nsecretly at the position forced upon him.\r\n\r\nHe was, for the first time in his life, in hiding from another person,\r\nand that person a man. Twice--stung to it by the inevitable loss of\r\nself-respect which his situation occasioned--he had gone to the door,\r\ndetermined to face Sir Patrick boldly; and twice he had abandoned the\r\nidea, in mercy to Anne. It would have been impossible for him to set\r\nhimself right with Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s guardian without betraying the unhappy\r\nwoman whose secret he was bound in honor to keep. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish to Heaven I\r\nhad never come here!\xe2\x80\x9d was the useless aspiration that escaped him, as\r\nhe doggedly seated himself on the dresser to wait till Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndeparture set him free.\r\n\r\nAfter an interval--not by any means the long interval which he had\r\nanticipated--his solitude was enlivened by the appearance of Father\r\nBishopriggs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Arnold, jumping off the dresser, \xe2\x80\x9cis the coast clear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere were occasions when Mr. Bishopriggs became, on a sudden,\r\nunexpectedly hard of hearing, This was one of them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoo do ye find the paintry?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, without paying the slightest\r\nattention to Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s question. \xe2\x80\x9cSnug and private? A Patmos in the\r\nweelderness, as ye may say!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis one available eye, which had begun by looking at Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s face,\r\ndropped slowly downward, and fixed itself, in mute but eloquent\r\nexpectation, on Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s waistcoat pocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand!\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold. \xe2\x80\x9cI promised to pay you for the Patmos--eh?\r\nThere you are!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs pocketed the money with a dreary smile and a sympathetic\r\nshake of the head. Other waiters would have returned thanks. The sage\r\nof Craig Fernie returned a few brief remarks instead. Admirable in many\r\nthings, Father Bishopriggs was especially great at drawing a moral. He\r\ndrew a moral on this occasion from his own gratuity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere I am--as ye say. Mercy presairve us! ye need the siller at every\r\nturn, when there\xe2\x80\x99s a woman at yer heels. It\xe2\x80\x99s an awfu\xe2\x80\x99 reflection--ye\r\ncanna hae any thing to do wi\xe2\x80\x99 the sex they ca\xe2\x80\x99 the opposite sex without\r\nits being an expense to ye. There\xe2\x80\x99s this young leddy o\xe2\x80\x99 yours, I doot\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99ll ha\xe2\x80\x99 been an expense to ye from the first. When you were\r\ncoortin\xe2\x80\x99 her, ye did it, I\xe2\x80\x99ll go bail, wi\xe2\x80\x99 the open hand. Presents and\r\nkeep-sakes, flowers and jewelery, and little dogues. Sair expenses all\r\nof them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHang your reflections! Has Sir Patrick left the inn?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe reflections of Mr. Bishopriggs declined to be disposed of in any\r\nthing approaching to a summary way. On they flowed from their parent\r\nsource, as slowly and as smoothly as ever!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNoo ye\xe2\x80\x99re married to her, there\xe2\x80\x99s her bonnets and goons and\r\nunder-clothin\xe2\x80\x99--her ribbons, laces, furbelows, and fallals. A sair\r\nexpense again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the expense of cutting your reflections short, Mr.\r\nBishopriggs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThirdly, and lastly, if ye canna agree wi\xe2\x80\x99 her as time gaes on--if\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s incompaitibeelity of temper betwixt ye--in short, if ye want a\r\nwee bit separation, hech, Sirs! ye pet yer hand in yer poaket, and come\r\nto an aimicable understandin\xe2\x80\x99 wi\xe2\x80\x99 her in that way. Or, maybe she takes\r\nye into Court, and pets _her_ hand in your poaket, and comes to a\r\nhoastile understandin\xe2\x80\x99 wi\xe2\x80\x99 ye there. Show me a woman--and I\xe2\x80\x99ll show ye\r\na man not far off wha\xe2\x80\x99 has mair expenses on his back than he ever\r\nbairgained for.\xe2\x80\x9d Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s patience would last no longer--he turned to\r\nthe door. Mr. Bishopriggs, with equal alacrity on his side, turned to\r\nthe matter in hand. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, Sir! The room is e\xe2\x80\x99en clear o\xe2\x80\x99 Sir Paitrick,\r\nand the leddy\xe2\x80\x99s alane, and waitin\xe2\x80\x99 for ye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn a moment more Arnold was back in the sitting-room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, anxiously. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it? Bad news from Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne closed and directed the letter to Blanche, which she had just\r\ncompleted. \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing to interest _you_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did Sir Patrick want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly to warn me. They have found out at Windygates that I am here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s awkward, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot in the least. I can manage perfectly; I have nothing to fear. Don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthink of _me_--think of yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not suspected, am I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank heaven--no. The rain had come--and was falling heavily.\r\nThe view on the moor was fast disappearing in mist and darkness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPleasant weather to travel in!\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe railway!\xe2\x80\x9d Anne exclaimed, impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s getting late. See\r\nabout the railway!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold walked to the fire-place to ring the bell. The railway time-table\r\nhanging over it met his eye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s the information I want,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Anne; \xe2\x80\x9cif I only knew how\r\nto get at it. \xe2\x80\x98Down\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98Up\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98A. M.\xe2\x80\x99--P. M.\xe2\x80\x99 What a cursed confusion! I\r\nbelieve they do it on purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne joined him at the fire-place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand it--I\xe2\x80\x99ll help you. She followed the intricate net-work of lines and\r\nfigures with her finger--suddenly stopped--looked again to make\r\nsure--and turned from the time-table with a face of blank despair. The\r\nlast train for the day had gone an hour since.\r\n\r\nIn the silence which followed that discovery, a first flash of lightning\r\npassed across the window and the low roll of thunder sounded the\r\noutbreak of the storm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s to be done now?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Arnold.\r\n\r\nIn the face of the storm, Anne answered without hesitation, \xe2\x80\x9cYou must\r\ntake a carriage, and drive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrive? They told me it was three-and-twenty miles, by railway, from\r\nthe station to my place--let alone the distance from this inn to the\r\nstation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does the distance matter? Mr. Brinkworth, you can\xe2\x80\x99t possibly stay\r\nhere!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA second flash of lightning crossed the window; the roll of the thunder\r\ncame nearer. Even Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s good temper began to be a little ruffled by\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s determination to get rid of him. He sat down with the air of a\r\nman who had made up his mind not to leave the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear that?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, as the sound of the thunder died away\r\ngrandly, and the hard pattering of the rain on the window became audible\r\nonce more. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I ordered horses, do you think they would let me have\r\nthem, in such weather as this? No! he was quite unconscious\r\nof having said any thing that could offend her. His rough masculine\r\nsense broke its way unconsciously through all the little feminine\r\nsubtleties and delicacies of his companion, and looked the position\r\npractically in the face for what it was worth, and no more. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nembarrassment?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, pointing to the bedroom door. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s your\r\nroom, all ready for you. And here\xe2\x80\x99s the sofa, in this room, all ready\r\nfor _me._ If you had seen the places I have slept in at sea--!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe interrupted him, without ceremony. The places he had slept in, at\r\nsea, were of no earthly importance. The one question to consider, was\r\nthe place he was to sleep in that night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you must stay,\xe2\x80\x9d she rejoined, \xe2\x80\x9ccan\xe2\x80\x99t you get a room in some other\r\npart of the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut one last mistake in dealing with her, in her present nervous\r\ncondition, was left to make--and the innocent Arnold made it. \xe2\x80\x9cIn some\r\nother part of the house?\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, jestingly. \xe2\x80\x9cThe landlady would be\r\nscandalized. The most sensitive woman breathing could not\r\nhave accused him of failing toward her in any single essential of\r\nconsideration and respect. Mr. Bishopriggs\r\n(employing his brief leisure in the seclusion of his own apartment) had\r\njust mixed a glass of the hot and comforting liquor called \xe2\x80\x9ctoddy\xe2\x80\x9d in\r\nthe language of North Britain, and was just lifting it to his lips, when\r\nthe summons from Arnold invited him to leave his grog.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaud yer screechin\xe2\x80\x99 tongue!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mr. Bishopriggs, addressing the\r\nbell through the door. \xe2\x80\x9cYe\xe2\x80\x99re waur than a woman when ye aince begin!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe bell--like the woman--went on again. Mr. Bishopriggs, equally\r\npertinacious, went on with his toddy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy! ay! ye may e\xe2\x80\x99en ring yer heart out--but ye won\xe2\x80\x99t part a Scotchman\r\nfrom his glass. It was useless to say\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccome in.\xe2\x80\x9d The immutable laws of Bishopriggs had decided that a second\r\nknock was necessary. Storm or no storm, the second knock came--and\r\nthen, and not till then, the sage appeared, with the dish of untasted\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccollops\xe2\x80\x9d in his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCandles!\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold.\r\n\r\nMr. Bishopriggs set the \xe2\x80\x9ccollops\xe2\x80\x9d (in the language of England, minced\r\nmeat) upon the table, lit the candles on the mantle-piece, faced about\r\nwith the fire of recent toddy flaming in his nose, and waited for\r\nfurther orders, before he went back to his second glass. The deevil\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nallegories in the deevil\xe2\x80\x99s own colors--red and black! I wunna execute\r\nyer order. For yer ain saul\xe2\x80\x99s sake, I wunna do it.
