Do you follow me, so far?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! yes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you fail to control yourself, you place an obstacle in the way of\r\nmy being of some future use to Miss Silvester. Remember that, and now\r\nprepare for the surprise. What did I tell you before dinner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said you had made discoveries at Craig Fernie. What have you found\r\nout?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have found out that there is a certain person who is in full\r\npossession of the information which Miss Silvester has concealed from\r\nyou and from me. The person is within our reach. The person is in this\r\nneighborhood. The person is in this room!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe caught up Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s hand, resting on his arm, and pressed it\r\nsignificantly. She looked at him with the cry of surprise suspended\r\non her lips--waited a little with her eyes fixed on Fir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nface--struggled resolutely, and composed herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoint the person out.\xe2\x80\x9d She said the words with a self-possession which\r\nwon her uncle\xe2\x80\x99s hearty approval. Blanche had done wonders for a girl in\r\nher teens.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick; \xe2\x80\x9cand tell me what you see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see Lady Lundie, at the other end of the room, with the map of\r\nPerthshire and the Baronial Antiquities of Scotland on the table. And I\r\nsee every body but you and me obliged to listen to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvery body?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche looked carefully round the room, and noticed Geoffrey in the\r\nopposite corner; fast asleep by this time in his arm-chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUncle! you don\xe2\x80\x99t mean--?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is the man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Delamayn--!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Delamayn knows every thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche held mechanically by her uncle\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and looked at the sleeping\r\nman as if her eyes could never see enough of him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou saw me in the library in private consultation with Mr. Delamayn,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n resumed Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cI have to acknowledge, my dear, that you were\r\nquite right in thinking this a suspicious circumstance, And I am now\r\nto justify myself for having purposely kept you in the dark up to the\r\npresent time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith those introductory words, he briefly reverted to the earlier\r\noccurrences of the day, and then added, by way of commentary, a\r\nstatement of the conclusions which events had suggested to his own mind.\r\n\r\nThe events, it may be remembered, were three in number. First,\r\nGeoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s private conference with Sir Patrick on the subject of\r\nIrregular Marriages in Scotland. Secondly, Anne Silvester\xe2\x80\x99s appearance\r\nat Windygates. Thirdly, Anne\xe2\x80\x99s flight.\r\n\r\nThe conclusions which had thereupon suggested themselves to Sir\r\nPatrick\xe2\x80\x99s mind were six in number.\r\n\r\nFirst, that a connection of some sort might possibly exist between\r\nGeoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s acknowledged difficulty about his friend, and Miss\r\nSilvester\xe2\x80\x99s presumed difficulty about herself. Secondly, that Geoffrey\r\nhad really put to Sir Patrick--not his own case--but the case of a\r\nfriend. Thirdly, that Geoffrey had some interest (of no harmless kind)\r\nin establishing the fact of his friend\xe2\x80\x99s marriage. Fourthly, that Anne\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nanxiety (as described by Blanche) to hear the names of the gentlemen who\r\nwere staying at Windygates, pointed, in all probability, to Geoffrey.\r\nFifthly, that this last inference disturbed the second conclusion, and\r\nreopened the doubt whether Geoffrey had not been stating his own case,\r\nafter all, under pretense of stating the case of a friend. Sixthly, that\r\nthe one way of obtaining any enlightenment on this point, and on all the\r\nother points involved in mystery, was to go to Craig Fernie, and consult\r\nMrs. Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s experience during the period of Anne\xe2\x80\x99s residence at the\r\ninn. Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s apology for keeping all this a secret from his niece\r\nfollowed. He had shrunk from agitating her on the subject until he\r\ncould be sure of proving his conclusions to be true. The proof had been\r\nobtained; and he was now, therefore, ready to open his mind to Blanche\r\nwithout reserve.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d proceeded Sir Patrick, \xe2\x80\x9cfor those necessary\r\nexplanations which are also the necessary nuisances of human\r\nintercourse. You now know as much as I did when I arrived at Craig\r\nFernie--and you are, therefore, in a position to appreciate the value of\r\nmy discoveries at the inn. Do you understand every thing, so far?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good. I drove up to the inn; and--behold me closeted with Mrs.\r\nInchbare in her own private parlor! (My reputation may or may not\r\nsuffer, but Mrs. Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s bones are above suspicion!) It was a long\r\nbusiness, Blanche. A more sour-tempered, cunning, and distrustful\r\nwitness I never examined in all my experience at the Bar. She would have\r\nupset the temper of any mortal man but a lawyer. We have such wonderful\r\ntempers in our profession; and we can be so aggravating when we like! In\r\nshort, my dear, Mrs. Inchbare was a she-cat, and I was a he-cat--and I\r\nclawed the truth out of her at last. The result was well worth\r\narriving at, as you shall see. Mr. Delamayn had described to me certain\r\nremarkable circumstances as taking place between a lady and a gentleman\r\nat an inn: the object of the parties being to pass themselves off at\r\nthe time as man and wife. Every one of those circumstances, Blanche,\r\noccurred at Craig Fernie, between a lady and a gentleman, on the day\r\nwhen Miss Silvester disappeared from this house And--wait!--being\r\npressed for her name, after the gentleman had left her behind him at the\r\ninn, the name the lady gave was, \xe2\x80\x98Mrs. Silvester.\xe2\x80\x99 What do you think of\r\nthat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink! I\xe2\x80\x99m bewildered--I can\xe2\x80\x99t realize it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a startling discovery, my dear child--there is no denying that.\r\nShall I wait a little, and let you recover yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! no! Go on! The gentleman, uncle? The gentleman who was with Anne?\r\nWho is he? Not Mr. Delamayn?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot Mr. Delamayn,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I have proved nothing else, I\r\nhave proved that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat need was there to prove it? Mr. Delamayn went to London on the day\r\nof the lawn-party. And Arnold--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Arnold went with him as far as the second station from this. Quite\r\ntrue! But how was I to know what Mr. Delamayn might have done after\r\nArnold had left him? I could only make sure that he had not gone back\r\nprivately to the inn, by getting the proof from Mrs. Inchbare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did you get it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI asked her to describe the gentleman who was with Miss Silvester.\r\nMrs. Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s description (vague as you will presently find it to be)\r\ncompletely exonerates that man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick, pointing to Geoffrey\r\nstill asleep in his chair. \xe2\x80\x9c_He_ is not the person who passed Miss\r\nSilvester off as his wife at Craig Fernie. He spoke the truth when he\r\ndescribed the case to me as the case of a friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who is the friend?\xe2\x80\x9d persisted Blanche. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what I want to\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what I want to know, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me exactly, uncle, what Mrs. Inchbare said. I have lived with Anne\r\nall my life. I _must_ have seen the man somewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you can identify him by Mrs. Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s description,\xe2\x80\x9d returned\r\nSir Patrick, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will be a great deal cleverer than I am. Here is the\r\npicture of the man, as painted by the landlady: Young; middle-sized;\r\ndark hair, eyes, and complexion; nice temper, pleasant way of speaking.\r\nLeave out \xe2\x80\x98young,\xe2\x80\x99 and the rest is the exact contrary of Mr. Delamayn.\r\nSo far, Mrs. Inchbare guides us plainly enough. But how are we to\r\napply her description to the right person? There must be, at the\r\nlowest computation, five hundred thousand men in England who are young,\r\nmiddle-sized, dark, nice-tempered, and pleasant spoken. One of the\r\nfootmen here answers that description in every particular.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Arnold answers it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Blanche--as a still stronger instance of\r\nthe provoking vagueness of the description.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Arnold answers it,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Sir Patrick, quite agreeing with her.\r\n\r\nThey had barely said those words when Arnold himself appeared,\r\napproaching Sir Patrick with a pack of cards in his hand.\r\n\r\nThere--at the very moment when they had both guessed the truth, without\r\nfeeling the slightest suspicion of it in their own minds--there stood\r\nDiscovery, presenting itself unconsciously to eyes incapable of seeing\r\nit, in the person of the man who had passed Anne Silvester off as\r\nhis wife at the Craig Fernie inn! The terrible caprice of Chance, the\r\nmerciless irony of Circumstance, could go no further than this. The\r\nthree had their feet on the brink of the precipice at that moment. And\r\ntwo of them were smiling at an odd coincidence; and one of them was\r\nshuffling a pack of cards!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have done with the Antiquities at last!\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold; \xe2\x80\x9cand we are\r\ngoing to play at Whist. Sir Patrick, will you choose a card?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToo soon after dinner, my good fellow, for _me_. Play the first rubber,\r\nand then give me another chance. By-the-way,\xe2\x80\x9d he added \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Silvester\r\nhas been traced to Kirkandrew. How is it that you never saw her go by?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe can\xe2\x80\x99t have gone my way, Sir Patrick, or I must have seen her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaving justified himself in those terms, he was recalled to the other\r\nend of the room by the whist-party, impatient for the cards which he had\r\nin his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat were we talking of when he interrupted us?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick to\r\nBlanche.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf the man, uncle, who was with Miss Silvester at the inn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s useless to pursue that inquiry, my dear, with nothing better than\r\nMrs. Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s description to help us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche looked round at the sleeping Geoffrey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd _he_ knows!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s maddening, uncle, to look at the brute\r\nsnoring in his chair!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick held up a warning hand. Before a word more could be said\r\nbetween them they were silenced again by another interruption.\r\n\r\nThe whist-party comprised Lady Lundie and the surgeon, playing as\r\npartners against Smith and Jones. Arnold sat behind the surgeon, taking\r\na lesson in the game. One, Two, and Three, thus left to their own\r\ndevices, naturally thought of the billiard-table; and, detecting\r\nGeoffrey asleep in his corner, advanced to disturb his slumbers, under\r\nthe all-sufficing apology of \xe2\x80\x9cPool.\xe2\x80\x9d Geoffrey roused himself, and rubbed\r\nhis eyes, and said, drowsily, \xe2\x80\x9cAll right.\xe2\x80\x9d As he rose, he looked at\r\nthe opposite corner in which Sir Patrick and his niece were sitting.\r\nBlanche\xe2\x80\x99s self-possession, resolutely as she struggled to preserve it,\r\nwas not strong enough to keep her eyes from turning toward Geoffrey with\r\nan expression which betrayed the reluctant interest that she now felt in\r\nhim. He stopped, noticing something entirely new in the look with which\r\nthe young lady was regarding him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Geoffrey. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you wish to speak to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche\xe2\x80\x99s face flushed all over. Her uncle came to the rescue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Lundie and I hope you have slept well Mr. Delamayn,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir\r\nPatrick, jocosely. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh? That\xe2\x80\x99s all?\xe2\x80\x9d said Geoffrey still looking at Blanche. \xe2\x80\x9cBeg your\r\npardon again. Deuced long walk, and deuced heavy dinner. Natural\r\nconsequence--a nap.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick eyed him closely. It was plain that he had been honestly\r\npuzzled at finding himself an object of special attention on Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npart. \xe2\x80\x9cSee you in the billiard-room?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, carelessly, and followed\r\nhis companions out of the room--as usual, without waiting for an answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMind what you are about,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick to his niece. \xe2\x80\x9cThat man is\r\nquicker than he looks. We commit a serious mistake if we put him on his\r\nguard at starting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt sha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t happen again, uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Blanche. \xe2\x80\x9cBut think of _his_\r\nbeing in Anne\xe2\x80\x99s confidence, and of _my_ being shut out of it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn his friend\xe2\x80\x99s confidence, you mean, my dear; and (if we only avoid\r\nawakening his suspicion) there is no knowing how soon he may say or do\r\nsomething which may show us who his friend is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he is going back to his brother\xe2\x80\x99s to-morrow--he said so at\r\ndinner-time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better. He will be out of the way of seeing strange things\r\nin a certain young lady\xe2\x80\x99s face. His brother\xe2\x80\x99s house is within easy reach\r\nof this; and I am his legal adviser. My experience tells me that he has\r\nnot done consulting me yet--and that he will let out something more\r\nnext time. So much for our chance of seeing the light through Mr.\r\nDelamayn--if we can\xe2\x80\x99t see it in any other way. And that is not our only\r\nchance, remember. I have something to tell you about Bishopriggs and the\r\nlost letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it found?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. I satisfied myself about that--I had it searched for, under my own\r\neye. The letter is stolen, Blanche; and Bishopriggs has got it. I have\r\nleft a line for him, in Mrs. Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s care. The old rascal is missed\r\nalready by the visitors at the inn, just as I told you he would be. His\r\nmistress is feeling the penalty of having been fool enough to vent her\r\nill temper on her head-waiter. She lays the whole blame of the quarrel\r\non Miss Silvester, of course. Bishopriggs neglected every body at\r\nthe inn to wait on Miss Silvester. Bishopriggs was insolent on being\r\nremonstrated with, and Miss Silvester encouraged him--and so on. The\r\nresult will be--now Miss Silvester has gone--that Bishopriggs will\r\nreturn to Craig Fernie before the autumn is over. We are sailing with\r\nwind and tide, my dear. Come, and learn to play whist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe rose to join the card-players. Blanche detained him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou haven\xe2\x80\x99t told me one thing yet,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhoever the man may be,\r\nis Anne married to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhoever the man may be,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Sir Patrick, \xe2\x80\x9che had better not\r\nattempt to marry any body else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo the niece unconsciously put the question, and so the uncle\r\nunconsciously gave the answer on which depended the whole happiness of\r\nBlanche\xe2\x80\x99s life to come, The \xe2\x80\x9cman!\xe2\x80\x9d How lightly they both talked of the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cman!\xe2\x80\x9d Would nothing happen to rouse the faintest suspicion--in their\r\nminds or in Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s mind--that Arnold was the \xe2\x80\x9cman\xe2\x80\x9d himself?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean that she _is_ married?\xe2\x80\x9d said Blanche.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t go as far as that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean that she is _not_ married?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t go so far as _that._\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! the law!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProvoking, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it, my dear? I can tell you, professionally, that (in\r\nmy opinion) she has grounds to go on if she claims to be the man\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\r\nThat is what I meant by my answer; and, until we know more, that is all\r\nI can say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen shall we know more? When shall we get the telegram?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot for some hours yet. Come, and learn to play whist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I would rather talk to Arnold, uncle, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy all means! But don\xe2\x80\x99t talk to him about what I have been telling you\r\nto-night. He and Mr. Delamayn are old associates, remember; and he might\r\nblunder into telling his friend what his friend had better not know. Sad\r\n(isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?) for me to be instilling these lessons of duplicity into the\r\nyouthful mind. A wise person once said, \xe2\x80\x98The older a man gets the\r\nworse he gets.\xe2\x80\x99 That wise person, my dear, had me in his eye, and was\r\nperfectly right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe mitigated the pain of that confession with a pinch of snuff, and went\r\nto the whist table to wait until the end of the rubber gave him a place\r\nat the game.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE TWENTY-FIFTH.\r\n\r\nFORWARD.\r\n\r\nBLANCHE found her lover as attentive as usual to her slightest wish, but\r\nnot in his customary good spirits. He pleaded fatigue, after his long\r\nwatch at the cross-roads, as an excuse for his depression. As long as\r\nthere was any hope of a reconciliation with Geoffrey, he was unwilling\r\nto tell Blanche what had happened that afternoon. The hope grew fainter\r\nand fainter as the evening advanced. Arnold purposely suggested a\r\nvisit to the billiard-room, and joined the game, with Blanche, to give\r\nGeoffrey an opportunity of saying the few gracious words which would\r\nhave made them friends again. Geoffrey never spoke the words; he\r\nobstinately ignored Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s presence in the room.\r\n\r\nAt the card-table the whist went on interminably. Lady Lundie, Sir\r\nPatrick, and the surgeon, were all inveterate players, evenly matched.\r\nSmith and Jones (joining the game alternately) were aids to whist,\r\nexactly as they were aids to conversation. The same safe and modest\r\nmediocrity of style distinguished the proceedings of these two gentlemen\r\nin all the affairs of life.\r\n\r\nThe time wore on to midnight. They went to bed late and they rose late\r\nat Windygates House. Under that hospitable roof, no intrusive hints, in\r\nthe shape of flat candlesticks exhibiting themselves with ostentatious\r\nvirtue on side-tables, hurried the guest to his room; no vile bell\r\nrang him ruthlessly out of bed the next morning, and insisted on his\r\nbreakfasting at a given hour. Life has surely hardships enough that\r\nare inevitable without gratuitously adding the hardship of absolute\r\ngovernment, administered by a clock?\r\n\r\nIt was a quarter past twelve when Lady Lundie rose blandly from the\r\nwhist-table, and said that she supposed somebody must set the example of\r\ngoing to bed. Sir Patrick and Smith, the surgeon and Jones, agreed on a\r\nlast rubber. Blanche vanished while her stepmother\xe2\x80\x99s eye was on her;\r\nand appeared again in the drawing-room, when Lady Lundie was safe in the\r\nhands of her maid. Nobody followed the example of the mistress of the\r\nhouse but Arnold. He left the billiard-room with the certainty that it\r\nwas all over now between Geoffrey and himself. Not even the attraction\r\nof Blanche proved strong enough to detain him that night. He went his\r\nway to bed.\r\n\r\nIt was past one o\xe2\x80\x99clock. The final rubber was at an end, the accounts\r\nwere settled at the card-table; the surgeon had strolled into the\r\nbilliard-room, and Smith and Jones had followed him, when Duncan came\r\nin, at last, with the telegram in his hand.\r\n\r\nBlanche turned from the broad, calm autumn moonlight which had drawn her\r\nto the window, and looked over her uncle\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder while he opened the\r\ntelegram.\r\n\r\nShe read the first line--and that was enough. The whole scaffolding of\r\nhope built round that morsel of paper fell to the ground in an instant.\r\nThe train from Kirkandrew had reached Edinburgh at the usual time. Every\r\npassenger in it had passed under the eyes of the police, and nothing had\r\nbeen seen of any person who answered the description given of Anne!\r\n\r\nSir Patrick pointed to the two last sentences in the telegram:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInquiries telegraphed to Falkirk. If with any result, you shall know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must hope for the best, Blanche. They evidently suspect her of\r\nhaving got out at the junction of the two railways for the purpose\r\nof giving the telegraph the slip. There is no help for it. Go to bed,\r\nchild--go to bed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche kissed her uncle in silence and went away. The bright young face\r\nwas sad with the first hopeless sorrow which the old man had yet seen in\r\nit. His niece\xe2\x80\x99s parting look dwelt painfully on his mind when he was up\r\nin his room, with the faithful Duncan getting him ready for his bed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a bad business, Duncan. I don\xe2\x80\x99t like to say so to Miss Lundie;\r\nbut I greatly fear the governess has baffled us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems likely, Sir Patrick. The poor young lady looks quite\r\nheart-broken about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou noticed that too, did you? She has lived all her life, you see,\r\nwith Miss Silvester; and there is a very strong attachment between them.\r\nI am uneasy about my niece, Duncan. I am afraid this disappointment will\r\nhave a serious effect on her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s young, Sir Patrick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my friend, she\xe2\x80\x99s young; but the young (when they are good for any\r\nthing) have warm hearts. Winter hasn\xe2\x80\x99t stolen on _them,_ Duncan! And\r\nthey feel keenly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think there\xe2\x80\x99s reason to hope, Sir, that Miss Lundie may get over it\r\nmore easily than you suppose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat reason, pray?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA person in my position can hardly venture to speak freely, Sir, on a\r\ndelicate matter of this kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s temper flashed out, half-seriously, half-whimsically, as\r\nusual.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that a snap at Me, you old dog? If I am not your friend, as well as\r\nyour master, who is? Am _I_ in the habit of keeping any of my harmless\r\nfellow-creatures at a distance? I despise the cant of modern Liberalism;\r\nbut it\xe2\x80\x99s not the less true that I have, all my life, protested against\r\nthe inhuman separation of classes in England. We are, in that respect,\r\nbrag as we may of our national virtue, the most unchristian people in\r\nthe civilized world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, Sir Patrick--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod help me! I\xe2\x80\x99m talking polities at this time of night! It\xe2\x80\x99s your\r\nfault, Duncan. What do you mean by casting my station in my teeth,\r\nbecause I can\xe2\x80\x99t put my night-cap on comfortably till you have brushed\r\nmy hair? I have a good mind to get up and brush yours. There! there! I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nuneasy about my niece--nervous irritability, my good fellow, that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\r\nLet\xe2\x80\x99s hear what you have to say about Miss Lundie. And go on with my\r\nhair. And don\xe2\x80\x99t be a humbug.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was about to remind you, Sir Patrick, that Miss Lundie has another\r\ninterest in her life to turn to. If this matter of Miss Silvester ends\r\nbadly--and I own it begins to look as if it would--I should hurry my\r\nniece\xe2\x80\x99s marriage, Sir, and see if _that_ wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t console her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick started under the gentle discipline of the hair-brush in\r\nDuncan\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s very sensibly put,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman. \xe2\x80\x9cDuncan! you are,\r\nwhat I call, a clear-minded man. Well worth thinking of, old Truepenny!\r\nIf the worst comes to the worst, well worth thinking of!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was not the first time that Duncan\xe2\x80\x99s steady good sense had struck\r\nlight, under the form of a new thought, in his master\xe2\x80\x99s mind. But never\r\nyet had he wrought such mischief as the mischief which he had innocently\r\ndone now. He had sent Sir Patrick to bed with the fatal idea of\r\nhastening the marriage of Arnold and Blanche.\r\n\r\nThe situation of affairs at Windygates--now that Anne had apparently\r\nobliterated all trace of herself--was becoming serious. The one chance\r\non which the discovery of Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s position depended, was the chance\r\nthat accident might reveal the truth in the lapse of time. In this\r\nposture of circumstances, Sir Patrick now resolved--if nothing happened\r\nto relieve Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s anxiety in the course of the week--to advance the\r\ncelebration of the marriage from the end of the autumn (as originally\r\ncontemplated) to the first fortnight of the ensuing month. As dates\r\nthen stood, the change led (so far as free scope for the development of\r\naccident was concerned) to this serious result. It abridged a lapse of\r\nthree months into an interval of three weeks.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next morning came; and Blanche marked it as a memorable morning,\r\nby committing an act of imprudence, which struck away one more of\r\nthe chances of discovery that had existed, before the arrival of the\r\nEdinburgh telegram on the previous day.\r\n\r\nShe had passed a sleepless night; fevered in mind and body; thinking,\r\nhour after hour, of nothing but Anne. At sunrise she could endure it no\r\nlonger. Her power to control herself was completely exhausted; her own\r\nimpulses led her as they pleased. She got up, determined not to let\r\nGeoffrey leave the house without risking an effort to make him reveal\r\nwhat he knew about Anne. It was nothing less than downright treason to\r\nSir Patrick to act on her own responsibility in this way. She knew it\r\nwas wrong; she was heartily ashamed of herself for doing it. But the\r\ndemon that possesses women with a recklessness all their own, at the\r\ncritical moments of their lives, had got her--and she did it.\r\n\r\nGeoffrey had arranged overnight, to breakfast early, by himself, and to\r\nwalk the ten miles to his brother\xe2\x80\x99s house; sending a servant to fetch\r\nhis luggage later in the day.\r\n\r\nHe had got on his hat; he was standing in the hall, searching his pocket\r\nfor his second self, the pipe--when Blanche suddenly appeared from the\r\nmorning-room, and placed herself between him and the house door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUp early--eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said Geoffrey. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m off to my brother\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe made no reply. He looked at her closer. The girl\xe2\x80\x99s eyes were trying\r\nto read his face, with an utter carelessness of concealment, which\r\nforbade (even to his mind) all unworthy interpretation of her motive for\r\nstopping him on his way out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny commands for me?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired\r\n\r\nThis time she answered him. \xe2\x80\x9cI have something to ask you,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nHe smiled graciously, and opened his tobacco-pouch. He was fresh and\r\nstrong after his night\xe2\x80\x99s sleep--healthy and handsome and good-humored.\r\nThe house-maids had had a peep at him that morning, and had wished--like\r\nDesdemona, with a difference--that \xe2\x80\x9cHeaven had made all three of them\r\nsuch a man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe put her question, without a single word of preface--purposely to\r\nsurprise him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Delamayn,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know where Anne Silvester is this\r\nmorning?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was filling his pipe as she spoke, and he dropped some of the tobacco\r\non the floor. Instead of answering before he picked up the tobacco he\r\nanswered after--in surly self-possession, and in one word--\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know nothing about her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe devoted himself doggedly to the filling of his pipe. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn your word of honor, as a gentleman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my word of honor, as a gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe put back his tobacco-pouch in his pocket. His handsome face was as\r\nhard as stone. His clear blue eyes defied all the girls in England put\r\ntogether to see into _his_ mind. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you done, Miss Lundie?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked,\r\nsuddenly changing to a bantering politeness of tone and manner.\r\n\r\nBlanche saw that it was hopeless--saw that she had compromised her own\r\ninterests by her own headlong act. Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s warning words came\r\nback reproachfully to her now when it was too late. \xe2\x80\x9cWe commit a serious\r\nmistake if we put him on his guard at starting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was but one course to take now. \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI have done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy turn now,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Geoffrey. \xe2\x80\x9cYou want to know where Miss Silvester\r\nis. Why do you ask Me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche did all that could be done toward repairing the error that she\r\nhad committed. She kept Geoffrey as far away as Geoffrey had kept _her_\r\nfrom the truth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI happen to know,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied \xe2\x80\x9cthat Miss Silvester left the place\r\nat which she had been staying about the time when you went out walking\r\nyesterday. And I thought you might have seen her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh? That\xe2\x80\x99s the reason--is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Geoffrey, with a smile.\r\n\r\nThe smile stung Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s sensitive temper to the quick. She made a\r\nfinal effort to control herself, before her indignation got the better\r\nof her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no more to say, Mr. Delamayn.\xe2\x80\x9d With that reply she turned her\r\nback on him, and closed the door of the morning-room between them.\r\n\r\nGeoffrey descended the house steps and lit his pipe. He was not at the\r\nslightest loss, on this occasion, to account for what had happened. He\r\nassumed at once that Arnold had taken a mean revenge on him after his\r\nconduct of the day before, and had told the whole secret of his errand\r\nat Craig Fernie to Blanche. The thing would get next, no doubt, to Sir\r\nPatrick\xe2\x80\x99s ears; and Sir Patrick would thereupon be probably the first\r\nperson who revealed to Arnold the position in which he had placed\r\nhimself with Anne. All right! Sir Patrick would be an excellent witness\r\nto appeal to, when the scandal broke out, and when the time came for\r\nrepudiating Anne\xe2\x80\x99s claim on him as the barefaced imposture of a woman\r\nwho was married already to another man. He puffed away unconcernedly at\r\nhis pipe, and started, at his swinging, steady pace, for his brother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhouse.\r\n\r\nBlanche remained alone in the morning-room. The prospect of getting at\r\nthe truth, by means of what Geoffrey might say on the next occasion when\r\nhe consulted Sir Patrick, was a prospect that she herself had closed\r\nfrom that moment. She sat down in despair by the window. It commanded a\r\nview of the little side-terrace which had been Anne\xe2\x80\x99s favorite walk at\r\nWindygates. With weary eyes and aching heart the poor child looked at\r\nthe familiar place; and asked herself, with the bitter repentance that\r\ncomes too late, if she had destroyed the last chance of finding Anne!\r\n\r\nShe sat passively at the window, while the hours of the morning wore on,\r\nuntil the postman came. Before the servant could take the letter bag she\r\nwas in the hall to receive it. Was it possible to hope that the bag had\r\nbrought tidings of Anne? She sorted the letters; and lighted suddenly\r\non a letter to herself. It bore the Kirkandrew postmark, and It was\r\naddressed to her in Anne\xe2\x80\x99s handwriting.\r\n\r\nShe tore the letter open, and read these lines:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have left you forever, Blanche. God bless and reward you! God make\r\nyou a happy woman in all your life to come! Cruel as you will think me,\r\nlove, I have never been so truly your sister as I am now. I can only\r\ntell you this--I can never tell you more. Forgive me, and forget me, our\r\nlives are parted lives from this day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nGoing down to breakfast about his usual hour, Sir Patrick missed\r\nBlanche, whom he was accustomed to see waiting for him at the table at\r\nthat time. The room was empty; the other members of the household having\r\nall finished their morning meal. Sir Patrick disliked breakfasting\r\nalone. He sent Duncan with a message, to be given to Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s maid.\r\n\r\nThe maid appeared in due time Miss Lundie was unable to leave her room.\r\nShe sent a letter to her uncle, with her love--and begged he would read\r\nit.\r\n\r\nSir Patrick opened the letter and saw what Anne had written to Blanche.\r\n\r\nHe waited a little, reflecting, with evident pain and anxiety, on what\r\nhe had read--then opened his own letters, and hurriedly looked at the\r\nsignatures. There was nothing for him from his friend, the sheriff,\r\nat Edinburgh, and no communication from the railway, in the shape of a\r\ntelegram. He had decided, overnight, on waiting till the end of the week\r\nbefore he interfered in the matter of Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s marriage. The events of\r\nthe morning determined him on not waiting another day. Duncan returned\r\nto the breakfast-room to pour out his master\xe2\x80\x99s coffee. Sir Patrick sent\r\nhim away again with a second message,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know where Lady Lundie is, Duncan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Sir Patrick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy compliments to her ladyship. If she is not otherwise engaged, I\r\nshall be glad to speak to her privately in an hour\xe2\x80\x99s time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE TWENTY-SIXTH.\r\n\r\nDROPPED.\r\n\r\nSIR PATRICK made a bad breakfast. Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s absence fretted him, and\r\nAnne Silvester\xe2\x80\x99s letter puzzled him.\r\n\r\nHe read it, short as it was, a second time, and a third. If it meant any\r\nthing, it meant that the motive at the bottom of Anne\xe2\x80\x99s flight was to\r\naccomplish the sacrifice of herself to the happiness of Blanche. She had\r\nparted for life from his niece for his niece\xe2\x80\x99s sake! What did this mean?\r\nAnd how was it to be reconciled with Anne\xe2\x80\x99s position--as described to\r\nhim by Mrs. Inchbare during his visit to Craig Fernie?\r\n\r\nAll Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s ingenuity, and all Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s experience, failed to\r\nfind so much as the shadow of an answer to that question.\r\n\r\nWhile he was still pondering over the letter, Arnold and the surgeon\r\nentered the breakfast-room together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you heard about Blanche?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Arnold, excitedly. \xe2\x80\x9cShe is in no\r\ndanger, Sir Patrick--the worst of it is over now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe surgeon interposed before Sir Patrick could appeal to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Brinkworth\xe2\x80\x99s interest in the young lady a little exaggerates the\r\nstate of the case,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI have seen her, at Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s request;\r\nand I can assure you that there is not the slightest reason for any\r\npresent alarm. Miss Lundie has had a nervous attack, which has yielded\r\nto the simplest domestic remedies. The only anxiety you need feel is\r\nconnected with the management of her in the future. She is suffering\r\nfrom some mental distress, which it is not for me, but for her friends,\r\nto alleviate and remove. If you can turn her thoughts from the painful\r\nsubject--whatever it may be--on which they are dwelling now, you will do\r\nall that needs to be done.\xe2\x80\x9d He took up a newspaper from the table, and\r\nstrolled out into the garden, leaving Sir Patrick and Arnold together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou heard that?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he right, do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Arnold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRight? Do you suppose a man gets _his_ reputation by making mistakes?\r\nYou\xe2\x80\x99re one of the new generation, Master Arnold. You can all of you\r\nstare at a famous man; but you haven\xe2\x80\x99t an atom of respect for his fame.\r\nIf Shakspeare came to life again, and talked of playwriting, the first\r\npretentious nobody who sat opposite at dinner would differ with him as\r\ncomposedly as he might differ with you and me. Veneration is dead among\r\nus; the present age has buried it, without a stone to mark the place. So\r\nmuch for that! Let\xe2\x80\x99s get back to Blanche. I suppose you can guess what\r\nthe painful subject is that\xe2\x80\x99s dwelling on her mind? Miss Silvester has\r\nbaffled me, and baffled the Edinburgh police. Blanche discovered that we\r\nhad failed last night and Blanche received that letter this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe pushed Anne\xe2\x80\x99s letter across the breakfast-table.\r\n\r\nArnold read it, and handed it back without a word. Viewed by the new\r\nlight in which he saw Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s character after the quarrel on the\r\nheath, the letter conveyed but one conclusion to his mind. Geoffrey had\r\ndeserted her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you understand what it means?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s wretchedness when she read it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe said no more than that. It was plain that no information which he\r\ncould afford--even if he had considered himself at liberty to give\r\nit--would be of the slightest use in assisting Sir Patrick to trace\r\nMiss Silvester, under present circumstances, There was--unhappily--no\r\ntemptation to induce him to break the honorable silence which he\r\nhad maintained thus far. And--more unfortunately still--assuming the\r\ntemptation to present itself, Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s capacity to resist it had never\r\nbeen so strong a capacity as it was now.\r\n\r\nTo the two powerful motives which had hitherto tied his tongue--respect\r\nfor Anne\xe2\x80\x99s reputation, and reluctance to reveal to Blanche the deception\r\nwhich he had been compelled to practice on her at the inn--to these\r\ntwo motives there was now added a third. The meanness of betraying the\r\nconfidence which Geoffrey had reposed in him would be doubled meanness\r\nif he proved false to his trust after Geoffrey had personally insulted\r\nhim. The paltry revenge which that false friend had unhesitatingly\r\nsuspected him of taking was a revenge of which Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s nature was\r\nsimply incapable. Never had his lips been more effectually sealed\r\nthan at this moment--when his whole future depended on Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndiscovering the part that he had played in past events at Craig Fernie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! yes!\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Sir Patrick, impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cBlanche\xe2\x80\x99s distress is\r\nintelligible enough. But here is my niece apparently answerable for this\r\nunhappy woman\xe2\x80\x99s disappearance. Can you explain what my niece has got to\r\ndo with it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI! Blanche herself is completely mystified. How should _I_ know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnswering in those terms, he spoke with perfect sincerity. Anne\xe2\x80\x99s vague\r\ndistrust of the position in which they had innocently placed themselves\r\nat the inn had produced no corresponding effect on Arnold at the time.\r\nHe had not regarded it; he had not even understood it. As a necessary\r\nresult, not the faintest suspicion of the motive under which Anne was\r\nacting existed in his mind now.\r\n\r\nSir Patrick put the letter into his pocket-book, and abandoned all\r\nfurther attempt at interpreting the meaning of it in despair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough, and more than enough, of groping in the dark,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cOne\r\npoint is clear to me after what has happened up stairs this morning. We\r\nmust accept the position in which Miss Silvester has placed us. I shall\r\ngive up all further effort to trace her from this moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely that will be a dreadful disappointment to Blanche, Sir Patrick?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t deny it. We must face that result.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are sure there is nothing else to be done, I suppose we must.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not sure of anything of the sort, Master Arnold! There are two\r\nchances still left of throwing light on this matter, which are both of\r\nthem independent of any thing that Miss Silvester can do to keep it in\r\nthe dark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen why not try them, Sir? It seems hard to drop Miss Silvester when\r\nshe is in trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t help her against her own will,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nwe can\xe2\x80\x99t run the risk, after that nervous attack this morning, of\r\nsubjecting Blanche to any further suspense. I have thought of my niece\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninterests throughout this business; and if I now change my mind, and\r\ndecline to agitate her by more experiments, ending (quite possibly) in\r\nmore failures, it is because I am thinking of her interests still. I\r\nhave no other motive. However numerous my weaknesses may be, ambition\r\nto distinguish myself as a detective policeman is not one of them. The\r\ncase, from the police point of view, is by no means a lost case. I\r\ndrop it, nevertheless, for Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s sake. Instead of encouraging her\r\nthoughts to dwell on this melancholy business, we must apply the remedy\r\nsuggested by our medical friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is that to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Arnold.\r\n\r\nThe sly twist of humor began to show itself in Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas she nothing to think of in the future, which is a pleasanter\r\nsubject of reflection than the loss of her friend?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are\r\ninterested, my young gentleman, in the remedy that is to cure Blanche.\r\nYou are one of the drugs in the moral prescription. Can you guess what\r\nit is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold started to his feet, and brightened into a new being.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you object to be hurried?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cObject! If Blanche will only consent, I\xe2\x80\x99ll take her to church as soon\r\nas she comes down stairs!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick, dryly. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Arnold Brinkworth, may you\r\nalways be as ready to take Time by the forelock as you are now! Sit down\r\nagain; and don\xe2\x80\x99t talk nonsense. It is just possible--if Blanche consents\r\n(as you say), and if we can hurry the lawyers--that you may be married\r\nin three weeks\xe2\x80\x99 or a month\xe2\x80\x99s time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have the lawyers got to do with it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy good fellow, this is not a marriage in a novel! This is the most\r\nunromantic affair of the sort that ever happened. Here are a young\r\ngentleman and a young lady, both rich people; both well matched in birth\r\nand character; one of age, and the other marrying with the full consent\r\nand approval of her guardian. What is the consequence of this purely\r\nprosaic state of things? Lawyers and settlements, of course!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome into the library, Sir Patrick; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll soon settle the\r\nsettlements! A bit of paper, and a dip of ink. \xe2\x80\x98I hereby give every\r\nblessed farthing I have got in the world to my dear Blanche.\xe2\x80\x99 Sign that;\r\nstick a wafer on at the side; clap your finger on the wafer; \xe2\x80\x98I deliver\r\nthis as my act and deed;\xe2\x80\x99 and there it is--done!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it, really? You are a born legislator. You create and codify your\r\nown system all in a breath. Moses-Justinian-Mahomet, give me your arm!\r\nThere is one atom of sense in what you have just said. \xe2\x80\x98Come into the\r\nlibrary\xe2\x80\x99--is a suggestion worth attending to. Do you happen, among your\r\nother superfluities, to have such a thing as a lawyer about you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have got two. One in London, and one in Edinburgh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will take the nearest of the two, because we are in a hurry. Who is\r\nthe Edinburgh lawyer? Pringle of Pitt Street? Couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be a better man.\r\nCome and write to him. You have given me your abstract of a marriage\r\nsettlement with the brevity of an ancient Roman. I scorn to be outdone\r\nby an amateur lawyer. Here is _my_ abstract: You are just and generous\r\nto Blanche; Blanche is just and generous to you; and you both combine\r\nto be just and generous together to your children. There is a model\r\nsettlement! and there are your instructions to Pringle of Pitt Street!\r\nCan you do it by yourself? No; of course you can\xe2\x80\x99t. Now don\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nslovenly-minded! See the points in their order as they come. You are\r\ngoing to be married; you state to whom, you add that I am the lady\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nguardian; you give the name and address of my lawyer in Edinburgh; you\r\nwrite your instructions plainly in the fewest words, and leave details\r\nto your legal adviser; you refer the lawyers to each other; you request\r\nthat the draft settlements be prepared as speedily as possible, and you\r\ngive your address at this house. There are the heads. Can\xe2\x80\x99t you do it\r\nnow? Oh, the rising generation! Oh, the progress we are making in these\r\nenlightened modern times! There! there! you can marry Blanche, and make\r\nher happy, and increase the population--and all without knowing how\r\nto write the English language. One can only say with the learned\r\nBevorskius, looking out of his window at the illimitable loves of the\r\nsparrows, \xe2\x80\x98How merciful is Heaven to its creatures!\xe2\x80\x99 Take up the pen.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll dictate! I\xe2\x80\x99ll dictate!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick read the letter over, approved of it, and saw it safe in the\r\nbox for the post. This done, he peremptorily forbade Arnold to speak to\r\nhis niece on the subject of the marriage without his express permission.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s somebody else\xe2\x80\x99s consent to be got,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cbesides Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconsent and mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLady Lundie?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLady Lundie. Strictly speaking, I am the only authority. But my\r\nsister-in-law is Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s step-mother, and she is appointed guardian in\r\nthe event of my death. She has a right to be consulted--in courtesy, if\r\nnot in law. Would you like to do it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s face fell. He looked at Sir Patrick in silent dismay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! you can\xe2\x80\x99t even speak to such a perfectly pliable person as Lady\r\nLundie? You may have been a very useful fellow at sea. A more helpless\r\nyoung man I never met with on shore. Get out with you into the garden\r\namong the other sparrows! Somebody must confront her ladyship. And if\r\nyou won\xe2\x80\x99t--I must.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe pushed Arnold out of the library, and applied meditatively to the\r\nknob of his cane. His gayety disappeared, now that he was alone. His\r\nexperience of Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s character told him that, in attempting to\r\nwin her approval to any scheme for hurrying Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s marriage, he was\r\nundertaking no easy task. \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose,\xe2\x80\x9d mused Sir Patrick, thinking of\r\nhis late brother--\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose poor Tom had some way of managing her. How\r\ndid he do it, I wonder? If she had been the wife of a bricklayer, she\r\nis the sort of woman who would have been kept in perfect order by a\r\nvigorous and regular application of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s fist. But Tom wasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\na bricklayer. I wonder how Tom did it?\xe2\x80\x9d After a little hard thinking on\r\nthis point Sir Patrick gave up the problem as beyond human solution. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\nmust be done,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd my own mother-wit must help me to do\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn that resigned frame of mind he knocked at the door of Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nboudoir.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE TWENTY-SEVENTH.\r\n\r\nOUTWITTED.\r\n\r\nSIR PATRICK found his sister-in-law immersed in domestic business. Her\r\nladyship\xe2\x80\x99s correspondence and visiting list, her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s household\r\nbills and ledgers; her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s Diary and Memorandum-book (bound in\r\nscarlet morocco); her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s desk, envelope-case, match-box, and\r\ntaper candlestick (all in ebony and silver); her ladyship herself,\r\npresiding over her responsibilities, and wielding her materials, equal\r\nto any calls of emergency, beautifully dressed in correct morning\r\ncostume, blessed with perfect health both of the secretions and the\r\nprinciples; absolutely void of vice, and formidably full of virtue,\r\npresented, to every properly-constituted mind, the most imposing\r\nspectacle known to humanity--the British Matron on her throne, asking\r\nthe world in general, When will you produce the like of Me?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid I disturb you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cI am a perfectly idle\r\nperson. Shall I look in a little later?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie put her hand to her head, and smiled faintly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little pressure _here,_ Sir Patrick. Pray sit down. Duty finds me\r\nearnest; Duty finds me cheerful; Duty finds me accessible. From a poor,\r\nweak woman, Duty must expect no more. Now what is it?\xe2\x80\x9d (Her ladyship\r\nconsulted her scarlet memorandum-book.) \xe2\x80\x9cI have got it here, under\r\nits proper head, distinguished by initial letters. P.--the poor.\r\nNo. H.M.--heathen missions. No. V.T.A.--Visitors to arrive. No. P. I.\r\nP.--Here it is: private interview with Patrick. Will you forgive me the\r\nlittle harmless familiarity of omitting your title? Thank you! You are\r\nalways so good. I am quite at your service when you like to begin. If\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s any thing painful, pray don\xe2\x80\x99t hesitate. I am quite prepared.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that intimation her ladyship threw herself back in her chair, with\r\nher elbows on the arms, and her fingers joined at the tips, as if\r\nshe was receiving a deputation. \xe2\x80\x9cYes?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, interrogatively. Sir\r\nPatrick paid a private tribute of pity to his late brother\xe2\x80\x99s memory, and\r\nentered on his business.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe won\xe2\x80\x99t call it a painful matter,\xe2\x80\x9d he began. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us say it\xe2\x80\x99s a matter\r\nof domestic anxiety. Blanche--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie emitted a faint scream, and put her hand over her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Must_ you?\xe2\x80\x9d cried her ladyship, in a tone of touching remonstrance.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Sir Patrick, _must_ you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. I must.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s magnificent eyes looked up at that hidden court of human\r\nappeal which is lodged in the ceiling. The hidden court looked down at\r\nLady Lundie, and saw--Duty advertising itself in the largest capital\r\nletters.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, Sir Patrick. The motto of woman is Self-sacrifice. You sha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsee how you distress me. Go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick went on impenetrably--without betraying the slightest\r\nexpression of sympathy or surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was about to refer to the nervous attack from which Blanche has\r\nsuffered this morning,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cMay I ask whether you have been\r\ninformed of the cause to which the attack is attributable?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Lady Lundie with a sudden bound in her chair, and a\r\nsudden development of vocal power to correspond. \xe2\x80\x9cThe one thing I shrank\r\nfrom speaking of! the cruel, cruel, cruel behavior I was prepared to\r\npass over! And Sir Patrick hints on it! Innocently--don\xe2\x80\x99t let me do an\r\ninjustice--innocently hints on it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHints on what, my dear Madam?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlanche\xe2\x80\x99s conduct to me this morning. Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s heartless secrecy.\r\nBlanche\xe2\x80\x99s undutiful silence. I repeat the words: Heartless secrecy.\r\nUndutiful silence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me for one moment, Lady Lundie--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow _me,_ Sir Patrick! Heaven knows how unwilling I am to speak of\r\nit. Heaven knows that not a word of reference to it escaped _my_ lips.\r\nBut you leave me no choice now. As mistress of the household, as a\r\nChristian woman, as the widow of your dear brother, as a mother to this\r\nmisguided girl, I must state the facts. I know you mean well; I know you\r\nwish to spare me. Quite useless! I must state the facts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick bowed, and submitted. (If he had only been a bricklayer! and\r\nif Lady Lundie had not been, what her ladyship unquestionably was, the\r\nstrongest person of the two!)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPermit me to draw a veil, for your sake,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Lundie, \xe2\x80\x9cover the\r\nhorrors--I can not, with the best wish to spare you, conscientiously\r\ncall them by any other name--the horrors that took place up stairs. The\r\nmoment I heard that Blanche was ill I was at my post. Duty will always\r\nfind me ready, Sir Patrick, to my dying day. Shocking as the whole thing\r\nwas, I presided calmly over the screams and sobs of my step-daughter.\r\nI closed my ears to the profane violence of her language. I set\r\nthe necessary example, as an English gentlewoman at the head of her\r\nhousehold. It was only when I distinctly heard the name of a person,\r\nnever to be mentioned again in my family circle, issue (if I may use\r\nthe expression) from Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s lips that I began to be really alarmed. I\r\nsaid to my maid: \xe2\x80\x98Hopkins, this is not Hysteria. This is a possession of\r\nthe devil. Fetch the chloroform.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nChloroform, applied in the capacity of an exorcism, was entirely new to\r\nSir Patrick. He preserved his gravity with considerable difficulty. Lady\r\nLundie went on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHopkins is an excellent person--but Hopkins has a tongue. She met our\r\ndistinguished medical guest in the corridor, and told him. He was so\r\ngood as to come to the door. I was shocked to trouble him to act in his\r\nprofessional capacity while he was a visitor, an honored visitor, in my\r\nhouse. Besides, I considered it more a case for a clergyman than for a\r\nmedical man. However, there was no help for it after Hopkins\xe2\x80\x99s tongue.\r\nI requested our eminent friend to favor us with--I think the exact\r\nscientific term is--a Prognosis. He took the purely material view\r\nwhich was only to be expected from a person in his profession. He\r\nprognosed--_am_ I right? Did he prognose? or did he diagnose? A habit of\r\nspeaking correctly is _so_ important, Sir Patrick! and I should be _so_\r\ngrieved to mislead you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind, Lady Lundie! I have heard the medical report. Don\xe2\x80\x99t trouble\r\nyourself to repeat it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t trouble myself to repeat it?\xe2\x80\x9d echoed Lady Lundie--with her\r\ndignity up in arms at the bare prospect of finding her remarks abridged.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Sir Patrick! that little constitutional impatience of yours!--Oh,\r\ndear me! how often you must have given way to it, and how often you must\r\nhave regretted it, in your time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear lady! if you wish to repeat the report, why not say so, in\r\nplain words? Don\xe2\x80\x99t let me hurry you. Let us have the prognosis, by all\r\nmeans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie shook her head compassionately, and smiled with angelic\r\nsadness. \xe2\x80\x9cOur little besetting sins!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat slaves we are to\r\nour little besetting sins! Take a turn in the room--do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAny ordinary man would have lost his temper. But the law (as Sir Patrick\r\nhad told his niece) has a special temper of its own. Without\r\nexhibiting the smallest irritation, Sir Patrick dextrously applied his\r\nsister-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s blister to his sister-in-law herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat an eye you have!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI was impatient. I _am_ impatient. I\r\nam dying to know what Blanche said to you when she got better?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe British Matron froze up into a matron of stone on the spot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing!\xe2\x80\x9d answered her ladyship, with a vicious snap of her teeth, as\r\nif she had tried to bite the word before it escaped her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Sir Patrick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Lady Lundie, with her most formidable emphasis of\r\nlook and tone. \xe2\x80\x9cI applied all the remedies with my own hands; I cut her\r\nlaces with my own scissors, I completely wetted her head through with\r\ncold water; I remained with her until she was quite exhausted--I took\r\nher in my arms, and folded her to my bosom; I sent every body out of the\r\nroom; I said, \xe2\x80\x98Dear child, confide in me.\xe2\x80\x99 And how were my advances--my\r\nmotherly advances--met? I have already told you. By heartless secrecy.\r\nBy undutiful silence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick pressed the blister a little closer to the skin. \xe2\x80\x9cShe was\r\nprobably afraid to speak,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfraid? Oh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Lady Lundie, distrusting the evidence of her own\r\nsenses. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t have said that? I have evidently misapprehended you.\r\nYou didn\xe2\x80\x99t really say, afraid?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said she was probably afraid--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop! I can\xe2\x80\x99t be told to my face that I have failed to do my duty by\r\nBlanche. No, Sir Patrick! I can bear a great deal; but I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear\r\nthat. After having been more than a mother to your dear brother\xe2\x80\x99s child;\r\nafter having been an elder sister to Blanche; after having toiled--I say\r\n_toiled,_ Sir Patrick!--to cultivate her intelligence (with the sweet\r\nlines of the poet ever present to my memory: \xe2\x80\x98Delightful task to rear\r\nthe tender mind, and teach the young idea how to shoot!\xe2\x80\x99); after having\r\ndone all I have done--a place in the carriage only yesterday, and a\r\nvisit to the most interesting relic of feudal times in Perthshire--after\r\nhaving sacrificed all I have sacrificed, to be told that I have behaved\r\nin such a manner to Blanche as to frighten her when I ask her to confide\r\nin me, is a little too cruel. I have a sensitive--an unduly sensitive\r\nnature, dear Sir Patrick. Forgive me for wincing when I am wounded.\r\nForgive me for feeling it when the wound is dealt me by a person whom I\r\nrevere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer ladyship put her handkerchief to her eyes. Any other man would have\r\ntaken off the blister. Sir Patrick pressed it harder than ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou quite mistake me,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied. \xe2\x80\x9cI meant that Blanche was afraid to\r\ntell you the true cause of her illness. The true cause is anxiety about\r\nMiss Silvester.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie emitted another scream--a loud scream this time--and closed\r\nher eyes in horror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can run out of the house,\xe2\x80\x9d cried her ladyship, wildly. \xe2\x80\x9cI can fly to\r\nthe uttermost corners of the earth; but I can _not_ hear that person\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nname mentioned! No, Sir Patrick! not in my presence! not in my room!\r\nnot while I am mistress at Windygates House!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry to say any thing that is disagreeable to you, Lady Lundie.\r\nBut the nature of my errand here obliges me to touch--as lightly as\r\npossible--on something which has happened in your house without your\r\nknowledge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie suddenly opened her eyes, and became the picture of\r\nattention. A casual observer might have supposed her ladyship to be not\r\nwholly inaccessible to the vulgar emotion of curiosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA visitor came to Windygates yesterday, while we were all at lunch,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n proceeded Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cShe--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie seized the scarlet memorandum-book, and stopped her\r\nbrother-in-law, before he could get any further. Her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s next\r\nwords escaped her lips spasmodically, like words let at intervals out of\r\na trap.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI undertake--as a woman accustomed to self-restraint, Sir Patrick--I\r\nundertake to control myself, on one condition. I won\xe2\x80\x99t have the name\r\nmentioned. I won\xe2\x80\x99t have the sex mentioned. Say, \xe2\x80\x98The Person,\xe2\x80\x99 if\r\nyou please. \xe2\x80\x98The Person,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d continued Lady Lundie, opening her\r\nmemorandum-book and taking up her pen, \xe2\x80\x9ccommitted an audacious invasion\r\nof my premises yesterday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick bowed. Her ladyship made a note--a fiercely-penned note\r\nthat scratched the paper viciously--and then proceeded to examine her\r\nbrother-in-law, in the capacity of witness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat part of my house did \xe2\x80\x98The Person\xe2\x80\x99 invade? Be very careful, Sir\r\nPatrick! I propose to place myself under the protection of a justice of\r\nthe peace; and this is a memorandum of my statement. The library--did I\r\nunderstand you to say? Just so--the library.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdd,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick, with another pressure on the blister, \xe2\x80\x9cthat The\r\nPerson had an interview with Blanche in the library.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s pen suddenly stuck in the paper, and scattered a little\r\nshower of ink-drops all round it. \xe2\x80\x9cThe library,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated her ladyship,\r\nin a voice suggestive of approaching suffocation. \xe2\x80\x9cI undertake to\r\ncontrol myself, Sir Patrick! Any thing missing from the library?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing missing, Lady Lundie, but The Person herself. She--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Sir Patrick! I won\xe2\x80\x99t have it! In the name of my own sex, I won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhave it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray pardon me--I forgot that \xe2\x80\x98she\xe2\x80\x99 was a prohibited pronoun on the\r\npresent occasion. The Person has written a farewell letter to Blanche,\r\nand has gone nobody knows where. The distress produced by these events\r\nis alone answerable for what has happened to Blanche this morning. If\r\nyou bear that in mind--and if you remember what your own opinion is of\r\nMiss Silvester--you will understand why Blanche hesitated to admit you\r\ninto her confidence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere he waited for a reply. Lady Lundie was too deeply absorbed in\r\ncompleting her memorandum to be conscious of his presence in the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Carriage to be at the door at two-thirty,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Lundie,\r\nrepeating the final words of the memorandum while she wrote them.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Inquire for the nearest justice of the peace, and place the privacy\r\nof Windygates under the protection of the law.\xe2\x80\x99--I beg your pardon!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n exclaimed her ladyship, becoming conscious again of Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npresence. \xe2\x80\x9cHave I missed any thing particularly painful? Pray mention it\r\nif I have!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have missed nothing of the slightest importance,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Sir\r\nPatrick. \xe2\x80\x9cI have placed you in possession of facts which you had a right\r\nto know; and we have now only to return to our medical friend\xe2\x80\x99s report\r\non Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s health. You were about to favor me, I think, with the\r\nPrognosis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDiagnosis!\xe2\x80\x9d said her ladyship, spitefully. \xe2\x80\x9cI had forgotten at the\r\ntime--I remember now. Prognosis is entirely wrong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI sit corrected, Lady Lundie. Diagnosis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have informed me, Sir Patrick, that you were already acquainted\r\nwith the Diagnosis. It is quite needless for me to repeat it now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was anxious to correct my own impression, my dear lady, by comparing\r\nit with yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very good. You are a learned man. I am only a poor ignorant\r\nwoman. Your impression can not possibly require correcting by mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy impression, Lady Lundie, was that our so friend recommended moral,\r\nrather than medical, treatment for Blanche. If we can turn her thoughts\r\nfrom the painful subject on which they are now dwelling, we shall do all\r\nthat is needful. Those were his own words, as I remember them. Do you\r\nconfirm me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan _I_ presume to dispute with you, Sir Patrick? You are a master of\r\nrefined irony, I know. I am afraid it\xe2\x80\x99s all thrown away on poor me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n(The law kept its wonderful temper! The law met the most exasperating of\r\nliving women with a counter-power of defensive aggravation all its own!)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI take that as confirming me, Lady Lundie. Thank you. Now, as to the\r\nmethod of carrying out our friend\xe2\x80\x99s advice. The method seems plain. All\r\nwe can do to divert Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s mind is to turn Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s attention to\r\nsome other subject of reflection less painful than the subject which\r\noccupies her now. Do you agree, so far?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy place the whole responsibility on my shoulders?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Lady\r\nLundie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOut of profound deference for your opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Sir Patrick.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrictly speaking, no doubt, any serious responsibility rests with me.\r\nI am Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s guardian--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Lady Lundie, with a perfect explosion of pious\r\nfervor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hear an outburst of devout thankfulness,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cAm\r\nI to take it as expressing--let me say--some little doubt, on your\r\npart, as to the prospect of managing Blanche successfully, under present\r\ncircumstances?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s temper began to give way again--exactly as her\r\nbrother-in-law had anticipated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are to take it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cas expressing my conviction that I\r\nsaddled myself with the charge of an incorrigibly heartless, obstinate\r\nand perverse girl, when I undertook the care of Blanche.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you say \xe2\x80\x98incorrigibly?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said \xe2\x80\x98incorrigibly.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf the case is as hopeless as that, my dear Madam--as Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nguardian, I ought to find means to relieve you of the charge of\r\nBlanche.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNobody shall relieve _me_ of a duty that I have once undertaken!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n retorted Lady Lundie. \xe2\x80\x9cNot if I die at my post!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose it was consistent with your duty,\xe2\x80\x9d pleaded Sir Patrick, \xe2\x80\x9cto\r\nbe relieved at your post? Suppose it was in harmony with that\r\n\xe2\x80\x98self-sacrifice\xe2\x80\x99 which is \xe2\x80\x98the motto of women?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand you, Sir Patrick. Be so good as to explain\r\nyourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick assumed a new character--the character of a hesitating man.\r\nHe cast a look of respectful inquiry at his sister-in-law, sighed, and\r\nshook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt would be asking too much. Even with your high\r\nstandard of duty, it would be asking too much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing which you can ask me in the name of duty is too much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! no! Let me remind you. Human nature has its limits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Christian gentlewoman\xe2\x80\x99s sense of duty knows no limits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, surely yes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Patrick! after what I have just said your perseverance in doubting\r\nme amounts to something like an insult!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t say that! Let me put a case. Let\xe2\x80\x99s suppose the future interests\r\nof another person depend on your saying, Yes--when all your own most\r\ncherished ideas and opinions urge you to say, No. Do you really mean to\r\ntell me that you could trample your own convictions under foot, if\r\nit could be shown that the purely abstract consideration of duty was\r\ninvolved in the sacrifice?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Lady Lundie, mounting the pedestal of her virtue on the\r\nspot. \xe2\x80\x9cYes--without a moment\xe2\x80\x99s hesitation!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI sit corrected, Lady Lundie. You embolden me to proceed. Allow me to\r\nask (after what I just heard)--whether it is not your duty to act\r\non advice given for Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s benefit, by one the highest medical\r\nauthorities in England?\xe2\x80\x9d Her ladyship admitted that it was her\r\nduty; pending a more favorable opportunity for contradicting her\r\nbrother-in-law.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cAssuming that Blanche is like most\r\nother human beings, and has some prospect of happiness to contemplate,\r\nif she could only be made to see it--are we not bound to make her see\r\nit, by our moral obligation to act on the medical advice?\xe2\x80\x9d He cast a\r\ncourteously-persuasive look at her ladyship, and paused in the most\r\ninnocent manner for a reply.\r\n\r\nIf Lady Lundie had not been bent--thanks to the irritation fomented by\r\nher brother-in-law--on disputing the ground with him, inch by inch, she\r\nmust have seen signs, by this time, of the snare that was being set\r\nfor her. As it was, she saw nothing but the opportunity of disparaging\r\nBlanche and contradicting Sir Patrick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf my step-daughter had any such prospect as you describe,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n she answered, \xe2\x80\x9cI should of course say, Yes. But Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s is an\r\nill-regulated mind. An ill-regulated mind has no prospect of happiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cBlanche _has_ a prospect of happiness.\r\nIn other words, Blanche has a prospect of being married. And what is\r\nmore, Arnold Brinkworth is ready to marry her as soon as the settlements\r\ncan be prepared.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie started in her chair--turned crimson with rage--and opened\r\nher lips to speak. Sir Patrick rose to his feet, and went on before she\r\ncould utter a word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg to relieve you, Lady Lundie--by means which you have just\r\nacknowledged it to be your duty to accept--of all further charge of an\r\nincorrigible girl. As Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s guardian, I have the honor of proposing\r\nthat her marriage be advanced to a day to be hereafter named in the\r\nfirst fortnight of the ensuing month.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn those words he closed the trap which he had set for his\r\nsister-in-law, and waited to see what came of it.\r\n\r\nA thoroughly spiteful woman, thoroughly roused, is capable of\r\nsubordinating every other consideration to the one imperative necessity\r\nof gratifying her spite. There was but one way now of turning the tables\r\non Sir Patrick--and Lady Lundie took it. She hated him, at that moment,\r\nso intensely, that not even the assertion of her own obstinate will\r\npromised her more than a tame satisfaction, by comparison with the\r\npriceless enjoyment of beating her brother-in-law with his own weapons.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Sir Patrick!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with a little silvery laugh, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have\r\nwasted much precious time and many eloquent words in trying to entrap\r\nme into giving my consent, when you might have had it for the asking.\r\nI think the idea of hastening Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s marriage an excellent one. I am\r\ncharmed to transfer the charge of such a person as my step-daughter to\r\nthe unfortunate young man who is willing to take her off my hands. The\r\nless he sees of Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s character the more satisfied I shall feel of\r\nhis performing his engagement to marry her. Pray hurry the lawyers, Sir\r\nPatrick, and let it be a week sooner rather than a week later, if you\r\nwish to please Me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer ladyship rose in her grandest proportions, and made a courtesy\r\nwhich was nothing less than a triumph of polite satire in dumb show. Sir\r\nPatrick answered by a profound bow and a smile which said, eloquently,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe every word of that charming answer. Admirable woman--adieu!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo the one person in the family circle, whose opposition might have\r\nforced Sir Patrick to submit to a timely delay, was silenced by adroit\r\nmanagement of the vices of her own character. So, in despite of herself,\r\nLady Lundie was won over to the project for hurrying the marriage of\r\nArnold and Blanche.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE TWENTY-EIGHTH.\r\n\r\nSTIFLED.\r\n\r\nIT is the nature of Truth to struggle to the light. In more than one\r\ndirection, the truth strove to pierce the overlying darkness, and to\r\nreveal itself to view, during the interval between the date of Sir\r\nPatrick\xe2\x80\x99s victory and the date of the wedding-day.\r\n\r\nSigns of perturbation under the surface, suggestive of some hidden\r\ninfluence at work, were not wanting, as the time passed on. The one\r\nthing missing was the prophetic faculty that could read those signs\r\naright at Windygates House.\r\n\r\nOn the very day when Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s dextrous treatment of his\r\nsister-in-law had smoothed the way to the hastening of the marriage,\r\nan obstacle was raised to the new arrangement by no less a person than\r\nBlanche herself. She had sufficiently recovered, toward noon, to be able\r\nto receive Arnold in her own little sitting-room. It proved to be a very\r\nbrief interview. A quarter of an hour later, Arnold appeared before Sir\r\nPatrick--while the old gentleman was sunning himself in the garden--with\r\na face of blank despair. Blanche had indignantly declined even to think\r\nof such a thing as her marriage, at a time when she was heart-broken by\r\nthe discovery that Anne had left her forever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou gave me leave to mention it, Sir Patrick--didn\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold.\r\n\r\nSir Patrick shifted round a little, so as to get the sun on his back,\r\nand admitted that he had given leave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I had only known, I would rather have cut my tongue out than have\r\nsaid a word about it. What do you think she did? She burst out crying,\r\nand ordered me to leave the room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was a lovely morning--a cool breeze tempered the heat of the sun; the\r\nbirds were singing; the garden wore its brightest look. Sir Patrick was\r\nsupremely comfortable. The little wearisome vexations of this mortal\r\nlife had retired to a respectful distance from him. He positively\r\ndeclined to invite them to come any nearer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is a world,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old gentleman, getting the sun a little more\r\nbroadly on his back, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich a merciful Creator has filled with lovely\r\nsights, harmonious sounds, delicious scents; and here are creatures\r\nwith faculties expressly made for enjoyment of those sights, sounds, and\r\nscents--to say nothing of Love, Dinner, and Sleep, all thrown into the\r\nbargain. And these same creatures hate, starve, toss sleepless on their\r\npillows, see nothing pleasant, hear nothing pleasant, smell nothing\r\npleasant--cry bitter tears, say hard words, contract painful illnesses;\r\nwither, sink, age, die! What does it mean, Arnold? And how much longer\r\nis it all to go on?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe fine connecting link between the blindness of Blanche to the\r\nadvantage of being married, and the blindness of humanity to the\r\nadvantage of being in existence, though sufficiently perceptible no\r\ndoubt to venerable Philosophy ripening in the sun, was absolutely\r\ninvisible to Arnold. He deliberately dropped the vast question opened by\r\nSir Patrick; and, reverting to Blanche, asked what was to be done.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you do with a fire, when you can\xe2\x80\x99t extinguish it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir\r\nPatrick. \xe2\x80\x9cYou let it blaze till it goes out. What do you do with a woman\r\nwhen you can\xe2\x80\x99t pacify her? Let _her_ blaze till she goes out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold failed to see the wisdom embodied in that excellent advice. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nthought you would have helped me to put things right with Blanche,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI _am_ helping you. Let Blanche alone. Don\xe2\x80\x99t speak of the marriage\r\nagain, the next time you see her. If she mentions it, beg her pardon,\r\nand tell her you won\xe2\x80\x99t press the question any more. I shall see her in\r\nan hour or two, and I shall take exactly the same tone myself. You have\r\nput the idea into her mind--leave it there to ripen. Give her distress\r\nabout Miss Silvester nothing to feed on. Don\xe2\x80\x99t stimulate it by\r\ncontradiction; don\xe2\x80\x99t rouse it to defend itself by disparagement of her\r\nlost friend. Leave Time to edge her gently nearer and nearer to the\r\nhusband who is waiting for her--and take my word for it, Time will have\r\nher ready when the settlements are ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nToward the luncheon hour Sir Patrick saw Blanche, and put in practice\r\nthe principle which he had laid down.
