The inquiries made for\r\nhim, at Anne\xe2\x80\x99s request, as soon as she arrived in the town, openly\r\ndescribed his name, and his former position as headwaiter at Craig\r\nFernie--and thu s led easily to the discovery of him, in his publicly\r\navowed character of Thomas Pennyquick\xe2\x80\x99s devoted friend. Toward\r\nevening, on the day after she reached Perth, the news came to Anne that\r\nBishopriggs was in service at the inn known as the Harp of Scotland.\r\nThe landlord of the hotel at which she was staying inquired whether he\r\nshould send a message for her. She answered, \xe2\x80\x9cNo, I will take my message\r\nmyself. All I want is a person to show me the way to the inn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSecluded in the solitude of the head-waiter\xe2\x80\x99s pantry, Bishopriggs sat\r\npeacefully melting the sugar in his whisky-punch.\r\n\r\nIt was the hour of the evening at which a period of tranquillity\r\ngenerally occurred before what was called \xe2\x80\x9cthe night-business\xe2\x80\x9d of the\r\nhouse began. Bishopriggs was accustomed to drink and meditate daily in\r\nthis interval of repose. He tasted the punch, and smiled contentedly as\r\nhe set down his glass. The prospect before him looked fairly enough. He\r\nhad outwitted the lawyers in the preliminary negotiations thus far. All\r\nthat was needful now was to wait till the terror of a public scandal\r\n(sustained by occasional letters from her \xe2\x80\x9cFriend in the Dark\xe2\x80\x9d) had\r\nits due effect on Mrs. Glenarm, and hurried her into paying the\r\npurchase-money for the correspondence with her own hand. \xe2\x80\x9cLet it breed\r\nin the brain,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cand the siller will soon come out o\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\npurse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis reflections were interrupted by the appearance of a slovenly\r\nmaid-servant, with a cotton handkerchief tied round her head, and an\r\nuncleaned sauce-pan in her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, Maister Bishopriggs,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the girl, \xe2\x80\x9chere\xe2\x80\x99s a braw young leddy\r\nspeerin\xe2\x80\x99 for ye by yer ain name at the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA leddy?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Bishopriggs, with a look of virtuous disgust. \xe2\x80\x9cYe\r\ndonnert ne\xe2\x80\x99er-do-weel, do you come to a decent, \xe2\x80\x98sponsible man like me,\r\nwi\xe2\x80\x99 sic a Cyprian overture as that? What d\xe2\x80\x99ye tak\xe2\x80\x99 me for? Mark Antony\r\nthat lost the world for love (the mair fule he!)? or Don Jovanny that\r\ncounted his concubines by hundreds, like the blessed Solomon himself?\r\nAwa\xe2\x80\x99 wi\xe2\x80\x99 ye to yer pots and pans; and bid the wandering Venus that sent\r\nye go spin!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBefore the girl could answer she was gently pulled aside from the\r\ndoorway, and Bishopriggs, thunder-struck, saw Anne Silvester standing in\r\nher place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had better tell the servant I am no stranger to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anne,\r\nlooking toward the kitchen-maid, who stood in the passage staring at her\r\nin stolid amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy ain sister\xe2\x80\x99s child!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bishopriggs, lying with his customary\r\nreadiness. \xe2\x80\x9cGo yer ways, Maggie. The bonny lassie\xe2\x80\x99s my ain kith and kin.\r\nThe tongue o\xe2\x80\x99 scandal, I trow, has naething to say against that.--Lord\r\nsave us and guide us!\xe2\x80\x9d he added In another tone, as the girl closed the\r\ndoor on them, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat brings ye here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have something to say to you. I am not very well; I must wait a\r\nlittle first. Give me a chair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBishopriggs obeyed in silence. His one available eye rested on Anne,\r\nas he produced the chair, with an uneasy and suspicious attention. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nwanting to know one thing,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cBy what meeraiculous means, young\r\nmadam, do ye happen to ha\xe2\x80\x99 fund yer way to this inn?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne told him how her inquiries had been made and what the result had\r\nbeen, plainly and frankly. The clouded face of Bishopriggs began to\r\nclear again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHech! hech!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, recovering all his native impudence, \xe2\x80\x9cI hae\r\nhad occasion to remark already, to anither leddy than yersel\xe2\x80\x99, that it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nseemply mairvelous hoo a man\xe2\x80\x99s ain gude deeds find him oot in this lower\r\nwarld o\xe2\x80\x99 ours. I hae dune a gude deed by pure Tammy Pennyquick, and\r\nhere\xe2\x80\x99s a\xe2\x80\x99 Pairth ringing wi the report o\xe2\x80\x99 it; and Sawmuel Bishopriggs\r\nsae weel known that ony stranger has only to ask, and find him.\r\nUnderstand, I beseech ye, that it\xe2\x80\x99s no hand o\xe2\x80\x99 mine that pets this new\r\nfeather in my cap. As a gude Calvinist, my saul\xe2\x80\x99s clear o\xe2\x80\x99 the smallest\r\nfigment o\xe2\x80\x99 belief in Warks. When I look at my ain celeebrity I joost\r\nask, as the Psawmist asked before me, \xe2\x80\x98Why do the heathen rage, and the\r\npeople imagine a vain thing?\xe2\x80\x99 It seems ye\xe2\x80\x99ve something to say to me,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nadded, suddenly reverting to the object of Anne\xe2\x80\x99s visit. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it humanly\r\npossible that ye can ha\xe2\x80\x99 come a\xe2\x80\x99 the way to Pairth for naething but\r\nthat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe expression of suspicion began to show itself again in his face.\r\nConcealing as she best might the disgust that he inspired in her, Anne\r\nstated her errand in the most direct manner, and in the fewest possible\r\nwords.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have come here to ask you for something,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy? ay? What may it be ye\xe2\x80\x99re wanting of me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want the letter I lost at Craig Fernie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEven the solidly-founded self-possession of Bishopriggs himself was\r\nshaken by the startling directness of that attack on it. His glib tongue\r\nwas paralyzed for the moment. \xe2\x80\x9cI dinna ken what ye\xe2\x80\x99re drivin\xe2\x80\x99 at,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, after an interval, with a sullen consciousness that he had been\r\nall but tricked into betraying himself.\r\n\r\nThe change in his manner convinced Anne that she had found in\r\nBishopriggs the person of whom she was in search.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have got my letter,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, sternly insisting on the truth. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nyou are trying to turn it to a disgraceful use. I won\xe2\x80\x99t allow you to\r\nmake a market of my private affairs. You have offered a letter of mine\r\nfor sale to a stranger. I insist on your restoring it to me before I\r\nleave this room!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBishopriggs hesitated again. His first suspicion that Anne had been\r\nprivately instructed by Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s lawyers returned to his mind as\r\na suspicion confirmed. He felt the vast importance of making a cautious\r\nreply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll no\xe2\x80\x99 waste precious time,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s consideration\r\nwith himself, \xe2\x80\x9cin brushing awa\xe2\x80\x99 the fawse breath o\xe2\x80\x99 scandal, when it\r\npasses my way. It blaws to nae purpose, my young leddy, when it blaws on\r\nan honest man like me. Fie for shame on ye for saying what ye\xe2\x80\x99ve joost\r\nsaid--to me that was a fether to ye at Craig Fernie! Wha\xe2\x80\x99 set ye on to\r\nit? Will it be man or woman that\xe2\x80\x99s misca\xe2\x80\x99ed me behind my back?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne took the Glasgow newspaper from the pocket of her traveling cloak,\r\nand placed it before him, open at the paragraph which described the act\r\nof extortion attempted on Mrs. Glenarm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have found there,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9call that I want to know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay a\xe2\x80\x99 the tribe o\xe2\x80\x99 editors, preenters, paper-makers, news-vendors,\r\nand the like, bleeze together in the pit o\xe2\x80\x99 Tophet!\xe2\x80\x9d With this devout\r\naspiration--internally felt, not openly uttered--Bishopriggs put on his\r\nspectacles, and read the passage pointed out to him. \xe2\x80\x9cI see naething\r\nhere touching the name o\xe2\x80\x99 Sawmuel Bishopriggs, or the matter o\xe2\x80\x99 ony loss\r\nye may or may not ha\xe2\x80\x99 had at Craig Fernie,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, when he had done;\r\nstill defending his position, with a resolution worthy of a better\r\ncause.\r\n\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s pride recoiled at the prospect of prolonging the discussion with\r\nhim. She rose to her feet, and said her last words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have learned enough by this time,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, \xe2\x80\x9cto know that the\r\none argument that prevails with you is the argument of money. If money\r\nwill spare me the hateful necessity of disputing with you--poor as I\r\nam, money you shall have. Be silent, if you please. You are personally\r\ninterested in what I have to say next.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe opened her purse, and took a five-pound note from it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you choose to own the truth, and produce the letter,\xe2\x80\x9d she resumed,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will give you this, as your reward for finding, and restoring to me,\r\nsomething that I had lost. If you persist in your present prevarication,\r\nI can, and will, make that sheet of note-paper you have stolen from me\r\nnothing but waste paper in your hands. You have threatened Mrs. Glenarm\r\nwith my interference. Suppose I go to Mrs. Glenarm? Suppose I interfere\r\nbefore the week is out? Suppose I have other letters of Mr. Delamayn\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nin my possession, and produce them to speak for me? What has Mrs.\r\nGlenarm to purchase of you _then?_ Answer me that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe color rose on her pale face. Her eyes, dim and weary when\r\nshe entered the room, looked him brightly through and through in\r\nimmeasurable contempt. \xe2\x80\x9cAnswer me that!\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated, with a burst\r\nof her old energy which revealed the fire and passion of the woman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnature, not quenched even yet!\r\n\r\nIf Bishopriggs had a merit, it was a rare merit, as men go, of\r\nknowing when he was beaten. If he had an accomplishment, it was the\r\naccomplishment of retiring defeated, with all the honors of war.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMercy presairve us!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, in the most innocent manner. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it\r\neven You Yersel\xe2\x80\x99 that writ the letter to the man ca\xe2\x80\x99ed Jaffray Delamayn,\r\nand got the wee bit answer in pencil on the blank page? Hoo, in Heeven\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nname, was I to know _that_ was the letter ye were after when ye cam\xe2\x80\x99 in\r\nhere? Did ye ever tell me ye were Anne Silvester, at the hottle? Never\r\nance! Was the puir feckless husband-creature ye had wi\xe2\x80\x99 ye at the inn,\r\nJaffray Delamayn? Jaffray wad mak\xe2\x80\x99 twa o\xe2\x80\x99 him, as my ain eyes ha\xe2\x80\x99 seen.\r\nGi\xe2\x80\x99 ye back yer letter? My certie! noo I know it is yer letter, I\xe2\x80\x99ll gi\xe2\x80\x99\r\nit back wi\xe2\x80\x99 a\xe2\x80\x99 the pleasure in life!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe opened his pocket-book, and took it out, with an alacrity worthy of\r\nthe honestest man in Christendom--and (more wonderful still) he looked\r\nwith a perfectly assumed expression of indifference at the five-pound\r\nnote in Anne\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoot! toot!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m no\xe2\x80\x99 that clear in my mind that I\xe2\x80\x99m free to\r\ntak\xe2\x80\x99 yer money. Eh, weel! weel! I\xe2\x80\x99ll een receive it, if ye like, as a\r\nbit Memento o\xe2\x80\x99 the time when I was o\xe2\x80\x99 some sma\xe2\x80\x99 sairvice to ye at the\r\nhottle. Ye\xe2\x80\x99ll no\xe2\x80\x99 mind,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, suddenly returning to business,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwritin\xe2\x80\x99 me joost a line--in the way o\xe2\x80\x99 receipt, ye ken--to clear me o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nony future suspicion in the matter o\xe2\x80\x99 the letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne threw down the bank-note on the table near which they were\r\nstanding, and snatched the letter from him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou need no receipt,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. \xe2\x80\x9cThere shall be no letter to bear\r\nwitness against you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe lifted her other hand to tear it in pieces. Bishopriggs caught her\r\nby both wrists, at the same moment, and held her fast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBide a wee!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYe don\xe2\x80\x99t get the letter, young madam, without\r\nthe receipt. It may be a\xe2\x80\x99 the same to _you,_ now ye\xe2\x80\x99ve married the other\r\nman, whether Jaffray Delamayn ance promised ye fair in the by-gone time,\r\nor no. But, my certie! it\xe2\x80\x99s a matter o\xe2\x80\x99 some moment to _me,_ that ye\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nchairged wi\xe2\x80\x99 stealin\xe2\x80\x99 the letter, and making a market o\xe2\x80\x99t, and Lord\r\nknows what besides, that I suld hae yer ain acknowledgment for it in\r\nblack and white. Gi\xe2\x80\x99 me my bit receipt--and een do as ye will with yer\r\nletter after that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s hold of the letter relaxed. She let Bishopriggs repossess himself\r\nof it as it dropped on the floor between them, without making an effort\r\nto prevent him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be a\xe2\x80\x99 the same to _you,_ now ye\xe2\x80\x99ve married the other man,\r\nwhether Jaffray Delamayn ance promised ye fair in the by-gone time,\r\nor no.\xe2\x80\x9d Those words presented Anne\xe2\x80\x99s position before her in a light in\r\nwhich she had not seen it yet. She had truly expressed the loathing that\r\nGeoffrey now inspired in her, when she had declared, in her letter to\r\nArnold, that, even if he offered her marriage, in atonement for the\r\npast, she would rather be what she was than be his wife. It had never\r\noccurred to her, until this moment, that others would misinterpret the\r\nsensitive pride which had prompted the abandonment of her claim on the\r\nman who had ruined her. It had never been brought home to her until now,\r\nthat if she left him contemptuously to go his own way, and sell himself\r\nto the first woman who had money enough to buy him, her conduct would\r\nsanction the false conclusion that she was powerless to interfere,\r\nbecause she was married already to another man. The color that had risen\r\nin her face vanished, and left it deadly pale again. She began to see\r\nthat the purpose of her journey to the north was not completed yet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will give you your receipt,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cTell me what to write, and it\r\nshall be written.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBishopriggs dictated the receipt. She wrote and signed it. He put it in\r\nhis pocket-book with the five-pound note, and handed her the letter in\r\nexchange.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTear it if ye will,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt matters naething to _me._\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor a moment she hesitated. A sudden shuddering shook her from head to\r\nfoot--the forewarning, it might be, of the influence which that letter,\r\nsaved from destruction by a hair\xe2\x80\x99s-breadth, was destined to exercise on\r\nher life to come. She recovered herself, and folded her cloak closer to\r\nher, as if she had felt a passing chill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cI will keep the letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe folded it and put it in the pocket of her dress. Then turned to\r\ngo--and stopped at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne thing more,\xe2\x80\x9d she added. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s present\r\naddress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe\xe2\x80\x99re no\xe2\x80\x99 reely going to Mistress Glenarm?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is no concern of yours. You can answer my question or not, as you\r\nplease.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, my leddy! yer temper\xe2\x80\x99s no\xe2\x80\x99 what it used to be in the auld times at\r\nthe hottle. Aweel! aweel! ye ha\xe2\x80\x99 gi\xe2\x80\x99en me yer money, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll een gi\xe2\x80\x99\r\nye back gude measure for it, on my side. Mistress Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s awa\xe2\x80\x99 in\r\nprivate--incog, as they say--to Jaffray Delamayn\xe2\x80\x99s brither at Swanhaven\r\nLodge. Ye may rely on the information, and it\xe2\x80\x99s no\xe2\x80\x99 that easy to come\r\nat either. They\xe2\x80\x99ve keepit it a secret as they think from a\xe2\x80\x99 the warld.\r\nHech! hech! Tammy Pennyquick\xe2\x80\x99s youngest but twa is page-boy at the hoose\r\nwhere the leddy\xe2\x80\x99s been veesitin\xe2\x80\x99, on the outskirts o\xe2\x80\x99 Pairth. Keep a\r\nsecret if ye can frae the pawky ears o\xe2\x80\x99 yer domestics in the servants\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhall!--Eh! she\xe2\x80\x99s aff, without a word at parting!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, as Anne\r\nleft him without ceremony in the middle of his dissertation on secrets\r\nand servants\xe2\x80\x99 halls. \xe2\x80\x9cI trow I ha\xe2\x80\x99 gaen out for wool, and come back\r\nshorn,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, reflecting grimly on the disastrous overthrow of the\r\npromising speculation on which he had embarked. \xe2\x80\x9cMy certie! there was\r\nnaething left for\xe2\x80\x99t, when madam\xe2\x80\x99s fingers had grippit me, but to slip\r\nthrough them as cannily as I could. What\xe2\x80\x99s Jaffray\xe2\x80\x99s marrying, or no\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmarrying, to do wi\xe2\x80\x99 _her?_\xe2\x80\x9d he wondered, reverting to the question which\r\nAnne had put to him at parting. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd whar\xe2\x80\x99s the sense o\xe2\x80\x99 her errand, if\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99s reely bent on finding her way to Mistress Glenarm?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhatever the sense of her errand might be, Anne\xe2\x80\x99s next proceeding proved\r\nthat she was really bent on it. After resting two days, she left Perth\r\nby the first train in the morning, for Swanhaven Lodge.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNINTH SCENE.--THE MUSIC-ROOM.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE FORTIETH.\r\n\r\nJULIUS MAKES MISCHIEF.\r\n\r\nJULIUS DELAMAYN was alone, idly sauntering to and fro, with his violin\r\nin his hand, on the terrace at Swanhaven Lodge.\r\n\r\nThe first mellow light of evening was in the sky. It was the close of\r\nthe day on which Anne Silvester had left Perth.\r\n\r\nSome hours earlier, Julius had sacrificed himself to the duties of his\r\npolitical position--as made for him by his father. He had submitted to\r\nthe dire necessity of delivering an oration to the electors, at a public\r\nmeeting in the neighboring town of Kirkandrew. A detestable atmosphere\r\nto breathe; a disorderly audience to address; insolent opposition to\r\nconciliate; imbecile inquiries to answer; brutish interruptions to\r\nendure; greedy petitioners to pacify; and dirty hands to shake: these\r\nare the stages by which the aspiring English gentleman is compelled\r\nto travel on the journey which leads him from the modest obscurity of\r\nprivate life to the glorious publicity of the House of Commons. Julius\r\npaid the preliminary penalties of a political first appearance, as\r\nexacted by free institutions, with the necessary patience; and returned\r\nto the welcome shelter of home, more indifferent, if possible, to the\r\nattractions of Parliamentary distinction than when he set out. The\r\ndiscord of the roaring \xe2\x80\x9cpeople\xe2\x80\x9d (still echoing in his ears) had\r\nsharpened his customary sensibility to the poetry of sound, as composed\r\nby Mozart, and as interpreted by piano and violin. Possessing himself of\r\nhis beloved instrument, he had gone out on the terrace to cool himself\r\nin the evening air, pending the arrival of the servant whom he had\r\nsummoned by the music-room bell. The man appeared at the glass door\r\nwhich led into the room; and reported, in answer to his master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninquiry, that Mrs. Julius Delamayn was out paying visits, and was not\r\nexpected to return for another hour at least.\r\n\r\nJulius groaned in spirit. The finest music which Mozart has written for\r\nthe violin associates that instrument with the piano. Without the wife\r\nto help him, the husband was mute. After an instant\xe2\x80\x99s consideration,\r\nJulius hit on an idea which promised, in some degree, to remedy the\r\ndisaster of Mrs. Delamayn\xe2\x80\x99s absence from home.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas Mrs. Glenarm gone out, too?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy compliments. If Mrs. Glenarm has nothing else to do, will she be so\r\nkind as to come to me in the music-room?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe servant went away with his message. Julius seated himself on one of\r\nthe terrace-benches, and began to tune his violin.\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm--rightly reported by Bishopriggs as having privately\r\ntaken refuge from her anonymous correspondent at Swanhaven Lodge--was,\r\nmusically speaking, far from being an efficient substitute for Mrs.\r\nDelamayn. Julius possessed, in his wife, one of the few players on\r\nthe piano-forte under whose subtle touch that shallow and soulless\r\ninstrument becomes inspired with expression not its own, and produces\r\nmusic instead of noise. The fine organization which can work this\r\nmiracle had not been bestowed on Mrs. Glenarm. She had been carefully\r\ntaught; and she was to be trusted to play correctly--and that was all.\r\nJulius, hungry for music, and reigned to circumstances, asked for no\r\nmore.\r\n\r\nThe servant returned with his answer. Mrs. Glenarm would join Mr.\r\nDelamayn in the music-room in ten minutes\xe2\x80\x99 time.\r\n\r\nJulius rose, relieved, and resumed his sauntering walk; now playing\r\nlittle snatches of music, now stopping to look at the flowers on the\r\nterrace, with an eye that enjoyed their beauty, and a hand that fondled\r\nthem with caressing touch. If Imperial Parliament had seen him at that\r\nmoment, Imperial Parliament must have given notice of a question to\r\nhis illustrious father: Is it possible, my lord, that _you_ can have\r\nbegotten such a Member as this?\r\n\r\nAfter stopping for a moment to tighten one of the strings of his violin,\r\nJulius, raising his head from the instrument, was surprised to see\r\na lady approaching him on the terrace. Advancing to meet her, and\r\nperceiving that she was a total stranger to him, he assumed that she\r\nwas, in all probability, a visitor to his wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave I the honor of speaking to a friend of Mrs. Delamayn\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy wife is not at home, I am sorry to say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a stranger to Mrs. Delamayn,\xe2\x80\x9d the lady answered. \xe2\x80\x9cThe servant\r\ninformed me that she had gone out; and that I should find Mr. Delamayn\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJulius bowed--and waited to hear more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must beg you to forgive my intrusion,\xe2\x80\x9d the stranger went on. \xe2\x80\x9cMy\r\nobject is to ask permission to see a lady who is, I have been informed,\r\na guest in your house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe extraordinary formality of the request rather puzzled Julius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean Mrs. Glenarm?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray don\xe2\x80\x99t think any permission necessary. A friend of Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmay take her welcome for granted in this house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not a friend of Mrs. Glenarm. I am a total stranger to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis made the ceremonious request preferred by the lady a little more\r\nintelligible--but it left the lady\xe2\x80\x99s object in wishing to speak to Mrs.\r\nGlenarm still in the dark. Julius politely waited, until it pleased her\r\nto proceed further, and explain herself The explanation did not appear\r\nto be an easy one to give. Her eyes dropped to the ground. She hesitated\r\npainfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy name--if I mention it,\xe2\x80\x9d she resumed, without looking up, \xe2\x80\x9cmay\r\npossibly inform you--\xe2\x80\x9d She paused. Her color came and went. She\r\nhesitated again; struggled with her agitation, and controlled it. \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nAnne Silvester,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, suddenly raising her pale face, and suddenly\r\nsteadying her trembling voice.\r\n\r\nJulius started, and looked at her in silent surprise.\r\n\r\nThe name was doubly known to him. Not long since, he had heard it from\r\nhis father\xe2\x80\x99s lips, at his father\xe2\x80\x99s bedside. Lord Holchester had charged\r\nhim, had earnestly charged him, to bear that name in mind, and to help\r\nthe woman who bore it, if the woman ever applied to him in time to come.\r\nAgain, he had heard the name, more lately, associated scandalously with\r\nthe name of his brother. On the receipt of the first of the anonymous\r\nletters sent to her, Mrs. Glenarm had not only summoned Geoffrey himself\r\nto refute the aspersion cast upon him, but had forwarded a private copy\r\nof the letter to his relatives at Swanhaven. Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s defense had not\r\nentirely satisfied Julius that his brother was free from blame. As\r\nhe now looked at Anne Silvester, the doubt returned upon him\r\nstrengthened--almost confirmed. Was this woman--so modest, so gentle, so\r\nsimply and unaffectedly refined--the shameless adventuress denounced\r\nby Geoffrey, as claiming him on the strength of a foolish flirtation;\r\nknowing herself, at the time, to be privately married to another man?\r\nWas this woman--with the voice of a lady, the look of a lady, the manner\r\nof a lady--in league (as Geoffrey had declared) with the illiterate\r\nvagabond who was attempting to extort money anonymously from Mrs.\r\nGlenarm? Impossible! Making every allowance for the proverbial\r\ndeceitfulness of appearances, impossible!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour name has been mentioned to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Julius, answering her after\r\na momentary pause. His instincts, as a gentleman, made him shrink from\r\nreferring to the association of her name with the name of his brother.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father mentioned you,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, considerately explaining his\r\nknowledge of her in _that_ way, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen I last saw him in London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour father!\xe2\x80\x9d She came a step nearer, with a look of distrust as\r\nwell as a look of astonishment in her face. \xe2\x80\x9cYour father is Lord\r\nHolchester--is he not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat made him speak of _me?_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was ill at the time,\xe2\x80\x9d Julius answered. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd he had been thinking of\r\nevents in his past life with which I am entirely unacquainted. He said\r\nhe had known your father and mother. He desired me, if you were ever in\r\nwant of any assistance, to place my services at your disposal. When he\r\nexpressed that wish, he spoke very earnestly--he gave me the impression\r\nthat there was a feeling of regret associated with the recollections on\r\nwhich he had been dwelling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSlowly, and in silence, Anne drew back to the low wall of the terrace\r\nclose by. She rested one hand on it to support herself. Julius had said\r\nwords of terrible import without a suspicion of what he had done. Never\r\nuntil now had Anne Silvester known that the man who had betrayed her was\r\nthe son of that other man whose discovery of the flaw in the marriage\r\nhad ended in the betrayal of her mother before her. She felt the shock\r\nof the revelation with a chill of superstitious dread. Was the chain of\r\na fatality wound invisibly round her? Turn which way she might was she\r\nstill going darkly on, in the track of her dead mother, to an appointed\r\nand hereditary doom? Present things passed from her view as the awful\r\ndoubt cast its shadow over her mind. She lived again for a moment in\r\nthe time when she was a child. She saw the face of her mother once more,\r\nwith the wan despair on it of the bygone days when the title of wife was\r\ndenied her, and the social prospect was closed forever.\r\n\r\nJulius approached, and roused her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan I get you any thing?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are looking very ill. I hope I\r\nhave said nothing to distress you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe question failed to attract her attention. She put a question herself\r\ninstead of answering it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you say you were quite ignorant of what your father was thinking of\r\nwhen he spoke to you about me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite ignorant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs your brother likely to know more about it than you do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe paused, absorbed once more in her own thoughts. Startled, on the\r\nmemorable day when they had first met, by Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s family name, she\r\nhad put the question to him whether there had not been some acquaintance\r\nbetween their parents in the past time. Deceiving her in all else,\r\nhe had not deceived in this. He had spoken in good faith, when he had\r\ndeclared that he had never heard her father or her mother mentioned at\r\nhome.\r\n\r\nThe curiosity of Julius was aroused. He attempted to lead her on into\r\nsaying more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou appear to know what my father was thinking of when he spoke to me,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n he resumed. \xe2\x80\x9cMay I ask--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe interrupted him with a gesture of entreaty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray don\xe2\x80\x99t ask! It\xe2\x80\x99s past and over--it can have no interest for you--it\r\nhas nothing to do with my errand here. I must return,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on,\r\nhurriedly, \xe2\x80\x9cto my object in trespassing on your kindness. Have you heard\r\nme mentioned, Mr. Delamayn, by another member of your family besides\r\nyour father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJulius had not anticipated that sh e would approach, of her own accord,\r\nthe painful subject on which he had himself forborne to touch. He was a\r\nlittle disappointed. He had expected more delicacy of feeling from her\r\nthan she had shown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it necessary,\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, coldly, \xe2\x80\x9cto enter on that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe blood rose again in Anne\xe2\x80\x99s cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it had not been necessary,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you think I could have\r\nforced myself to mention it to _you?_ Let me remind you that I am here\r\non sufferance. If I don\xe2\x80\x99t speak plainly (no matter at what sacrifice\r\nto my own feelings), I make my situation more embarrassing than it is\r\nalready. I have something to tell Mrs. Glenarm relating to the anonymous\r\nletters which she has lately received. And I have a word to say to her,\r\nnext, about her contemplated marriage. Before you allow me to do this,\r\nyou ought to know who I am. (I have owned it.) You ought to have heard\r\nthe worst that can be said of my conduct. (Your face tells me you have\r\nheard the worst.) After the forbearance you have shown to me, as a\r\nperfect stranger, I will not commit the meanness of taking you by\r\nsurprise. Perhaps, Mr. Delamayn, you understand, _now,_ why I felt\r\nmyself obliged to refer to your brother. Will you trust me with\r\npermission to speak to Mrs. Glenarm?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was simply and modestly said--with an unaffected and touching\r\nresignation of look and manner. Julius gave her back the respect and the\r\nsympathy which, for a moment, he had unjustly withheld from her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have placed a confidence in me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said \xe2\x80\x9cwhich most persons in\r\nyour situation would have withheld. I feel bound, in return to place\r\nconfidence in you. I will take it for granted that your motive in\r\nthis matter is one which it is my duty to respect. It will be for Mrs.\r\nGlenarm to say whether she wishes the interview to take place or not.\r\nAll that I can do is to leave you free to propose it to her. You _are_\r\nfree.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he spoke the sound of the piano reached them from the music-room.\r\nJulius pointed to the glass door which opened on to the terrace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have only to go in by that door,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand you will find Mrs.\r\nGlenarm alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne bowed, and left him. Arrived at the short flight of steps which led\r\nup to the door, she paused to collect her thoughts before she went in.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA sudden reluctance to go on and enter the room took possession of\r\nher, as she waited with her foot on the lower step. The report of Mrs.\r\nGlenarm\xe2\x80\x99s contemplated marriage had produced no such effect on her as\r\nSir Patrick had supposed: it had found no love for Geoffrey left to\r\nwound, no latent jealousy only waiting to be inflamed. Her object in\r\ntaking the journey to Perth was completed when her correspondence with\r\nGeoffrey was in her own hands again. The change of purpose which\r\nhad brought her to Swanhaven was due entirely to the new view of her\r\nposition toward Mrs. Glenarm which the coarse commonsense of Bishopriggs\r\nhad first suggested to her. If she failed to protest against Mrs.\r\nGlenarm\xe2\x80\x99s marriage, in the interests of the reparation which Geoffrey\r\nowed to her, her conduct would only confirm Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s audacious\r\nassertion that she was a married woman already. For her own sake\r\nshe might still have hesitated to move in the matter. But Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninterests were concerned as well as her own; and, for Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s sake,\r\nshe had resolved on making the journey to Swanhaven Lodge.\r\n\r\nAt the same time, feeling toward Geoffrey as she felt now--conscious as\r\nshe was of not really desiring the reparation on which she was about\r\nto insist--it was essential to the preservation of her own self-respect\r\nthat she should have some purpose in view which could justify her to her\r\nown conscience in assuming the character of Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s rival.\r\n\r\nShe had only to call to mind the critical situation of Blanche--and to\r\nsee her purpose before her plainly. Assuming that she could open the\r\ncoming interview by peaceably proving that her claim on Geoffrey was\r\nbeyond dispute, she might then, without fear of misconception, take the\r\ntone of a friend instead of an enemy, and might, with the best grace,\r\nassure Mrs. Glenarm that she had no rivalry to dread, on the one easy\r\ncondition that she engaged to make Geoffrey repair the evil that he had\r\ndone. \xe2\x80\x9cMarry him without a word against it to dread from _me_--so long\r\nas he unsays the words and undoes the deeds which have thrown a doubt\r\non the marriage of Arnold and Blanche.\xe2\x80\x9d If she could but bring the\r\ninterview to this end--there was the way found of extricating Arnold, by\r\nher own exertions, from the false position in which she had innocently\r\nplaced him toward his wife! Such was the object before her, as she now\r\nstood on the brink of her interview with Mrs. Glenarm.\r\n\r\nUp to this moment, she had firmly believed in her capacity to realize\r\nher own visionary project. It was only when she had her foot on the step\r\nthat a doubt of the success of the coming experiment crossed her mind.\r\nFor the first time, she saw the weak point in her own reasoning. For\r\nthe first time, she felt how much she had blindly taken for granted, in\r\nassuming that Mrs. Glenarm would have sufficient sense of justice and\r\nsufficient command of temper to hear her patiently. All her hopes of\r\nsuccess rested on her own favorable estimate of a woman who was a total\r\nstranger to her! What if the first words exchanged between them proved\r\nthe estimate to be wrong?\r\n\r\nIt was too late to pause and reconsider the position. Julius Delamayn\r\nhad noticed her hesitation, and was advancing toward her from the end\r\nof the terrace. There was no help for it but to master her own\r\nirresolution, and to run the risk boldly. \xe2\x80\x9cCome what may, I have gone\r\ntoo far to stop _here._\xe2\x80\x9d With that desperate resolution to animate her,\r\nshe opened the glass door at the top of the steps, and went into the\r\nroom.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm rose from the piano. The two women--one so richly, the\r\nother so plainly dressed; one with her beauty in its full bloom, the\r\nother worn and blighted; one with society at her feet, the other an\r\noutcast living under the bleak shadow of reproach--the two women stood\r\nface to face, and exchanged the cold courtesies of salute between\r\nstrangers, in silence.\r\n\r\nThe first to meet the trivial necessities of the situation was Mrs.\r\nGlenarm. She good-humoredly put an end to the embarrassment--which the\r\nshy visitor appeared to feel acutely--by speaking first.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid the servants have not told you?\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Delamayn\r\nhas gone out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon--I have not called to see Mrs. Delamayn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm looked a little surprised. She went on, however, as amiably\r\nas before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Delamayn, perhaps?\xe2\x80\x9d she suggested. \xe2\x80\x9cI expect him here every\r\nmoment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne explained again. \xe2\x80\x9cI have just parted from Mr. Delamayn.\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs.\r\nGlenarm opened her eyes in astonishment. Anne proceeded. \xe2\x80\x9cI have come\r\nhere, if you will excuse the intrusion--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe hesitated--at a loss how to end the sentence. Mrs. Glenarm,\r\nbeginning by this time to feel a strong curiosity as to what might be\r\ncoming next, advanced to the rescue once more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray don\xe2\x80\x99t apologize,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think I understand that you are\r\nso good as to have come to see _me._ You look tired. Won\xe2\x80\x99t you take a\r\nchair?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne could stand no longer. She took the offered chair. Mrs. Glenarm\r\nresumed her place on the music-stool, and ran her fingers idly over the\r\nkeys of the piano. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere did you see Mr. Delamayn?\xe2\x80\x9d she went on. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nmost irresponsible of men, except when he has got his fiddle in his\r\nhand! Is he coming in soon? Are we going to have any music? Have you\r\ncome to play with us? Mr. Delamayn is a perfect fanatic in music, isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhe? Why isn\xe2\x80\x99t he here to introduce us? I suppose you like the classical\r\nstyle, too? Did you know that I was in the music-room? Might I ask your\r\nname?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrivolous as they were, Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s questions were not without their\r\nuse. They gave Anne time to summon her resolution, and to feel the\r\nnecessity of explaining herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am speaking, I believe, to Mrs. Glenarm?\xe2\x80\x9d she began.\r\n\r\nThe good-humored widow smiled and bowed graciously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have come here, Mrs. Glenarm--by Mr. Delamayn\xe2\x80\x99s permission--to ask\r\nleave to speak to you on a matter in which you are interested.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s many-ringed fingers paused over the keys of the piano.\r\nMrs. Gle narm\xe2\x80\x99s plump face turned on the stranger with a dawning\r\nexpression of surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed? I am interested in so many matters. May I ask what _this_\r\nmatter is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe flippant tone of the speaker jarred on Anne. If Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnature was as shallow as it appeared to be on the surface, there was\r\nlittle hope of any sympathy establishing itself between them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wished to speak to you,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, \xe2\x80\x9cabout something that happened\r\nwhile you were paying a visit in the neighborhood of Perth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe dawning surprise in Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s face became intensified into\r\nan expression of distrust. Her hearty manner vanished under a veil\r\nof conventional civility, drawn over it suddenly. She looked at Anne.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever at the best of times a beauty,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought. \xe2\x80\x9cWretchedly out of\r\nhealth now. Dressed like a servant, and looking like a lady. What _does_\r\nit mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe last doubt was not to be borne in silence by a person of Mrs.\r\nGlenarm\xe2\x80\x99s temperament. She addressed herself to the solution of it with\r\nthe most unblushing directness--dextrously excused by the most winning\r\nfrankness of manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cMy memory for faces is a bad one; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthink you heard me just now, when I asked for your name. Have we ever\r\nmet before?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet--if I understand what you are referring to--you wish to speak\r\nto me about something which is only interesting to myself and my most\r\nintimate friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou understand me quite correctly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anne. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish to speak to you\r\nabout some anonymous letters--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the third time, will you permit me to ask for your name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall hear it directly--if you will first allow me to finish what\r\nI wanted to say. I wish--if I can--to persuade you that I come here as a\r\nfriend, before I mention my name. You will, I am sure, not be very sorry\r\nto hear that you need dread no further annoyance--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me once more,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Glenarm, interposing for the second\r\ntime. \xe2\x80\x9cI am at a loss to know to what I am to attribute this kind\r\ninterest in my affairs on the part of a total stranger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis time, her tone was more than politely cold--it was politely\r\nimpertinent. Mrs. Glenarm had lived all her life in good society, and\r\nwas a perfect mistress of the subtleties of refined insolence in her\r\nintercourse with those who incurred her displeasure.\r\n\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s sensitive nature felt the wound--but Anne\xe2\x80\x99s patient courage\r\nsubmitted. She put away from her the insolence which had tried to sting,\r\nand went on, gently and firmly, as if nothing had happened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe person who wrote to you anonymously,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9calluded to a\r\ncorrespondence. He is no longer in possession of it. The correspondence\r\nhas passed into hands which may be trusted to respect it. It will be put\r\nto no base use in the future--I answer for that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou answer for that?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mrs. Glenarm. She suddenly leaned\r\nforward over the piano, and fixed her eyes in unconcealed scrutiny on\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s face. The violent temper, so often found in combination with the\r\nweak nature, began to show itself in her rising color, and her lowering\r\nbrow. \xe2\x80\x9cHow do _you_ know what the person wrote?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked. \xe2\x80\x9cHow do\r\n_you_ know that the correspondence has passed into other hands? Who are\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d Before Anne could answer her, she sprang to her feet, electrified\r\nby a new idea. \xe2\x80\x9cThe man who wrote to me spoke of something else besides\r\na correspondence. He spoke of a woman. I have found you out!\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nexclaimed, with a burst of jealous fury. \xe2\x80\x9c_You_ are the woman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne rose on her side, still in firm possession of her self-control.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Glenarm,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, calmly, \xe2\x80\x9cI warn--no, I entreat you--not to\r\ntake that tone with me. Compose yourself; and I promise to satisfy you\r\nthat you are more interested than you are willing to believe in what I\r\nhave still to say. Pray bear with me for a little longer. I admit that\r\nyou have guessed right. I own that I am the miserable woman who has been\r\nruined and deserted by Geoffrey Delamayn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s false!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mrs. Glenarm. \xe2\x80\x9cYou wretch! Do you come to _me_ with\r\nyour trumped-up story? What does Julius Delamayn mean by exposing me\r\nto this?\xe2\x80\x9d Her indignation at finding herself in the same room with Anne\r\nbroke its way through, not the restraints only, but the common decencies\r\nof politeness. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll ring for the servants!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have you\r\nturned out of the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe tried to cross the fire-place to ring the bell. Anne, who was\r\nstanding nearest to it, stepped forward at the same moment. Without\r\nsaying a word, she motioned with her hand to the other woman to stand\r\nback. There was a pause. The two waited, with their eyes steadily fixed\r\non one another--each with her resolution laid bare to the other\xe2\x80\x99s view.\r\nIn a moment more, the finer nature prevailed. Mrs. Glenarm drew back a\r\nstep in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen to you?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mrs. Glenarm. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have no right to be in this\r\nhouse. You have no right to force yourself in here. Leave the room!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s patience--so firmly and admirably preserved thus far--began to\r\nfail her at last.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care, Mrs. Glenarm!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, still struggling with herself.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not naturally a patient woman. Trouble has done much to tame my\r\ntemper--but endurance has its limits. You have reached the limits of\r\nmine. I have a claim to be heard--and after what you have said to me, I\r\n_will_ be heard!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have no claim! You shameless woman, you are married already. I know\r\nthe man\xe2\x80\x99s name. Arnold Brinkworth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid Geoffrey Delamayn tell you that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI decline to answer a woman who speaks of Mr. Geoffrey Delamayn in that\r\nfamiliar way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne advanced a step nearer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid Geoffrey Delamayn tell you that?\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated.\r\n\r\nThere was a light in her eyes, there was a ring in her voice, which\r\nshowed that she was roused at last. Mrs. Glenarm answered her, this\r\ntime.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe did tell me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe lied!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe did _not!_ He knew. I believe _him._ I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe _you._\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he told you that I was any thing but a single woman--if he told\r\nyou that Arnold Brinkworth was married to any body but Miss Lundie of\r\nWindygates--I say again he lied!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say again--I believe _him,_ and not you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou believe I am Arnold Brinkworth\xe2\x80\x99s wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am certain of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou tell me that to my face?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you to your face--you may have been Geoffrey Delamayn\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmistress; you are Arnold Brinkworth\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt those words the long restrained anger leaped up in Anne--all the more\r\nhotly for having been hitherto so steadily controlled. In one breathless\r\nmoment the whirlwind of her indignation swept away, not only all\r\nremembrance of the purpose which had brought her to Swanhaven, but\r\nall sense even of the unpardonable wrong which she had suffered at\r\nGeoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s hands. If he had been there, at that moment, and had offered\r\nto redeem his pledge, she would have consented to marry him, while Mrs.\r\nGlenarm s eye was on her--no matter whether she destroyed herself in her\r\nfirst cool moment afterward or not. The small sting had planted itself\r\nat last in the great nature. The noblest woman is only a woman, after\r\nall!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI forbid your marriage to Geoffrey Delamayn! I insist on his performing\r\nthe promise he gave me, to make me his wife! I have got it here in his\r\nown words, in his own writing. On his soul, he swears it to me--he will\r\nredeem his pledge. His mistress, did you say? His wife, Mrs. Glenarm,\r\nbefore the week is out!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn those wild words she cast back the taunt--with the letter held in\r\ntriumph in her hand.\r\n\r\nDaunted for the moment by the doubt now literally forced on her, that\r\nAnne might really have the claim on Geoffrey which she advanced, Mrs.\r\nGlenarm answered nevertheless with the obstinacy of a woman brought to\r\nbay--with a resolution not to be convinced by conviction itself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t give him up!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried. \xe2\x80\x9cYour letter is a forgery. You have\r\nno proof. I won\xe2\x80\x99t, I won\xe2\x80\x99t, I won\xe2\x80\x99t give him up!\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated, with the\r\nimpotent iteration of an angry child.\r\n\r\nAnne pointed disdainfully to the letter that she held. \xe2\x80\x9cHere is his\r\npledged and written word,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhile I live, you will never be\r\nhis wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be his wife the day after the race. I am going to him in\r\nLondon--to warn him against You!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will find me in London, before you--with this in my hand. Do you\r\nknow his writing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe held up the letter, open. Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s hand flew out with the\r\nstealthy rapidity of a cat\xe2\x80\x99s paw, to seize and destroy it. Quick as she\r\nwas, her rival was quicker still. For an instant they faced each other\r\nbreathless--one with the letter held behind her; one with her hand still\r\nstretched out.\r\n\r\nAt the same moment--before a word more had passed between them--the\r\nglass door opened; and Julius Delamayn appeared in the room.\r\n\r\nHe addressed himself to Anne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe decided, on the terrace,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, quietly, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you should speak\r\nto Mrs. Glenarm, if Mrs. Glenarm wished it. Do you think it desirable\r\nthat the interview should be continued any longer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s head drooped on her breast. The fiery anger in her was quenched\r\nin an instant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been cruelly provoked, Mr. Delamayn,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I have\r\nno right to plead that.\xe2\x80\x9d She looked up at him for a moment. The hot\r\ntears of shame gathered in her eyes, and fell slowly over her cheeks.\r\nShe bent her head again, and hid them from him. \xe2\x80\x9cThe only atonement I\r\ncan make,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cis to ask your pardon, and to leave the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn silence, she turned away to the door. In silence, Julius Delamayn\r\npaid her the trifling courtesy of opening it for her. She went out.\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s indignation--suspended for the moment--transferred itself\r\nto Julius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I have been entrapped into seeing that woman, with your approval,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n she said, haughtily, \xe2\x80\x9cI owe it to myself, Mr. Delamayn, to follow her\r\nexample, and to leave your house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI authorized her to ask you for an interview, Mrs. Glenarm. If she has\r\npresumed on the permission that I gave her, I sincerely regret it, and I\r\nbeg you to accept my apologies. At the same time, I may venture to add,\r\nin defense of my conduct, that I thought her--and think her still--a\r\nwoman to be pitied more than to be blamed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be pitied did you say?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mrs. Glenarm, doubtful whether her\r\nears had not deceived her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be pitied,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Julius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_You_ may find it convenient, Mr. Delamayn, to forget what your brother\r\nhas told us about that person. _I_ happen to remember it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo do I, Mrs. Glenarm. But, with my experience of Geoffrey--\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nhesitated, and ran his fingers nervously over the strings of his violin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t believe him?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Glenarm.\r\n\r\nJulius declined to admit that he doubted his brother\xe2\x80\x99s word, to the lady\r\nwho was about to become his brother\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t quite go that length,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI find it difficult to\r\nreconcile what Geoffrey has told us, with Miss Silvester\xe2\x80\x99s manner and\r\nappearance--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer appearance!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mrs. Glenarm, in a transport of astonishment and\r\ndisgust. \xe2\x80\x9c_Her_ appearance! Oh, the men! I beg your pardon--I ought to\r\nhave remembered that there is no accounting for tastes. Go on--pray go\r\non!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we compose ourselves with a little music?\xe2\x80\x9d suggested Julius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI particularly request you will go on,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mrs. Glenarm,\r\nemphatically. \xe2\x80\x9cYou find it \xe2\x80\x98impossible to reconcile\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said \xe2\x80\x98difficult.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, very well. Difficult to reconcile what Geoffrey told us, with Miss\r\nSilvester\xe2\x80\x99s manner and appearance. What next? You had something else to\r\nsay, when I was so rude as to interrupt you. What was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Julius. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t find it easy to understand Sir\r\nPatrick Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s conduct in permitting Mr. Brinkworth to commit bigamy\r\nwith his niece.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a minute! The marriage of that horrible woman to Mr. Brinkworth\r\nwas a private marriage. Of course, Sir Patrick knew nothing about it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJulius owned that this might be possible, and made a second attempt to\r\nlead the angry lady back to the piano. Useless, once more! Though she\r\nshrank from confessing it to herself, Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s belief in the\r\ngenuineness of her lover\xe2\x80\x99s defense had been shaken. The tone taken by\r\nJulius--moderate as it was--revived the first startling suspicion of the\r\ncredibility of Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s statement which Anne\xe2\x80\x99s language and conduct\r\nhad forced on Mrs. Glenarm. She dropped into the nearest chair, and\r\nput her handkerchief to her eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cYou always hated poor Geoffrey,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nsaid, with a burst of tears. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd now you\xe2\x80\x99re defaming him to me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJulius managed her admirably. On the point of answering her seriously,\r\nhe checked himself. \xe2\x80\x9cI always hated poor Geoffrey,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, with\r\na smile. \xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to be the last person to say that, Mrs. Glenarm!\r\nI brought him all the way from London expressly to introduce him to\r\n_you._\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I wish you had left him in London!\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Mrs. Glenarm,\r\nshifting suddenly from tears to temper. \xe2\x80\x9cI was a happy woman before I\r\nmet your brother. I can\xe2\x80\x99t give him up!\xe2\x80\x9d she burst out, shifting back\r\nagain from temper to tears. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care if he _has_ deceived me.\r\nI won\xe2\x80\x99t let another woman have him! I _will_ be his wife!\xe2\x80\x9d She threw\r\nherself theatrically on her knees before Julius. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, _do_ help me to\r\nfind out the truth!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, Julius, pity me! I am so fond of\r\nhim!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was genuine distress in her face, there was true feeling in her\r\nvoice. Who would have believed that there were reserves of merciless\r\ninsolence and heartless cruelty in this woman--and that they had been\r\nlavishly poured out on a fallen sister not five minutes since?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do all I can,\xe2\x80\x9d said Julius, raising her. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us talk of it when\r\nyou are more composed. Try a little music,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, \xe2\x80\x9cjust to quiet\r\nyour nerves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould _you_ like me to play?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mrs. Glenarm, becoming a model of\r\nfeminine docility at a moment\xe2\x80\x99s notice.\r\n\r\nJulius opened the Sonatas of Mozart, and shouldered his violin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s try the Fifteenth,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, placing Mrs. Glenarm at the piano.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will begin with the Adagio. If ever there was divine music written\r\nby mortal man, there it is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey began. At the third bar Mrs. Glenarm dropped a note--and the bow of\r\nJulius paused shuddering on the strings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t play!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI am so agitated; I am so anxious. How _am_ I\r\nto find out whether that wretch is really married or not? Who can I ask?\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t go to Geoffrey in London--the trainers won\xe2\x80\x99t let me see him. I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t appeal to Mr. Brinkworth himself--I am not even acquainted with\r\nhim. Who else is there? Do think, and tell me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was but one chance of making her return to the Adagio--the chance\r\nof hitting on a suggestion which would satisfy and quiet her. Julius\r\nlaid his violin on the piano, and considered the question before him\r\ncarefully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are the witnesses,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf Geoffrey\xe2\x80\x99s story is to be\r\ndepended on, the landlady and the waiter at the inn can speak to the\r\nfacts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLow people!\xe2\x80\x9d objected Mrs. Glenarm. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. People who\r\nmight take advantage of my situation, and be insolent to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJulius considered once more; and made another suggestion. With the fatal\r\ningenuity of innocence, he hit on the idea of referring Mrs. Glenarm to\r\nno less a person than Lady Lundie herself!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is our good friend at Windygates,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cSome whisper of the\r\nmatter may have reached Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s ears. It may be a little awkward\r\nto call on her (if she _has_ heard any thing) at the time of a serious\r\nfamily disaster. You are the best judge of that, however. All I can do\r\nis to throw out the notion. Windygates isn\xe2\x80\x99t very far off--and something\r\nmight come of it. What do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSomething might come of it! Let it be remembered that Lady Lundie had\r\nbeen left entirely in the dark--that she had written to Sir Patrick in\r\na tone which plainly showed that her self-esteem was wounded and her\r\nsuspicion roused--and that her first intimation of the serious dilemma\r\nin which Arnold Brinkworth stood was now likely, thanks to Julius\r\nDelamayn, to reach her from the lips of a mere acquaintance. Let this\r\nbe remembered; and then let the estimate be formed of what might come of\r\nit--not at Windygates only, but also at Ham Farm!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Julius.\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm was enchanted. \xe2\x80\x9cThe very person to go to!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I\r\nam not let in I can easily write--and explain my object as an apology.\r\nLady Lundie is so right-minded, so sympathetic. If she sees no one\r\nelse--I have only to confide my anxieties to her, and I am sure she will\r\nsee me. You will lend me a carriage, won\xe2\x80\x99t you? I\xe2\x80\x99ll go to Windygates\r\nto-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJulius took his violin off the pi ano.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t think me very troublesome,\xe2\x80\x9d he said coaxingly. \xe2\x80\x9cBetween this and\r\nto-morrow we have nothing to do. And it is _such_ music, if you once get\r\ninto the swing of it! Would you mind trying again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm was willing to do any thing to prove her gratitude, after\r\nthe invaluable hint which she had just received. At the second trial the\r\nfair pianist\xe2\x80\x99s eye and hand were in perfect harmony. The lovely melody\r\nwhich the Adagio of Mozart\xe2\x80\x99s Fifteenth Sonata has given to violin and\r\npiano flowed smoothly at last--and Julius Delamayn soared to the seventh\r\nheaven of musical delight.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next day Mrs. Glenarm and Mrs. Delamayn went together to Windygates\r\nHouse.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTENTH SCENE--THE BEDROOM.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE FORTY-FIRST.\r\n\r\nLADY LUNDIE DOES HER DUTY.\r\n\r\nTHE scene opens on a bedroom--and discloses, in broad daylight, a lady\r\nin bed.\r\n\r\nPersons with an irritable sense of propriety, whose self-appointed duty\r\nit is to be always crying out, are warned to pause before they cry out\r\non this occasion. The lady now presented to view being no less a person\r\nthan Lady Lundie herself, it follows, as a matter of course, that the\r\nutmost demands of propriety are, by the mere assertion of that fact,\r\nabundantly and indisputably satisfied. To say that any thing short of\r\ndirect moral advantage could, by any possibility, accrue to any living\r\ncreature by the presentation of her ladyship in a horizontal, instead\r\nof a perpendicular position, is to assert that Virtue is a question of\r\nposture, and that Respectability ceases to assert itself when it ceases\r\nto appear in morning or evening dress. Will any body be bold enough to\r\nsay that? Let nobody cry out, then, on the present occasion.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nLady Lundie was in bed.\r\n\r\nHer ladyship had received Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s written announcement of the\r\nsudden stoppage of the bridal tour; and had penned the answer to Sir\r\nPatrick--the receipt of which at Ham Farm has been already described.\r\nThis done, Lady Lundie felt it due to herself to take a becoming\r\nposition in her own house, pending the possible arrival of Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nreply. What does a right-minded woman do, when she has reason to believe\r\nthat she is cruelly distrusted by the members of her own family? A\r\nright-minded woman feels it so acutely that she falls ill. Lady Lundie\r\nfell ill accordingly.\r\n\r\nThe case being a serious one, a medical practitioner of the highest\r\ngrade in the profession was required to treat it. A physician from the\r\nneighboring town of Kirkandrew was called in.\r\n\r\nThe physician came in a carriage and pair, with the necessary bald head,\r\nand the indispensable white cravat. He felt her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s pulse, and\r\nput a few gentle questions. He turned his back solemnly, as only a great\r\ndoctor can, on his own positive internal conviction that his patient had\r\nnothing whatever the matter with her. He said, with every appearance of\r\nbelieving in himself, \xe2\x80\x9cNerves, Lady Lundie. Repose in bed is essentially\r\nnecessary. I will write a prescription.\xe2\x80\x9d He prescribed, with perfect\r\ngravity: Aromatic Spirits of Ammonia--16 drops. Spirits of Red\r\nLavender--10 drops. Syrup of Orange Peel--2 drams. Camphor Julep--1\r\nounce. When he had written, Misce fiat Hanstus (instead of Mix a\r\nDraught)--when he had added, Ter die Sumendus (instead of To be taken\r\nThree times a day)--and when he had certified to his own Latin, by\r\nputting his initials at the end, he had only to make his bow; to slip\r\ntwo guineas into his pocket; and to go his way, with an approving\r\nprofessional conscience, in the character of a physician who had done\r\nhis duty.\r\n\r\nLady Lundie was in bed. The visible part of her ladyship was perfectly\r\nattired, with a view to the occasion. A fillet of superb white lace\r\nencircled her head. She wore an adorable invalid jacket of white\r\ncambric, trimmed with lace and pink ribbons. The rest was--bed-clothes.\r\nOn a table at her side stood the Red Lavender Draught--in color soothing\r\nto the eye; in flavor not unpleasant to the taste. A book of devotional\r\ncharacter was near it. The domestic ledgers, and the kitchen report\r\nfor the day, were ranged modestly behind the devout book. (Not even\r\nher ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s nerves, observe, were permitted to interfere with her\r\nladyship\xe2\x80\x99s duty.) A fan, a smelling-bottle, and a handkerchief lay\r\nwithin reach on the counterpane. The spacious room was partially\r\ndarkened. One of the lower windows was open, affording her ladyship the\r\nnecessary cubic supply of air. The late Sir Thomas looked at his widow,\r\nin effigy, from the wall opposite the end of the bed. Not a chair was\r\nout of its place; not a vestige of wearing apparel dared to show itself\r\noutside the sacred limits of the wardrobe and the drawers. The sparkling\r\ntreasures of the toilet-table glittered in the dim distance, The jugs\r\nand basins were of a rare and creamy white; spotless and beautiful to\r\nsee. Look where you might, you saw a perfect room. Then look at the\r\nbed--and you saw a perfect woman, and completed the picture.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was the day after Anne\xe2\x80\x99s appearance at Swanhaven--toward the end of\r\nthe afternoon.\r\n\r\nLady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s own maid opened the door noiselessly, and stole on tip-toe\r\nto the bedside. Her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s eyes were closed. Her ladyship suddenly\r\nopened them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot asleep, Hopkins. Suffering. What is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHopkins laid two cards on the counterpane. \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Delamayn, my lady--and\r\nMrs. Glenarm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey were told I was ill, of course?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my lady. Mrs. Glenarm sent for me. She went into the library,\r\nand wrote this note.\xe2\x80\x9d Hopkins produced the note, neatly folded in\r\nthree-cornered form.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave they gone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my lady. Mrs. Glenarm told me Yes or No would do for answer, if you\r\ncould only have the goodness to read this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThoughtless of Mrs. Glenarm--at a time when the doctor insists on\r\nperfect repose,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Lundie. \xe2\x80\x9cIt doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter. One sacrifice\r\nmore or less is of very little consequence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe fortified herself by an application of the smelling-bottle, and\r\nopened the note. It ran thus:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo grieved, dear Lady Lundie, to hear that you are a prisoner in your\r\nroom! I had taken the opportunity of calling with Mrs. Delamayn, in the\r\nhope that I might be able to ask you a question. Will your inexhaustible\r\nkindness forgive me if I ask it in writing? Have you had any unexpected\r\nnews of Mr. Arnold Brinkworth lately? I mean, have you heard any thing\r\nabout him, which has taken you very much by surprise? I have a serious\r\nreason for asking this. I will tell you what it is, the moment you are\r\nable to see me. Until then, one word of answer is all I expect. Send\r\nword down--Yes, or No. A thousand apologies--and pray get better soon!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe singular question contained in this note suggested one of two\r\ninferences to Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s mind. Either Mrs. Glenarm had heard a report\r\nof the unexpected return of the married couple to England--or she was in\r\nthe far more interesting and important position of possessing a clew\r\nto the secret of what was going on under the surface at Ham Farm. The\r\nphrase used in the note, \xe2\x80\x9cI have a serious reason for asking this,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n appeared to favor the latter of the two interpretations. Impossible as\r\nit seemed to be that Mrs. Glenarm could know something about Arnold of\r\nwhich Lady Lundie was in absolute ignorance, her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s curiosity\r\n(already powerfully excited by Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s mysterious letter) was only\r\nto be quieted by obtaining the necessary explanation forthwith, at a\r\npersonal interview.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHopkins,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI must see Mrs. Glenarm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHopkins respectfully held up her hands in horror. Company in the bedroom\r\nin the present state of her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s health!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA matter of duty is involved in this, Hopkins. Give me the glass.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHopkins produced an elegant little hand-mirror. Lady Lundie carefully\r\nsurveyed herself in it down to the margin of the bedclothes. Above\r\ncriticism in every respect? Yes--even when the critic was a woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShow Mrs. Glenarm up here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn a minute or two more the iron-master\xe2\x80\x99s widow fluttered into\r\nthe room--a little over-dressed as usual; and a little profuse in\r\nexpressions of gratitude for her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s kindness, and of anxiety\r\nabout her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s health. Lady Lundie endured it as long as she\r\ncould--then stopped it with a gesture of polite remonstrance, and came\r\nto the point.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, my dear--about this question in your note? Is it possible you have\r\nheard already that Arnold Brinkworth and his wife have come back from\r\nBaden?\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Glenarm opened her eyes in astonishment. Lady Lundie put it\r\nmore plainly. \xe2\x80\x9cThey were to have gone on to Switzerland, you know, for\r\ntheir wedding tour, and they suddenly altered their minds, and came back\r\nto England on Sunday last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Lady Lundie, it\xe2\x80\x99s not that! Have you heard nothing about Mr.\r\nBrinkworth except what you have just told me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a pause. Mrs. Glenarm toyed hesitatingly with her parasol.\r\nLady Lundie leaned forward in the bed, and looked at her attentively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have _you_ heard about him?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm was embarrassed. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s so difficult to say,\xe2\x80\x9d she began.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can bear any thing but suspense,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Lundie. \xe2\x80\x9cTell me the\r\nworst.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm decided to risk it. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you never heard,\xe2\x80\x9d she asked,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat Mr. Brinkworth might possibly have committed himself with another\r\nlady before he married Miss Lundie?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer ladyship first closed her eyes in horror and then searched blindly\r\non the counterpane for the smelling-bottle. Mrs. Glenarm gave it to her,\r\nand waited to see how the invalid bore it before she said any more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are things one _must_ hear,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Lady Lundie. \xe2\x80\x9cI see an act\r\nof duty involved in this. No words can describe how you astonish me. Who\r\ntold you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Geoffrey Delamayn told me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer ladyship applied for the second time to the smelling-bottle. \xe2\x80\x9cArnold\r\nBrinkworth\xe2\x80\x99s most intimate friend!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cHe ought to know if\r\nany body does. This is dreadful. Why should Mr. Geoffrey Delamayn tell\r\n_you?_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going to marry him,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mrs. Glenarm. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is my excuse,\r\ndear Lady Lundie, for troubling you in this matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie partially opened her eyes in a state of faint bewilderment.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cFor Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake explain yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaven\xe2\x80\x99t you heard about the anonymous letters?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mrs. Glenarm.\r\n\r\nYes. Lady Lundie had heard about the letters. But only what the public\r\nin general had heard. The name of the lady in the background not\r\nmentioned; and Mr. Geoffrey Delamayn assumed to be as innocent as the\r\nbabe unborn. Any mistake in that assumption? \xe2\x80\x9cGive me your hand, my poor\r\ndear, and confide it all to _me!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is not quite innocent,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Glenarm. \xe2\x80\x9cHe owned to a foolish\r\nflirtation--all _her_ doing, no doubt. Of course, I insisted on a\r\ndistinct explanation. Had she really any claim on him? Not the shadow of\r\na claim. I felt that I only had his word for that--and I told him so.\r\nHe said he could prove it--he said he knew her to be privately married\r\nalready. Her husband had disowned and deserted her; she was at the\r\nend of her resources; she was desperate enough to attempt any thing. I\r\nthought it all very suspicious--until Geoffrey mentioned the man\xe2\x80\x99s name.\r\n_That_ certainly proved that he had cast off his wife; for I myself knew\r\nthat he had lately married another person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie suddenly started up from her pillow--honestly agitated;\r\ngenuinely alarmed by this time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Delamayn told you the man\xe2\x80\x99s name?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, breathlessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo I know it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t ask me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie fell back on the pillow.\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm rose to ring for help. Before she could touch the bell, her\r\nladyship had rallied again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried. \xe2\x80\x9cI can confirm it! It\xe2\x80\x99s true, Mrs. Glenarm! it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntrue! Open the silver box on the toilet-table--you will find the key in\r\nit. Bring me the top letter. Here! Look at it. I got this from Blanche.\r\nWhy have they suddenly given up their bridal tour? Why have they gone\r\nback to Sir Patrick at Ham Farm? Why have they put me off with an\r\ninfamous subterfuge to account for it? I felt sure something dreadful\r\nhad happened. Now I know what it is!\xe2\x80\x9d She sank back again, with closed\r\neyes, and repeated the words, in a fierce whisper, to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cNow I\r\nknow what it is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm read the letter. The reason given for the suspiciously\r\nsudden return of the bride and bridegroom was palpably a\r\nsubterfuge--and, more remarkable still, the name of Anne Silvester was\r\nconnected with it. Mrs. Glenarm became strongly agitated on her side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis _is_ a confirmation,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Brinkworth has been found\r\nout--the woman _is_ married to him--Geoffrey is free. Oh, my dear\r\nfriend, what a load of anxiety you have taken off my mind! That vile\r\nwretch--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie suddenly opened her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean,\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, \xe2\x80\x9cthe woman who is at the bottom of all the\r\nmischief?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. I saw her yesterday. She forced herself in at Swanhaven. She\r\ncalled him Geoffrey Delamayn. She declared herself a single woman. She\r\nclaimed him before my face in the most audacious manner. She shook my\r\nfaith, Lady Lundie--she shook my faith in Geoffrey!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d echoed Mrs. Glenarm. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you even know that? Why her name is\r\nrepeated half a dozen times in this letter!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie uttered a scream that rang through the room. Mrs. Glenarm\r\nstarted to her feet. The maid appeared at the door in terror. Her\r\nladyship motioned to the woman to withdraw again instantly, and then\r\npointed to Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me have a minute or two of quiet. I want\r\nnothing more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe silence in the room was unbroken until Lady Lundie spoke again.\r\nShe asked for Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s letter. After reading it carefully, she laid it\r\naside, and fell for a while into deep thought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have done Blanche an injustice!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cMy poor Blanche!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think she knows nothing about it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am certain of it! You forget, Mrs. Glenarm, that this horrible\r\ndiscovery casts a doubt on my step-daughter\xe2\x80\x99s marriage. Do you think, if\r\nshe knew the truth, she would write of a wretch who has mortally injured\r\nher as she writes here? They have put her off with the excuse that\r\nshe innocently sends to _me._ I see it as plainly as I see you! Mr.\r\nBrinkworth and Sir Patrick are in league to keep us both in the dark.\r\nDear child! I owe her an atonement. If nobody else opens her eyes, I\r\nwill do it. Sir Patrick shall find that Blanche has a friend in Me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA smile--the dangerous smile of an inveterately vindictive woman\r\nthoroughly roused--showed itself with a furtive suddenness on her face.\r\nMrs. Glenarm was a little startled. Lady Lundie below the surface--as\r\ndistinguished from Lady Lundie _on_ the surface--was not a pleasant\r\nobject to contemplate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray try to compose yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Glenarm. \xe2\x80\x9cDear Lady Lundie,\r\nyou frighten me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe bland surface of her ladyship appeared smoothly once more; drawn\r\nback, as it were, over the hidden inner self, which it had left for the\r\nmoment exposed to view.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me for feeling it!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with the patient sweetness which\r\nso eminently distinguished her in times of trial. \xe2\x80\x9cIt falls a little\r\nheavily on a poor sick woman--innocent of all suspicion, and insulted by\r\nthe most heartless neglect. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let me distress you. I shall rally, my\r\ndear; I shall rally! In this dreadful calamity--this abyss of crime and\r\nmisery and deceit--I have no one to depend on but myself. For Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsake, the whole thing must be cleared up--probed, my dear, probed to the\r\ndepths. Blanche must take a position that is worthy of her. Blanche must\r\ninsist on her rights, under My protection. Never mind what I suffer, or\r\nwhat I sacrifice. There is a work of justice for poor weak Me to do.\r\nIt shall be done!\xe2\x80\x9d said her ladyship, fanning herself with an aspect of\r\nillimitable resolution. \xe2\x80\x9cIt shall be done!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Lady Lundie what can you do? They are all away in the south. And\r\nas for that abominable woman--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie touched Mrs. Glenarm on the shoulder with her fan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have my surprise in store, dear friend, as well as you. That\r\nabominable woman was employed as Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s governess in this house.\r\nWait! that is not all. She left us suddenly--ran away--on the pretense\r\nof being privately married. I know where she went. I can trace what\r\nshe did. I can find out who was with her. I can follow Mr. Brinkworth\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nproceedings, behind Mr. Brinkworth\xe2\x80\x99s back. I can search out the truth,\r\nwithout depending on people compromised in this black business, whose\r\ninterest it is to deceive me. And I will do it to-day!\xe2\x80\x9d She closed the\r\nfan with a sharp snap of triumph, and settled herself on the pillow in\r\nplacid enjoyment of her dear friend\xe2\x80\x99s surprise.\r\n\r\nMrs. Glenarm drew confidentially closer to the bedside. \xe2\x80\x9cHow can you\r\nmanage it?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, eagerly. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t think me curious. I have my\r\ninterest, too, in getting at the truth.
