Don\xe2\x80\x99t leave me out of it, pray!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you come back to-morrow, at this time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! yes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, then--and you shall know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan I be of any use?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at present.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan my uncle be of any use?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know where to communicate with Captain Newenden?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes--he is staying with some friends in Sussex.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe may possibly want his assistance. I can\xe2\x80\x99t tell yet. Don\xe2\x80\x99t keep Mrs.\r\nDelamayn waiting any longer, my dear. I shall expect you to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey exchanged an affectionate embrace. Lady Lundie was left alone.\r\n\r\nHer ladyship resigned herself to meditation, with frowning brow and\r\nclose-shut lips. She looked her full age, and a year or two more, as she\r\nlay thinking, with her head on her hand, and her elbow on the pillow.\r\nAfter committing herself to the physician (and to the red lavender\r\ndraught) the commonest regard for consistency made it necessary that\r\nshe should keep her bed for that day. And yet it was essential that the\r\nproposed inquiries should be instantly set on foot. On the one hand, the\r\nproblem was not an easy one to solve; on the other, her ladyship was\r\nnot an easy one to beat. How to send for the landlady at Craig Fernie,\r\nwithout exciting any special suspicion or remark--was the question\r\nbefore her. In less than five minutes she had looked back into her\r\nmemory of current events at Windygates--and had solved it.\r\n\r\nHer first proceeding was to ring the bell for her maid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid I frightened you, Hopkins. The state of my nerves. Mrs.\r\nGlenarm was a little sudden with some news that surprised me. I am\r\nbetter now--and able to attend to the household matters. There is a\r\nmistake in the butcher\xe2\x80\x99s account. Send the cook here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe took up the domestic ledger and the kitchen report; corrected the\r\nbutcher; cautioned the cook; and disposed of all arrears of domestic\r\nbusiness before Hopkins was summoned again. Having, in this way,\r\ndextrously prevented the woman from connecting any thing that her\r\nmistress said or did, after Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s departure, with any thing\r\nthat might have passed during Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s visit, Lady Lundie felt\r\nherself at liberty to pave the way for the investigation on which she\r\nwas determined to enter before she slept that night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much for the indoor arrangements,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou must be my prime\r\nminister, Hopkins, while I lie helpless here. Is there any thing wanted\r\nby the people out of doors? The coachman? The gardener?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have just seen the gardener, my lady. He came with last week\xe2\x80\x99s\r\naccounts. I told him he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t see your ladyship to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite right. Had he any report to make?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my lady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely, there was something I wanted to say to him--or to somebody\r\nelse? My memorandum-book, Hopkins. In the basket, on that chair. Why\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t the basket placed by my bedside?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHopkins brought the memorandum-book. Lady Lundie consulted it (without\r\nthe slightest necessity), with the same masterly gravity exhibited\r\nby the doctor when he wrote her prescription (without the slightest\r\nnecessity also).\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere it is,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, recovering the lost remembrance. \xe2\x80\x9cNot the\r\ngardener, but the gardener\xe2\x80\x99s wife. A memorandum to speak to her about\r\nMrs. Inchbare. Observe, Hopkins, the association of ideas. Mrs. Inchbare\r\nis associated with the poultry; the poultry are associated with\r\nthe gardener\xe2\x80\x99s wife; the gardener\xe2\x80\x99s wife is associated with the\r\ngardener--and so the gardener gets into my head. Do you see it? I am\r\nalways trying to improve your mind. You do see it? Very well. Now about\r\nMrs. Inchbare? Has she been here again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my lady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not at all sure, Hopkins, that I was right in declining to\r\nconsider the message Mrs. Inchbare sent to me about the poultry. Why\r\nshouldn\xe2\x80\x99t she offer to take any fowls that I can spare off my hands? She\r\nis a respectable woman; and it is important to me to live on good terms\r\nwith al my neighbors, great and small. Has she got a poultry-yard of her\r\nown at Craig Fernie?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my lady. And beautifully kept, I am told.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI really don\xe2\x80\x99t see--on reflection, Hopkins--why I should hesitate to\r\ndeal with Mrs. Inchbare. (I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it beneath me to sell the game\r\nkilled on my estate to the poulterer.) What was it she wanted to buy?\r\nSome of my black Spanish fowls?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my lady. Your ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s black Spaniards are famous all round the\r\nneighborhood. Nobody has got the breed. And Mrs. Inchbare--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWants to share the distinction of having the breed with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady\r\nLundie. \xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t appear ungracious. I will see her myself, as soon as I\r\nam a little better, and tell her that I have changed my mind. Send\r\none of the men to Craig Fernie with a message. I can\xe2\x80\x99t keep a trifling\r\nmatter of this sort in my memory--send him at once, or I may forget it.\r\nHe is to say I am willing to see Mrs. Inchbare, about the fowls, the\r\nfirst time she finds it convenient to come this way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid, my lady--Mrs. Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s heart is so set on the black\r\nSpaniards--she will find it convenient to come this way at once as fast\r\nas her feet can carry her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case, you must take her to the gardener\xe2\x80\x99s wife. Say she is to\r\nhave some eggs--on condition, of course, of paying the price for them.\r\nIf she does come, mind I hear of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHopkins withdrew. Hopkins\xe2\x80\x99s mistress reclined on her comfortable pillows\r\nand fanned herself gently. The vindictive smile reappeared on her face.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fancy I shall be well enough to see Mrs. Inchbare,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought to\r\nherself. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd it is just possible that the conversation may get beyond\r\nthe relative merits of her poultry-yard and mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA lapse of little more than two hours proved Hopkins\xe2\x80\x99s estimate of the\r\nlatent enthusiasm in Mrs. Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s character to have been correctly\r\nformed. The eager landlady appeared at Windygates on the heels of the\r\nreturning servant. Among the long list of human weaknesses, a passion\r\nfor poultry seems to have its practical advantages (in the shape\r\nof eggs) as compared with the more occult frenzies for collecting\r\nsnuff-boxes and fiddles, and amassing autographs and old postage-stamps.\r\nWhen the mistress of Craig Fernie was duly announced to the mistress of\r\nWindygates, Lady Lundie developed a sense of humor for the first time\r\nin her life. Her ladyship was feebly merry (the result, no doubt, of the\r\nexhilarating properties of the red lavender draught) on the subject of\r\nMrs. Inchbare and the Spanish fowls.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost ridiculous, Hopkins! This poor woman must be suffering from\r\na determination of poultry to the brain. Ill as I am, I should have\r\nthought that nothing could amuse me. But, really, this good creature\r\nstarting up, and rushing here, as you say, as fast as her feet can carry\r\nher--it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to resist it! I positively think I must see\r\nMrs. Inchbare. With my active habits, this imprisonment to my room is\r\ndreadful. I can neither sleep nor read. Any thing, Hopkins, to divert my\r\nmind from myself: It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to get rid of her if she is too much for me.\r\nSend her up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Inchbare made her appearance, courtesying deferentially; amazed at\r\nthe condescension which admitted her within the hallowed precincts of\r\nLady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake a chair,\xe2\x80\x9d said her ladyship, graciously. \xe2\x80\x9cI am suffering from\r\nillness, as you perceive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy certie! sick or well, yer leddyship\xe2\x80\x99s a braw sight to see!\xe2\x80\x9d returned\r\nMrs. Inchbare profoundly impressed by the elegant costume which illness\r\nassumes when illness appears in the regions of high life.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am far from being in a fit state to receive any body,\xe2\x80\x9d proceeded Lady\r\nLundie. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I had a motive for wishing to speak to you when you next\r\ncame to my house. I failed to treat a proposal you made to me, a short\r\ntime since, in a friendly and neighborly way. I beg you to understand\r\nthat I regret having forgotten the consideration due from a person in\r\nmy position to a person in yours. I am obliged to say this under very\r\nunusual circumstances,\xe2\x80\x9d added her ladyship, with a glance round her\r\nmagnificent bedroom, \xe2\x80\x9cthrough your unexpected promptitude in favoring me\r\nwith a call. You have lost no time, Mrs. Inchbare, in profiting by the\r\nmessage which I had the pleasure of sending to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, my leddy, I wasna\xe2\x80\x99 that sure (yer leddyship having ance changed yer\r\nmind) but that ye might e\xe2\x80\x99en change again if I failed to strike, as they\r\nsay, while the iron\xe2\x80\x99s het. I crave yer pardon, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure, if I ha\xe2\x80\x99\r\nbeen ower hasty. The pride o\xe2\x80\x99 my hairt\xe2\x80\x99s in my powltry--and the black\r\nSpaniards\xe2\x80\x99 (as they ca\xe2\x80\x99 them) are a sair temptation to me to break the\r\ntenth commandment, sae lang as they\xe2\x80\x99re a\xe2\x80\x99 in yer leddyship\xe2\x80\x99s possession,\r\nand nane o\xe2\x80\x99 them in mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am shocked to hear that I have been the innocent cause of your\r\nfalling into temptation, Mrs. Inchbare! Make your proposal--and I shall\r\nbe happy to meet it, if I can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must e\xe2\x80\x99en be content wi\xe2\x80\x99 what yer leddyship will condescend on. A\r\nhaitch o\xe2\x80\x99 eggs if I can come by naething else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is something else you would prefer to a hatch of eggs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wad prefer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Inchbare, modestly, \xe2\x80\x9ca cock and twa pullets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOpen the case on the table behind you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Lundie, \xe2\x80\x9cand you will\r\nfind some writing paper inside. Give me a sheet of it--and the pencil\r\nout of the tray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEagerly watched by Mrs. Inchbare, she wrote an order to the\r\npoultry-woman, and held it out with a gracious smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake that to the gardener\xe2\x80\x99s wife. If you agree with her about the\r\nprice, you can have the cock and the two pullets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Inchbare opened her lips--no doubt to express the utmost extremity\r\nof human gratitude. Before she had said three words, Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nimpatience to reach the end which she had kept in view from the\r\ntime when Mrs. Glenarm had left the house burst the bounds which had\r\nsuccessfully restrained it thus far. Stopping the landlady without\r\nceremony, she fairly forced the conversation to the subject of Anne\r\nSilvester\xe2\x80\x99s proceedings at the Craig Fernie inn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you getting on at the hotel, Mrs. Inchbare? Plenty of tourists,\r\nI suppose, at this time of year?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFull, my leddy (praise Providence), frae the basement to the ceiling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had a visitor, I think, some time since of whom I know something? A\r\nperson--\xe2\x80\x9d She paused, and put a strong constraint on herself. There was\r\nno alternative but to yield to the hard necessity of making her inquiry\r\nintelligible. \xe2\x80\x9cA lady,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, \xe2\x80\x9cwho came to you about the middle of\r\nlast month.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCould yer leddyship condescend on her name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie put a still stronger constraint on herself. \xe2\x80\x9cSilvester,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nsaid, sharply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPresairve us a\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mrs. Inchbare. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will never be the same that\r\ncam\xe2\x80\x99 driftin\xe2\x80\x99 in by hersel\xe2\x80\x99--wi\xe2\x80\x99 a bit bag in her hand, and a husband\r\nleft daidling an hour or mair on the road behind her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no doubt it is the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill she be a freend o\xe2\x80\x99 yer leddyship\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mrs. Inchbare, feeling\r\nher ground cautiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not!\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Lundie. \xe2\x80\x9cI felt a passing curiosity about\r\nher--nothing more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Inchbare looked relieved. \xe2\x80\x9cTo tell ye truth, my leddy, there was\r\nnae love lost between us. She had a maisterfu\xe2\x80\x99 temper o\xe2\x80\x99 her ain--and I\r\nwas weel pleased when I\xe2\x80\x99d seen the last of her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can quite understand that, Mrs. Inchbare--I know something of her\r\ntemper myself. Did I understand you to say that she came to your hotel\r\nalone, and that her husband joined her shortly afterward?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cE\xe2\x80\x99en sae, yer leddyship. I was no\xe2\x80\x99 free to gi\xe2\x80\x99 her house-room in the\r\nhottle till her husband daidled in at her heels and answered for her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fancy I must have seen her husband,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Lundie. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat sort of\r\na man was he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Inchbare replied in much the same words which she had used in\r\nanswering the similar question put by Sir Patrick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh! he was ower young for the like o\xe2\x80\x99 _her._ A pratty man, my\r\nleddy--betwixt tall and short; wi\xe2\x80\x99 bonny brown eyes and cheeks, and fine\r\ncoal-blaik hair. A nice douce-spoken lad. I hae naething to say against\r\nhim--except that he cam\xe2\x80\x99 late one day, and took leg-bail betimes the\r\nnext morning, and left madam behind, a load on my hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe answer produced precisely the same effect on Lady Lundie which it\r\nhad produced on Sir Patrick. She, also, felt that it was too vaguely\r\nlike too many young men of no uncommon humor and complexion to be\r\nrelied on. But her ladyship possessed one immense advantage over her\r\nbrother-in-law in attempting to arrive at the truth. _She_ suspected\r\nArnold--and it was possible, in her case, to assist Mrs. Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmemory by hints contributed from her own superior resources of\r\nexperience and observation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad he any thing about him of the look and way of a sailor?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did you notice, when you spoke to him, that he had a habit of\r\nplaying with a locket on his watch-chain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere he is, het aff to a T!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mrs. Inchbare. \xe2\x80\x9cYer leddyship\xe2\x80\x99s weel\r\nacquented wi\xe2\x80\x99 him--there\xe2\x80\x99s nae doot o\xe2\x80\x99 that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought I had seen him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lady Lundie. \xe2\x80\x9cA modest, well-behaved\r\nyoung man, Mrs. Inchbare, as you say. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let me keep you any longer\r\nfrom the poultry-yard. I am transgressing the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s orders in seeing\r\nany body. We quite understand each other now, don\xe2\x80\x99t we? Very glad to\r\nhave seen you. Good-evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo she dismissed Mrs. Inchbare, when Mrs. Inchbare had served her\r\npurpose.\r\n\r\nMost women, in her position, would have been content with the\r\ninformation which she had now obtained. But Lady Lundie--having a man\r\nlike Sir Patrick to deal with--determined to be doubly sure of her facts\r\nbefore she ventured on interfering at Ham Farm. She had learned from\r\nMrs. Inchbare that the so-called husband of Anne Silvester had joined\r\nher at Craig Fernie on the day when she arrived at the inn, and had left\r\nher again the next morning. Anne had made her escape from Windygates\r\non the occasion of the lawn-party--that is to say, on the fourteenth of\r\nAugust. On the same day Arnold Brinkworth had taken his departure for\r\nthe purpose of visiting the Scotch property left to him by his aunt. If\r\nMrs. Inchbare was to be depended on, he must have gone to Craig Fernie\r\ninstead of going to his appointed destination--and must, therefore, have\r\narrived to visit his house and lands one day later than the day which he\r\nhad originally set apart for that purpose. If this fact could be proved,\r\non the testimony of a disinterested witness, the case against Arnold\r\nwould be strengthened tenfold; and Lady Lundie might act on her\r\ndiscovery with something like a certainty that her information was to be\r\nrelied on.\r\n\r\nAfter a little consideration she decided on sending a messenger with a\r\nnote of inquiry addressed to Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s steward. The apology she invented\r\nto excuse and account for the strangeness of the proposed question,\r\nreferred it to a little family discussion as to the exact date of\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s arrival at his estate, and to a friendly wager in which the\r\ndifference of opinion had ended. If the steward could state whether his\r\nemployer had arrived on the fourteenth or on the fifteenth of August,\r\nthat was all that would be wanted to decide the question in dispute.\r\n\r\nHaving written in those terms, Lady Lundie gave the necessary directions\r\nfor having the note delivered at the earliest possible hour on the next\r\nmorning; the messenger being ordered to make his way back to Windygates\r\nby the first return train on the same day.\r\n\r\nThis arranged, her ladyship was free to refresh herself with another\r\ndose of the red lavender draught, and to sleep the sleep of the just who\r\nclose their eyes with the composing conviction that they have done their\r\nduty.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe events of the next day at Windygates succeeded each other in due\r\ncourse, as follows:\r\n\r\nThe post arrived, and brought no reply from Sir Patrick. Lady Lundie\r\nentered that incident on her mental register of debts owed by her\r\nbrother-in-law--to be paid, with interest, when the day of reckoning\r\ncame.\r\n\r\nNext in order occurred the return of the messenger with the steward\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nanswer.\r\n\r\nHe had referred to his Diary; and he had discovered that Mr. Brinkworth\r\nhad written beforehand to announce his arrival at his estate for the\r\nfourteenth of August--but that he had not actually appeared until the\r\nfifteenth. The one discovery needed to substantiate Mrs. Inchbare\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nevidence being now in Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s possession, she decided to allow\r\nanother day to pass--on the chance that Sir Patrick might al ter his\r\nmind, and write to her. If no letter arrived, and if nothing more was\r\nreceived from Blanche, she resolved to leave Windygates by the next\r\nmorning\xe2\x80\x99s train, and to try the bold experiment of personal interference\r\nat Ham Farm.\r\n\r\nThe third in the succession of events was the appearance of the doctor\r\nto pay his professional visit.\r\n\r\nA severe shock awaited him. He found his patient cured by the draught!\r\nIt was contrary to all rule and precedent; it savored of quackery--the\r\nred lavender had no business to do what the red lavender had done--but\r\nthere she was, nevertheless, up and dressed, and contemplating a journey\r\nto London on the next day but one. \xe2\x80\x9cAn act of duty, doctor, is involved\r\nin this--whatever the sacrifice, I must go!\xe2\x80\x9d No other explanation could\r\nbe obtained. The patient was plainly determined--nothing remained for\r\nthe physician but to retreat with unimpaired dignity and a paid fee.\r\nHe did it. \xe2\x80\x9cOur art,\xe2\x80\x9d he explained to Lady Lundie in confidence, \xe2\x80\x9cis\r\nnothing, after all, but a choice between alternatives. For instance. I\r\nsee you--not cured, as you think--but sustained by abnormal excitement.\r\nI have to ask which is the least of the two evils--to risk letting\r\nyou travel, or to irritate you by keeping you at home. With your\r\nconstitution, we must risk the journey. Be careful to keep the window of\r\nthe carriage up on the side on which the wind blows. Let the extremities\r\nbe moderately warm, and the mind easy--and pray don\xe2\x80\x99t omit to provide\r\nyourself with a second bottle of the Mixture before you start.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nmade his bow, as before--he slipped two guineas into his pocket, as\r\nbefore--and he went his way, as before, with an approving conscience,\r\nin the character of a physician who had done his duty. (What an enviable\r\nprofession is Medicine! And why don\xe2\x80\x99t we all belong to it?)\r\n\r\nThe last of the events was the arrival of Mrs. Glenarm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d she began, eagerly, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat news?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe narrative of her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s discoveries--recited at full length;\r\nand the announcement of her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s resolution--declared in the most\r\nuncompromising terms--raised Mrs. Glenarm\xe2\x80\x99s excitement to the highest\r\npitch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou go to town on Saturday?\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI will go with you. Ever since\r\nthat woman declared she should be in London before me, I have been dying\r\nto hasten my journey--and it is such an opportunity to go with you! I\r\ncan easily manage it. My uncle and I were to have met in London, early\r\nnext week, for the foot-race. I have only to write and tell him of my\r\nchange of plans.--By-the-by, talking of my uncle, I have heard, since I\r\nsaw you, from the lawyers at Perth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMore anonymous letters?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne more--received by the lawyers this time. My unknown correspondent\r\nhas written to them to withdraw his proposal, and to announce that\r\nhe has left Perth. The lawyers recommended me to stop my uncle from\r\nspending money uselessly in employing the London police. I have\r\nforwarded their letter to the captain; and he will probably be in town\r\nto see his solicitors as soon as I get there with you. So much for\r\nwhat _I_ have done in this matter. Dear Lady Lundie--when we are at our\r\njourney\xe2\x80\x99s end, what do _you_ mean to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy course is plain,\xe2\x80\x9d answered her ladyship, calmly. \xe2\x80\x9cSir Patrick will\r\nhear from me, on Sunday morning next, at Ham Farm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTelling him what you have found out?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not! Telling him that I find myself called to London by\r\nbusiness, and that I propose paying him a short visit on Monday next.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, he must receive you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think there is no doubt of that. Even _his_ hatred of his\r\nbrother\xe2\x80\x99s widow can hardly go to the length--after leaving my letter\r\nunanswered--of closing his doors against me next.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow will you manage it when you get there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I get there, my dear, I shall be breathing an atmosphere of\r\ntreachery and deceit; and, for my poor child\xe2\x80\x99s sake (abhorrent as all\r\ndissimulation is to me), I must be careful what I do. Not a word will\r\nescape my lips until I have first seen Blanche in private. However\r\npainful it may be, I shall not shrink from my duty, if my duty compels\r\nme to open her eyes to the truth. Sir Patrick and Mr. Brinkworth will\r\nhave somebody else besides an inexperienced young creature to deal with\r\non Monday next. I shall be there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that formidable announcement, Lady Lundie closed the conversation;\r\nand Mrs. Glenarm rose to take her leave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe meet at the Junction, dear Lady Lundie?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the Junction, on Saturday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nELEVENTH SCENE.--SIR PATRICK\xe2\x80\x99S HOUSE.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE FORTY-SECOND.\r\n\r\nTHE SMOKING-ROOM WINDOW.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI CAN\xe2\x80\x99T believe it! I won\xe2\x80\x99t believe it! You\xe2\x80\x99re trying to part me from\r\nmy husband--you\xe2\x80\x99re trying to set me against my dearest friend. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninfamous. It\xe2\x80\x99s horrible. What have I done to you? Oh, my head! my head!\r\nAre you trying to drive me mad?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPale and wild; her hands twisted in her hair; her feet hurrying her\r\naimlessly to and fro in the room--so Blanche answered her step-mother,\r\nwhen the object of Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s pilgrimage had been accomplished, and\r\nthe cruel truth had been plainly told.\r\n\r\nHer ladyship sat, superbly composed, looking out through the window at\r\nthe placid landscape of woods and fields which surrounded Ham Farm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was prepared for this outbreak,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, sadly. \xe2\x80\x9cThese wild words\r\nrelieve your over-burdened heart, my poor child. I can wait, Blanche--I\r\ncan wait!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche stopped, and confronted Lady Lundie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou and I never liked each other,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI wrote you a pert letter\r\nfrom this place. I have always taken Anne\xe2\x80\x99s part against you. I have\r\nshown you plainly--rudely, I dare say--that I was glad to be married and\r\nget away from you. This is not your revenge, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Blanche, Blanche, what thoughts to think! what words to say! I can\r\nonly pray for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am mad, Lady Lundie. You bear with mad people. Bear with me. I\r\nhave been hardly more than a fortnight married. I love _him_--I love\r\n_her_--with all my heart. Remember what you have told me about them.\r\nRemember! remember! remember!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe reiterated the words with a low cry of pain. Her hands went up to\r\nher head again; and she returned restlessly to pacing this way and that\r\nin the room.\r\n\r\nLady Lundie tried the effect of a gentle remonstrance. \xe2\x80\x9cFor your own\r\nsake,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t persist in estranging yourself from me. In this\r\ndreadful trial, I am the only friend you have.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche came back to her step-mother\xe2\x80\x99s chair; and looked at her\r\nsteadily, in silence. Lady Lundie submitted to inspection--and bore it\r\nperfectly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook into my heart,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cBlanche! it bleeds for you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche heard, without heeding. Her mind was painfully intent on its\r\nown thoughts. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are a religious woman,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, abruptly. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you\r\nswear on your Bible, that what you told me is true?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_My_ Bible!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Lady Lundie with sorrowful emphasis. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, my\r\nchild! have _you_ no part in that precious inheritance? Is it not _your_\r\nBible, too?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA momentary triumph showed itself in Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s face. \xe2\x80\x9cYou daren\xe2\x80\x99t swear\r\nit!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s enough for me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe turned away scornfully. Lady Lundie caught her by the hand, and drew\r\nher sharply back. The suffering saint disappeared, and the woman who was\r\nno longer to be trifled with took her place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere must be an end to this,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t believe what I have\r\ntold you. Have you courage enough to put it to the test?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche started, and released her hand. She trembled a little. There\r\nwas a horrible certainty of conviction expressed in Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s sudden\r\nchange of manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall see. Tell me the truth, on your side, first. Where is Sir\r\nPatrick? Is he really out, as his servant told me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. He is out with the farm bailiff. You have taken us all by\r\nsurprise. You wrote that we were to expect you by the next train.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen does the next train arrive? It is eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetween one and two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Patrick will not be back till then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot till then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is Mr. Brinkworth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy husband?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour husband--if you like. Is he out, too?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is in the smoking-room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean the long room, built out from the back of the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome down stairs at once with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche advanced a step--and drew back. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want of me?\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nasked, inspired by a sudden distrust.\r\n\r\nLady Lundie turned round, and looked at her impatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you see yet,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, sharply, \xe2\x80\x9cthat your interest and my\r\ninterest in this matter are one? What have I told you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t repeat it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must repeat it! I have told you that Arnold Brinkworth was privately\r\nat Craig Fernie, with Miss Silvester, in the acknowledged character of\r\nher husband--when we supposed him to be visiting the estate left him\r\nby his aunt. You refuse to believe it--and I am about to put it to\r\nthe proof. Is it your interest or is it not, to know whether this man\r\ndeserves the blind belief that you place in him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBlanche trembled from head to foot, and made no reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going into the garden, to speak to Mr. Brinkworth through the\r\nsmoking-room window,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued her ladyship. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you the courage to\r\ncome with me; to wait behind out of sight; and to hear what he says with\r\nhis own lips? I am not afraid of putting it to that test. Are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tone in which she asked the question roused Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s spirit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I believed him to be guilty,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, resolutely, \xe2\x80\x9cI should _not_\r\nhave the courage. I believe him to be innocent. Lead the way, Lady\r\nLundie, as soon as you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey left the room--Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s own room at Ham Farm--and descended to the\r\nhall. Lady Lundie stopped, and consulted the railway time-table hanging\r\nnear the house-door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a train to London at a quarter to twelve,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cHow long\r\ndoes it take to walk to the station?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you ask?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will soon know. Answer my question.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a walk of twenty minutes to the station.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie referred to her watch. \xe2\x80\x9cThere will be just time,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTime for what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome into the garden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that answer, she led the way out\r\n\r\nThe smoking-room projected at right angles from the wall of the house,\r\nin an oblong form--with a bow-window at the farther end, looking into\r\nthe garden. Before she turned the corner, and showed herself within the\r\nrange of view from the window Lady Lundie looked back, and signed to\r\nBlanche to wait behind the angle of the wall. Blanche waited.\r\n\r\nThe next instant she heard the voices in conversation through the open\r\nwindow. Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s voice was the first that spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLady Lundie! Why, we didn\xe2\x80\x99t expect you till luncheon time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lundie was ready with her answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was able to leave town earlier than I had anticipated. Don\xe2\x80\x99t put out\r\nyour cigar; and don\xe2\x80\x99t move. I am not coming in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe quick interchange of question and answer went on; every word being\r\naudible in the perfect stillness of the place. Arnold was the next to\r\nspeak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you seen Blanche?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlanche is getting ready to go out with me. We mean to have a walk\r\ntogether. I have many things to say to her. Before we go, I have\r\nsomething to say to _you._\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it any thing very serious?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is most serious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout you. I know where you went on the evening of my lawn-party at\r\nWindygates--you went to Craig Fernie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Heavens! how did you find out--?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know whom you went to meet--Miss Silvester. I know what is said of\r\nyou and of her--you are man and wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush! don\xe2\x80\x99t speak so loud. Somebody may hear you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does it matter if they do? I am the only person whom you have kept\r\nout of the secret. You all of you know it here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing of the sort! Blanche doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Neither you nor Sir Patrick has told Blanche of the situation you\r\nstand in at this moment?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot yet. Sir Patrick leaves it to me. I haven\xe2\x80\x99t been able to bring\r\nmyself to do it. Don\xe2\x80\x99t say a word, I entreat you. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how\r\nBlanche may interpret it. Her friend is expected in London to-morrow. I\r\nwant to wait till Sir Patrick can bring them together. Her friend will\r\nbreak it to her better than I can. It\xe2\x80\x99s _my_ notion. Sir Patrick thinks\r\nit a good one. Stop! you\xe2\x80\x99re not going away already?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe will be here to look for me if I stay any longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne word! I want to know--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall know later in the day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHer ladyship appeared again round the angle of the wall. The next words\r\nthat passed were words spoken in a whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you satisfied now, Blanche?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you mercy enough left, Lady Lundie, to take me away from this\r\nhouse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear child! Why else did I look at the time-table in the hall?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE FORTY-THIRD.\r\n\r\nTHE EXPLOSION.\r\n\r\nARNOLD\xe2\x80\x99S mind was far from easy when he was left by himself again in the\r\nsmoking-room.\r\n\r\nAfter wasting some time in vainly trying to guess at the source from\r\nwhich Lady Lundie had derived her information, he put on his hat, and\r\ntook the direction which led to Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s favorite walk at Ham Farm.\r\nWithout absolutely distrusting her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s discretion, the idea\r\nhad occurred to him that he would do well to join his wife and her\r\nstep-mother. By making a third at the interview between them, he might\r\nprevent the conversation from assuming a perilously confidential turn.\r\n\r\nThe search for the ladies proved useless. They had not taken the\r\ndirection in which he supposed them to have gone.\r\n\r\nHe returned to the smoking-room, and composed himself to wait for events\r\nas patiently as he might. In this passive position--with his\r\nthoughts still running on Lady Lundie--his memory reverted to a brief\r\nconversation between Sir Patrick and himself, occasioned, on the\r\nprevious day, by her ladyship\xe2\x80\x99s announcement of her proposed visit to\r\nHam Farm. Sir Patrick had at once expressed his conviction that his\r\nsister-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s journey south had some acknowledged purpose at the\r\nbottom of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not at all sure, Arnold\xe2\x80\x9d (he had said), \xe2\x80\x9cthat I have done wisely\r\nin leaving her letter unanswered. And I am strongly disposed to think\r\nthat the safest course will be to take her into the secret when she\r\ncomes to-morrow. We can\xe2\x80\x99t help the position in which we are placed.\r\nIt was impossible (without admitting your wife to our confidence) to\r\nprevent Blanche from writing that unlucky letter to her--and, even if\r\nwe had prevented it, she must have heard in other ways of your return to\r\nEngland. I don\xe2\x80\x99t doubt my own discretion, so far; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t doubt the\r\nconvenience of keeping her in the dark, as a means of keeping her from\r\nmeddling in this business of yours, until I have had time to set it\r\nright. But she may, by some unlucky accident, discover the truth for\r\nherself--and, in that case, I strongly distrust the influence which she\r\nmight attempt to exercise on Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThose were the words--and what had happened on the day after they had\r\nbeen spoken? Lady Lundie _had_ discovered the truth; and she was, at\r\nthat moment, alone somewhere with Blanche. Arnold took up his hat once\r\nmore, and set forth on the search for the ladies in another direction.\r\n\r\nThe second expedition was as fruitless as the first. Nothing was to be\r\nseen, and nothing was to be heard, of Lady Lundie and Blanche.\r\n\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s watch told him that it was not far from the time when Sir\r\nPatrick might be expected to return. In all probability, while he had\r\nbeen looking for them, the ladies had gone back by some other way to the\r\nhouse. He entered the rooms on the ground-floor, one after another. They\r\nwere all empty. He went up stairs, and knocked at the door of Blanche\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nroom. There was no answer. He opened the door and looked in. The room\r\nwas empty, like the rooms down stairs. But, close to the entrance, there\r\nwas a trifling circumstance to attract notice, in the shape of a note\r\nlying on the carpet. He picked it up, and saw that it was addressed to\r\nhim in the handwriting of his wife.\r\n\r\nHe opened it. The note began, without the usual form of address, in\r\nthese words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know the abominable secret that you and my uncle have hidden from\r\nme. I know _your_ infamy, and _her_ infamy, and the position in which,\r\nthanks to you and to her, I now stand. Reproaches would be wasted words,\r\naddressed to such a man as you are. I write these lines to tell you that\r\nI have placed myself under my step-mother\xe2\x80\x99s protection in London. It\r\nis useless to attempt to follow me. Others will find out whether the\r\nceremony of marriage which you went through with me is binding on you or\r\nnot. For myself, I know enough already. I have gone, never to come back,\r\nand never to let you see me again.--Blanche.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurrying headlong down the stairs with but one clear idea in his\r\nmind--the idea of instantly following his wife--Arnold encountered Sir\r\nPatrick, standing by a table in the hall, on which cards and notes left\r\nby visitors were usually placed, with an open letter in his hand. Seeing\r\nin an instant what had happened, he threw one of his arms round Arnold,\r\nand stopped him at the house-door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a man,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, firmly. \xe2\x80\x9cBear it like a man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s head fell on the shoulder of his kind old friend. He burst into\r\ntears.\r\n\r\nSir Patrick let the irrepressible outbreak of grief have its way. In\r\nthose first moments, silence was mercy. He said nothing. The letter\r\nwhich he had been reading (from Lady Lundie, it is needless to say),\r\ndropped unheeded at his feet.\r\n\r\nArnold lifted his head, and dashed away the tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am ashamed of myself,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWrong, my poor fellow--doubly wrong!\xe2\x80\x9d returned Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is\r\nno shame in shedding such tears as those. And there is nothing to be\r\ndone by leaving _me._\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must and will see her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick, pointing to the letter on the floor. \xe2\x80\x9cSee\r\nyour wife? Your wife is with the woman who has written those lines. Read\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold read them.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDEAR SIR PATRICK,--If you had honored me with your confidence, I should\r\nhave been happy to consult you before I interfered to rescue Blanche\r\nfrom the position in which Mr. Brinkworth has placed her. As it is, your\r\nlate brother\xe2\x80\x99s child is under my protection at my house in London. If\r\n_you_ attempt to exercise your authority, it must be by main force--I\r\nwill submit to nothing less. If Mr. Brinkworth attempts to exercise\r\n_his_ authority, he shall establish his right to do so (if he can) in a\r\npolice-court.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery truly yours, JULIA LUNDIE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nArnold\xe2\x80\x99s resolution was not to be shaken even by this. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do I care,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n he burst out, hotly, \xe2\x80\x9cwhether I am dragged through the streets by\r\nthe police or not! I _will_ see my wife. I _will_ clear myself of the\r\nhorrible suspicion she has about me. You have shown me your letter. Look\r\nat mine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s clear sense saw the wild words that Blanche had written in\r\ntheir true light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you hold your wife responsible for that letter?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cI see\r\nher step-mother in every line of it. You descend to something unworthy\r\nof you, if you seriously defend yourself against _this!_ You can\xe2\x80\x99t see\r\nit? You persist in holding to your own view? Write, then. You can\xe2\x80\x99t get\r\nto her--your letter may. No! When you leave this house, you leave it\r\nwith me. I have conceded something on my side, in allowing you to write.\r\nI insist on your conceding something, on your side, in return. Come into\r\nthe library! I answer for setting things right between you and Blanche,\r\nif you will place your interests in my hands. Do you trust me or not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold yielded. They went into the library together. Sir Patrick pointed\r\nto the writing-table. \xe2\x80\x9cRelieve your mind there,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd let me\r\nfind you a reasonable man again when I come back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen he returned to the library the letter was written; and Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmind was so far relieved--for the time at least.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall take your letter to Blanche myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick, \xe2\x80\x9cby the\r\ntrain that leaves for London in half an hour\xe2\x80\x99s time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will let me go with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot to-day. I shall be back this evening to dinner. You shall hear all\r\nthat has happened; and you shall accompany me to London to-morrow--if\r\nI find it necessary to make any lengthened stay there. Between this and\r\nthen, after the shock that you have suffered, you will do well to be\r\nquiet here. Be satisfied with my assurance that Blanche shall have your\r\nletter. I will force my authority on her step-mother to that extent (if\r\nher step-mother resists) without scruple. The respect in which I hold\r\nthe sex only lasts as long as the sex deserves it--and does _not_ extend\r\nto Lady Lundie. There is no advantage that a man can take of a woman\r\nwhich I am not fully prepared to take of my sister-in-law.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that characteristic farewell, he shook hands with Arnold, and\r\ndeparted for the station.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAt seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock the dinner was on the table. At seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock Sir\r\nPatrick came down stairs to eat it, as perfectly dressed as usual, and\r\nas composed as if nothing had happened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has got your letter,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered, as he took Arnold\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and\r\nled him into the dining-room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she say any thing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did she look?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs she ought to look--sorry for what she has done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe dinner began. As a matter of necessity, the subject of Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nexpedition was dropped while the servants were in the room--to be\r\nregularly taken up again by Arnold in the intervals between the courses.\r\nHe began when the soup was taken away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI confess I had hoped to see Blanche come back with you!\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\nsadly enough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn other words,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Sir Patrick, \xe2\x80\x9cyou forgot the native obstinacy\r\nof the sex. Blanche is beginning to feel that she has been wrong. What\r\nis the necessary consequence? She naturally persists in being wrong.\r\nLet her alone, and leave your letter to have its effect. The serious\r\ndifficulties in our way don\xe2\x80\x99t rest with Blanche. Content yourself with\r\nknowing that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe fish came in, and Arnold was silenced--until his next opportunity\r\ncame with the next interval in the course of the dinner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are the difficulties?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe difficulties are my difficulties and yours,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Sir Patrick.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy difficulty is, that I can\xe2\x80\x99t assert my authority, as guardian, if\r\nI assume my niece (as I do) to be a married woman. Your difficulty\r\nis, that you can\xe2\x80\x99t assert your authority as her husband, until it is\r\ndistinctly proved that you and Miss Silvester are not man and wife. Lady\r\nLundie was perfectly aware that she would place us in that position,\r\nwhen she removed Blanche from this house. She has cross-examined Mrs.\r\nInchbare; she has written to your steward for the date of your arrival\r\nat your estate; she has done every thing, calculated every thing, and\r\nforeseen every thing--except my excellent temper. The one mistake she\r\nhas made, is in thinking she could get the better of _that._ No, my dear\r\nboy! My trump card is my temper. I keep it in my hand, Arnold--I keep it\r\nin my hand!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe next course came in--and there was an end of the subject again.\r\nSir Patrick enjoyed his mutton, and entered on a long and interesting\r\nnarrative of the history of some rare white Burgundy on the table\r\nimported by himself. Arnold resolutely resumed the discussion with the\r\ndeparture of the mutton.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to be a dead lock,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo slang!\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Sir Patrick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake, Sir, consider my anxiety, and tell me what you\r\npropose to do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI propose to take you to London with me to-morrow, on this\r\ncondition--that you promise me, on your word of honor, not to attempt to\r\nsee your wife before Saturday next.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall see her then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you give me your promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do! I do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe next course came in. Sir Patrick entered on the question of the\r\nmerits of the partridge, viewed as an eatable bird, \xe2\x80\x9cBy himself,\r\nArnold--plainly roasted, and tested on his own merits--an overrated\r\nbird. Being too fond of shooting him in this country, we become too fond\r\nof eating him next. Properly understood, he is a vehicle for sauce and\r\ntruffles--nothing more. Or no--that is hardly doing him justice. I am\r\nbound to add that he is honorably associated with the famous French\r\nreceipt for cooking an olive. Do you know it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was an end of the bird; there was an end of the jelly. Arnold got\r\nhis next chance--and took it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is to be done in London to-morrow?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Sir Patrick, \xe2\x80\x9cis a memorable day in our calendar.\r\nTo-morrow is Tuesday--the day on which I am to see Miss Silvester.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold set down the glass of wine which he was just raising to his lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter what has happened,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI can hardly bear to hear her name\r\nmentioned. Miss Silvester has parted me from my wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Silvester may atone for that, Arnold, by uniting you again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has been the ruin of me so far.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe may be the salvation of you yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cheese came in; and Sir Patrick returned to the Art of Cookery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know the receipt for cooking an olive, Arnold?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat _does_ the new generation know? It knows how to row, how to shoot,\r\nhow to play at cricket, and how to bat. When it has lost its muscle and\r\nlost its money--that is to say, when it has grown old--what a generation\r\nit will be! It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter: I sha\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99t live to see it. Are you\r\nlistening, Arnold?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow to cook an olive! Put an olive into a lark, put a lark into a\r\nquail; put a quail into a plover; put a plover into a partridge; put a\r\npartridge into a pheasant; put a pheasant into a turkey. Good. First,\r\npartially roast, then carefully stew--until all is thoroughly done down\r\nto the olive. Good again. Next, open the window. Throw out the turkey,\r\nthe pheasant, the partridge, the plover, the quail, and the lark. _Then,\r\neat the olive._ The dish is expensive, but (we have it on the highest\r\nauthority) well worth the sacrifice. The quintessence of the flavor of\r\nsix birds, concentrated in one olive. Grand idea! Try another glass of\r\nthe white Burgundy, Arnold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt last the servants left them--with the wine and dessert on the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have borne it as long as I can, Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold. \xe2\x80\x9cAdd to all your\r\nkindness to me by telling me at once what happened at Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was a chilly evening. A bright wood fire was burning in the room. Sir\r\nPatrick drew his chair to the fire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is exactly what happened,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI found company at Lady\r\nLundie\xe2\x80\x99s, to begin with. Two perfect strangers to me. Captain Newenden,\r\nand his niece, Mrs. Glenarm. Lady Lundie offered to see me in another\r\nroom; the two strangers offered to withdraw. I declined both proposals.\r\nFirst check to her ladyship! She has reckoned throughout, Arnold, on our\r\nbeing afraid to face public opinion. I showed her at starting that we\r\nwere as ready to face it as she was. \xe2\x80\x98I always accept what the French\r\ncall accomplished facts,\xe2\x80\x99 I said. \xe2\x80\x98You have brought matters to a crisis,\r\nLady Lundie. So let it be. I have a word to say to my niece (in\r\nyour presence, if you like); and I have another word to say to you\r\nafterward--without presuming to disturb your guests.\xe2\x80\x99 The guests sat\r\ndown again (both naturally devoured by curiosity). Could her ladyship\r\ndecently refuse me an interview with my own niece, while two witnesses\r\nwere looking on? Impossible. I saw Blanche (Lady Lundie being present,\r\nit is needless to say) in the back drawing-room. I gave her your\r\nletter; I said a good word for you; I saw that she was sorry, though\r\nshe wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t own it--and that was enough. We went back into the front\r\ndrawing-room. I had not spoken five words on our side of the question\r\nbefore it appeared, to my astonishment and delight, that Captain\r\nNewenden was in the house on the very question that had brought me into\r\nthe house--the question of you and Miss Silvester. My business, in the\r\ninterests of _my_ niece, was to deny your marriage to the lady. His\r\nbusiness, in the interests of _his_ niece, was to assert your marriage\r\nto the lady. To the unutterable disgust of the two women, we joined\r\nissue, in the most friendly manner, on the spot. \xe2\x80\x98Charmed to have the\r\npleasure of meeting you, Captain Newenden.\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98Delighted to have the\r\nhonor of making your acquaintance, Sir Patrick.\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98I think we can settle\r\nthis in two minutes?\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98My own idea perfectly expressed.\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98State your\r\nposition, Captain.\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98With the greatest pleasure. Here is my niece,\r\nMrs. Glenarm, engaged to marry Mr. Geoffrey Delamayn. All very well,\r\nbut there happens to be an obstacle--in the shape of a lady. Do I put\r\nit plainly?\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98You put it admirably, Captain; but for the loss to the\r\nBritish navy, you ought to have been a lawyer. Pray, go on.\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98You are\r\ntoo good, Sir Patrick. I resume. Mr. Delamayn asserts that this person\r\nin the back-ground has no claim on him, and backs his assertion by\r\ndeclaring that she is married already to Mr. Arnold Brinkworth. Lady\r\nLundie and my niece assure me, on evidence which satisfies _them,_ that\r\nthe assertion is true. The evidence does not satisfy _me._ \xe2\x80\x98I hope, Sir\r\nPatrick, I don\xe2\x80\x99t strike you as being an excessively obstinate man?\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98My\r\ndear Sir, you impress me with the highest opinion of your capacity\r\nfor sifting human testimony! May I ask, next, what course you mean to\r\ntake?\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98The very thing I was going to mention, Sir Patrick! This is\r\nmy course. I refuse to sanction my niece\xe2\x80\x99s engagement to Mr. Delamayn,\r\nuntil Mr. Delamayn has actually proved his statement by appeal to\r\nwitnesses of the lady\xe2\x80\x99s marriage. He refers me to two witnesses; but\r\ndeclines acting at once in the matter for himself, on the ground that\r\nhe is in training for a foot-race. I admit that that is an obstacle, and\r\nconsent to arrange for bringing the two witnesses to London myself. By\r\nthis post I have written to my lawyers in Perth to look the witnesses\r\nup; to offer them the necessary terms (at Mr. Delamayn\xe2\x80\x99s expense) for\r\nthe use of their time; and to produce them by the end of the week. The\r\nfootrace is on Thursday next. Mr. Delamayn will be able to attend after\r\nthat, and establish his own assertion by his own witnesses. What do you\r\nsay, Sir Patrick, to Saturday next (with Lady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s permission) in\r\nthis room?\xe2\x80\x99--There is the substance of the captain\xe2\x80\x99s statement. He is\r\nas old as I am and is dressed to look like thirty; but a very pleasant\r\nfellow for all that. I struck my sister-in-law dumb by accepting the\r\nproposal without a moment\xe2\x80\x99s hesitation. Mrs. Glenarm and Lady Lundie\r\nlooked at each other in mute amazement. Here was a difference about\r\nwhich two women would have mortally quarreled; and here were two men\r\nsettling it in the friendliest possible manner. I wish you had seen\r\nLady Lundie\xe2\x80\x99s face, when I declared myself deeply indebted to Captain\r\nNewenden for rendering any prolonged interview with her ladyship quite\r\nunnecessary. \xe2\x80\x98Thanks to the captain,\xe2\x80\x99 I said to her, in the most cordial\r\nmanner, \xe2\x80\x98we have absolutely nothing to discuss. I shall catch the next\r\ntrain, and set Arnold Brinkworth\xe2\x80\x99s mind quite at ease.\xe2\x80\x99 To come back to\r\nserious things, I have engaged to produce you, in the presence of every\r\nbody--your wife included--on Saturday next. I put a bold face on it\r\nbefore the others. But I am bound to tell _you_ that it is by no means\r\neasy to say--situated as we are now--what the result of Saturday\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninquiry will be. Every thing depends on the issue of my interview with\r\nMiss Silvester to-morrow. It is no exaggeration to say, Arnold, that\r\nyour fate is in her hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish to heaven I had never set eyes on her!\xe2\x80\x9d said Arnold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLay the saddle on the right horse,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cWish you had\r\nnever set eyes on Geoffrey Delamayn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArnold hung his head. Sir Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s sharp tongue had got the better of\r\nhim once more.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTWELFTH SCENE.--DRURY LANE.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THE FORTY-FOURTH.\r\n\r\nTHE LETTER AND THE LAW.\r\n\r\nTHE many-toned murmur of the current of London life--flowing through the\r\nmurky channel of Drury Lane--found its muffled way from the front room\r\nto the back. Piles of old music lumbered the dusty floor. Stage masks\r\nand weapons, and portraits of singers and dancers, hung round the walls.\r\nAn empty violin case in one corner faced a broken bust of Rossini in\r\nanother. A frameless print, representing the Trial of Queen Caroline,\r\nwas pasted over the fireplace. The chairs were genuine specimens of\r\nancient carving in oak. The table was an equally excellent example of\r\ndirty modern deal. A small morsel of drugget was on the floor; and a\r\nlarge deposit of soot was on the ceiling. The scene thus presented,\r\nrevealed itself in the back drawing-room of a house in Drury Lane,\r\ndevoted to the transaction of musical and theatrical business of the\r\nhumbler sort. It was late in the afternoon, on Michaelmas-day. Two\r\npersons were seated together in the room: they were Anne Silvester and\r\nSir Patrick Lundie.\r\n\r\nThe opening conversation between them--comprising, on one side, the\r\nnarrative of what had happened at Perth and at Swanhaven; and, on the\r\nother, a statement of the circumstances attending the separation of\r\nArnold and Blanche--had come to an end. It rested with Sir Patrick\r\nto lead the way to the next topic. He looked at his companion, and\r\nhesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you feel strong enough to go on?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you would prefer to\r\nrest a little, pray say so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, Sir Patrick. I am more than ready, I am eager to go on. No\r\nwords can say how anxious I feel to be of some use to you, if I can. It\r\nrests entirely with your experience to show me how.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can only do that, Miss Silvester, by asking you without ceremony\r\nfor all the information that I want. Had you any object in traveling to\r\nLondon, which you have not mentioned to me yet? I mean, of course, any\r\nobject with which I have a claim (as Arnold Brinkworth\xe2\x80\x99s representative)\r\nto be acquainted?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had an object, Sir Patrick. And I have failed to accomplish it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I ask what it was?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was to see Geoffrey Delamayn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick started. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have attempted to see _him!_ When?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you only arrived in London last night!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only arrived,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anne, \xe2\x80\x9cafter waiting many days on the journey. I\r\nwas obliged to rest at Edinburgh, and again at York--and I was afraid\r\nI had given Mrs. Glenarm time enough to get to Geoffrey Delamayn before\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfraid?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cI understood that you had no serious\r\nintention of disputing the scoundrel with Mrs. Glenarm. What motive\r\ncould possibly have taken you _his_ way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same motive which took me to Swanhaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! the idea that it rested with Delamayn to set things right? and\r\nthat you might bribe him to do it, by consenting to release him, so far\r\nas your claims were concerned?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBear with my folly, Sir Patrick, as patiently as you can! I am always\r\nalone now; and I get into a habit of brooding over things. I have been\r\nbrooding over the position in which my misfortunes have placed Mr.\r\nBrinkworth. I have been obstinate--unreasonably obstinate--in believing\r\nthat I could prevail with Geoffrey Delamayn, after I had failed with\r\nMrs. Glenarm. I am obstinate about it still. If he would only have heard\r\nme, my madness in going to Fulham might have had its excuse.\xe2\x80\x9d She sighed\r\nbitterly, and said no more.\r\n\r\nSir Patrick took her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt _has_ its excuse,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, kindly. \xe2\x80\x9cYour motive is beyond reproach.\r\nLet me add--to quiet your mind--that, even if Delamayn had been willing\r\nto hear you, and had accepted the condition, the result would still\r\nhave been the same. You are quite wrong in supposing that he has only to\r\nspeak, and to set this matter right. It has passed entirely beyond\r\nhis control. The mischief was done when Arnold Brinkworth spent those\r\nunlucky hours with you at Craig Fernie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Sir Patrick, if I had only known that, before I went to Fulham this\r\nmorning!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe shuddered as she said the words. Something was plainly associated\r\nwith her visit to Geoffrey, the bare remembrance of which shook her\r\nnerves. What was it? Sir Patrick resolved to obtain an answer to that\r\nquestion, before he ventured on proceeding further with the main object\r\nof the interview.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have told me your reason for going to Fulham,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I have\r\nnot heard what happened there yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne hesitated. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it necessary for me to trouble you about that?\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nasked--with evident reluctance to enter on the subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is absolutely necessary,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Sir Patrick, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause Delamayn is\r\nconcerned in it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne summoned her resolution, and entered on her narrative in these\r\nwords:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe person who carries on the business here discovered the address for\r\nme,\xe2\x80\x9d she began. \xe2\x80\x9cI had some difficulty, however, in finding the house.\r\nIt is little more than a cottage; and it is quite lost in a great\r\ngarden, surrounded by high walls. I saw a carriage waiting. The coachman\r\nwas walking his horses up and down--and he showed me the door. It was a\r\nhigh wooden door in the wall, with a grating in it. I rang the bell. A\r\nservant-girl opened the grating, and looked at me. She refused to let\r\nme in. Her mistress had ordered her to close the door on all\r\nstrangers--especially strangers who were women. I contrived to pass some\r\nmoney to her through the grating, and asked to speak to her mistress.\r\nAfter waiting some time, I saw another face behind the bars--and it\r\nstruck me that I recognized it. I suppose I was nervous. It startled me.\r\nI said, \xe2\x80\x98I think we know each other.\xe2\x80\x99 There was no answer. The door was\r\nsuddenly opened--and who do you think stood before me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it somebody I know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMan? or woman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was Hester Dethridge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHester Dethridge!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Dressed just as usual, and looking just as usual--with her slate\r\nhanging at her side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAstonishing! Where did I last see her? At the Windygates station, to\r\nbe sure--going to London, after she had left my sister-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s service.\r\nHas she accepted another place--without letting me know first, as I told\r\nher?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is living at Fulham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn service?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. As mistress of her own house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Hester Dethridge in possession of a house of her own? Well! well!\r\nwhy shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t she have a rise in the world like other people? Did she\r\nlet you in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe stood for some time looking at me, in that dull strange way that\r\nshe has. The servants at Windygates always said she was not in her right\r\nmind--and you will say, Sir Patrick, when you hear what happened, that\r\nthe servants were not mistaken. She must be mad. I said, \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nremember me?\xe2\x80\x99 She lifted her slate, and wrote, \xe2\x80\x98I remember you, in a\r\ndead swoon at Windygates House.\xe2\x80\x99 I was quite unaware that she had been\r\npresent when I fainted in the library. The discovery startled me--or\r\nthat dreadful, dead-cold look that she has in her eyes startled me--I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know which. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t speak to her just at first. She wrote on\r\nher slate again--the strangest question--in these words: \xe2\x80\x98I said, at the\r\ntime, brought to it by a man. Did I say true?\xe2\x80\x99 If the question had been\r\nput in the usual way, by any body else, I should have considered it too\r\ninsolent to be noticed. Can you understand my answering it, Sir Patrick?\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t understand it myself, now--and yet I did answer. She forced me\r\nto it with her stony eyes. I said \xe2\x80\x98yes.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid all this take place at the door?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen did she let you in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe next thing she did was to let me in. She took me by the arm, in\r\na rough way, and drew me inside the door, and shut it. My nerves are\r\nbroken; my courage is gone. I crept with cold when she touched me. She\r\ndropped my arm. I stood like a child, waiting for what it pleased her to\r\nsay or do next. She rested her two hands on her sides, and took a long\r\nlook at me. She made a horrid dumb sound--not as if she was angry;\r\nmore, if such a thing could be, as if she was satisfied--pleased even,\r\nI should have said, if it had been any body but Hester Dethridge. Do you\r\nunderstand it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot yet. Let me get nearer to understanding it by asking something\r\nbefore you go on. Did she show any attachment to you, when you were both\r\nat Windygates?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot the least. She appeared to be incapable of attachment to me, or to\r\nany body.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she write any more questions on her slate?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. She wrote another question under what she had written just before.\r\nHer mind was still running on my fainting fit, and on the \xe2\x80\x98man\xe2\x80\x99 who had\r\n\xe2\x80\x98brought me to it.\xe2\x80\x99 She held up the slate; and the words were these:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell me how he served you, did he knock you down?\xe2\x80\x99 Most people would\r\nhave laughed at the question. _I_ was startled by it. I told her, No.\r\nShe shook her head as if she didn\xe2\x80\x99t believe me. She wrote on her slate,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We are loth to own it when they up with their fists and beat us--ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nwe?\xe2\x80\x99 I said, \xe2\x80\x98You are quite wrong.\xe2\x80\x99 She went on obstinately with her\r\nwriting. \xe2\x80\x98Who is the man?\xe2\x80\x99--was her next question. I had control enough\r\nover myself to decline telling her that. She opened the door, and\r\npointed to me to go out. I made a sign entreating her to wait a\r\nlittle. She went back, in her impenetrable way, to the writing on the\r\nslate--still about the \xe2\x80\x98man.\xe2\x80\x99 This time, the question was plainer still.\r\nShe had evidently placed her own interpretation of my appearance at the\r\nhouse. She wrote, \xe2\x80\x98Is it the man who lodges here?\xe2\x80\x99 I saw that she would\r\nclose the door on me if I didn\xe2\x80\x99t answer. My only chance with her was\r\nto own that she had guessed right. I said \xe2\x80\x98Yes. I want to see him.\xe2\x80\x99 She\r\ntook me by the arm, as roughly as before--and led me into the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI begin to understand her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Patrick. \xe2\x80\x9cI remember hearing, in\r\nmy brother\xe2\x80\x99s time, that she had been brutally ill-used by her husband.\r\nThe association of id eas, even in _her_ confused brain, becomes plain,\r\nif you bear that in mind. What is her last remembrance of you? It is the\r\nremembrance of a fainting woman at Windygates.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe makes you acknowledge that she has guessed right, in guessing that\r\na man was, in some way, answerable for the condition in which she found\r\nyou. A swoon produced by a shock indicted on the mind, is a swoon that\r\nshe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t understand. She looks back into her own experience, and\r\nassociates it with the exercise of actual physical brutality on the part\r\nof the man. And she sees, in you, a reflection of her own sufferings\r\nand her own case. It\xe2\x80\x99s curious--to a student of human nature. And it\r\nexplains, what is otherwise unintelligible--her overlooking her own\r\ninstructions to the servant, and letting you into the house. What\r\nhappened next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe took me into a room, which I suppose was her own room. She made\r\nsigns, offering me tea. It was done in the strangest way--without the\r\nleast appearance of kindness. After what you have just said to me, I\r\nthink I can in some degree interpret what was going on in her mind.\r\nI believe she felt a hard-hearted interest in seeing a woman whom she\r\nsupposed to be as unfortunate as she had once been herself. I declined\r\ntaking any tea, and tried to return to the subject of what I wanted in\r\nthe house. She paid no heed to me. She pointed round the room; and then\r\ntook me to a window, and pointed round the garden--and then made a sign\r\nindicating herself. \xe2\x80\x98My house; and my garden\xe2\x80\x99--that was what she meant.\r\nThere were four men in the garden--and Geoffrey Delamayn was one of\r\nthem. I made another attempt to tell her that I wanted to speak to him.\r\nBut, no! She had her own idea in her mind. After beckoning to me to\r\nleave the window, she led the way to the fire-place, and showed me a\r\nsheet of paper with writing on it, framed and placed under a glass, and\r\nhung on the wall. She seemed, I thought, to feel some kind of pride in\r\nher framed manuscript. At any rate, she insisted on my reading it. It\r\nwas an extract from a will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe will under which she had inherited the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Her brother\xe2\x80\x99s will. It said, that he regretted, on his death-bed,\r\nhis estrangement from his only sister, dating from the time when she had\r\nmarried in defiance of his wishes and against his advice. As a proof\r\nof his sincere desire to be reconciled with her, before he died, and as\r\nsome compensation for the sufferings that she had endured at the hands\r\nof her deceased husband, he left her an income of two hundred pounds a\r\nyear, together with the use of his house and garden, for her lifetime.\r\nThat, as well as I remember, was the substance of what it said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCreditable to her brother, and creditable to herself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir\r\nPatrick. \xe2\x80\x9cTaking her odd character into consideration, I understand her\r\nliking it to be seen. What puzzles me, is her letting lodgings with an\r\nincome of her own to live on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was the very question which I put to her myself. I was obliged\r\nto be cautious, and to begin by asking about the lodgers first--the men\r\nbeing still visible out in the garden, to excuse the inquiry. The rooms\r\nto let in the house had (as I understood her) been taken by a person\r\nacting for Geoffrey Delamayn--his trainer, I presume. He had surprised\r\nHester Dethridge by barely noticing the house, and showing the most\r\nextraordinary interest in the garden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is quite intelligible, Miss Silvester. The garden you have\r\ndescribed would be just the place he wanted for the exercises of his\r\nemployer--plenty of space, and well secured from observation by the high\r\nwalls all round. What next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNext, I got to the question of why she should let her house in lodgings\r\nat all. When I asked her that, her face turned harder than ever. She\r\nanswered me on her slate in these dismal words: \xe2\x80\x98I have not got a friend\r\nin the world. I dare not live alone.\xe2\x80\x99 There was her reason! Dreary and\r\ndreadful, Sir Patrick, was it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDreary indeed! How did it end? Did you get into the garden?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes--at the second attempt. She seemed suddenly to change her mind; she\r\nopened the door for me herself. Passing the window of the room in which\r\nI had left her, I looked back. She had taken her place, at a table\r\nbefore the window, apparently watching for what might happen. There was\r\nsomething about her, as her eyes met mine (I can\xe2\x80\x99t say what), which made\r\nme feel uneasy at the time. Adopting your view, I am almost inclined to\r\nthink now, horrid as the idea is, that she had the expectation of seeing\r\nme treated as _she_ had been treated in former days. It was actually a\r\nrelief to me--though I knew I was going to run a serious risk--to lose\r\nsight of her. As I got nearer to the men in the garden, I heard two of\r\nthem talking very earnestly to Geoffrey Delamayn. The fourth person, an\r\nelderly gentleman, stood apart from the rest at some little distance. I\r\nkept as far as I could out of sight, waiting till the talk was over.\r\nIt was impossible for me to help hearing it. The two men were trying\r\nto persuade Geoffrey Delamayn to speak to the elderly gentleman. They\r\npointed to him as a famous medical man. They reiterated over and over\r\nagain, that his opinion was well worth having--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSir Patrick interrupted her. \xe2\x80\x9cDid they mention his name?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. They called him Mr. Speedwell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe man himself! This is even more interesting, Miss Silvester, than\r\nyou suppose. I myself heard Mr. Speedwell warn Delamayn that he was in\r\nbroken health, when we were visiting together at Windygates House\r\nlast month. Did he do as the other men wished him? Did he speak to the\r\nsurgeon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. He sulkily refused--he remembered what you remember. He said, \xe2\x80\x98See\r\nthe man who told me I was broken down?--not I!\xe2\x80\x99 After confirming it\r\nwith an oath, he turned away from the others. Unfortunately, he took the\r\ndirection in which I was standing, and discovered me. The bare sight\r\nof me seemed to throw him instantly into a state of frenzy. He--it is\r\nimpossible for me to repeat the language that he used: it is bad enough\r\nto have heard it. I believe, Sir Patrick, but for the two men, who ran\r\nup and laid hold of him, that Hester Dethridge would have seen what she\r\nexpected to see. The change in him was so frightful--even to me, well as\r\nI thought I knew him in his fits of passion--I tremble when I think of\r\nit. One of the men who had restrained him was almost as brutal, in his\r\nway. He declared, in the foulest language, that if Delamayn had a fit,\r\nhe would lose the race, and that I should be answerable for it. But for\r\nMr. Speedwell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I should have done. He came forward\r\ndirectly. \xe2\x80\x98This is no place either for you, or for me,\xe2\x80\x99 he said--and\r\ngave me his arm, and led me back to the house. Hester Dethridge met us\r\nin the passage, and lifted her hand to stop me. Mr. Speedwell asked her\r\nwhat she wanted. She looked at me, and then looked toward the garden,\r\nand made the motion of striking a blow with her clenched fist. For the\r\nfirst time in my experience of her--I hope it was my fancy--I thought I\r\nsaw her smile. Mr. Speedwell took me out. \xe2\x80\x98They are well matched in that\r\nhouse,\xe2\x80\x99 he said. \xe2\x80\x98The woman is as complete a savage as the men.\xe2\x80\x99 The\r\ncarriage which I had seen waiting at the door was his. He called it up,\r\nand politely offered me a place in it. I said I would only trespass on\r\nhis kindness as far as to the railway station. While we were talking,\r\nHester Dethridge followed us to the door. She made the same motion again\r\nwith her clenched hand, and looked back toward the garden--and then\r\nlooked at me, and nodded her head, as much as to say, \xe2\x80\x98He will do it\r\nyet!\xe2\x80\x99 No words can describe how glad I was to see the last of her. I\r\nhope and trust I shall never set eyes on her again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you hear how Mr. Speedwell came to be at the house? Had he gone of\r\nhis own accord? or had he been sent for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe had been sent for. I ventured to speak to him about the persons whom\r\nI had seen in the garden. Mr. Speedwell explained everything which I was\r\nnot able of myself to understand, in the kindest manner. One of the two\r\nstrange men in the garden was the trainer; the other was a doctor, whom\r\nthe trainer was usually in the habit of consulting. It seems that the\r\nreal reason for their bringing Geof frey Delamayn away from Scotland\r\nwhen they did, was that the trainer was uneasy, and wanted to be near\r\nLondon for medical advice. The doctor, on being consulted, owned that he\r\nwas at a loss to understand the symptoms which he was asked to treat.\r\nHe had himself fetched the great surgeon to Fulham, that morning. Mr.\r\nSpeedwell abstained from mentioning that he had foreseen what would\r\nhappen, at Windygates. All he said was, \xe2\x80\x98I had met Mr. Delamayn in\r\nsociety, and I felt interest enough in the case to pay him a visit--with\r\nwhat result, you have seen yourself.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he tell you any thing about Delamayn\xe2\x80\x99s health?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe said that he had questioned the doctor on the way to Fulham, and\r\nthat some of the patient\xe2\x80\x99s symptoms indicated serious mischief. What the\r\nsymptoms were I did not hear. Mr. Speedwell only spoke of changes for\r\nthe worse in him which a woman would be likely to understand. At one\r\ntime, he would be so dull and heedless that nothing could rouse him. At\r\nanother, he flew into the most terrible passions without any apparent\r\ncause.
